Review_Text: Work is monotonous. Pay is above minimum wage. Not a ton of room for advancement and the pay increase is nothing to write home about. Covid times have made this worse. Overall a good company to work for regardless.

I loved my job and the people I worked with, but I was completely overwhelmed with my workload when my supervisor didn't follow through on hiring a new colleague after firing someone. I did not feel that my manager had my back, nor would he/she stick up for me when someone threw me under the bus, which is what happened. First time in my 25+ years that I have been fired.
Lots of quality people but it lacks quality senior management leadership. They say the words but do not follow up with their action. Ok place to work but not a place to grow
Great place to work, the travel can get a little exhausting sometimes. Other than that it has great opportunity and has been a major learning experience.
it went very well.  The company is in the Boulder County and next to the foothill.  It is in a very good town.  The traffic there is a lot better than Denver

The leadership is now obsessed with growing at a pace to prevent the parent company Spectris from selling it off.  As a result, leadership has lost focus on the customer and employees, and is only focused on short-term gains to make their bottom line look better.
PMS was a good place to work. I learned a lot there. They taught me how to set-up a CNC Hardinge Lathe and how to fix and make programs to make aircraft parts.
This company employs many with longevity.  It is a company that values its employees and offers many benefits.  Personal expression is welcomed and an intelligent atmosphere is provided.
The manager I have is the worst I have ever had. They had never been a manager before and has no clue how to be one. I think there should be some kind of training
Customers have no idea who they are. The name is ridiculous. Customer Service is a joke, I couldn't wait to leave. The factory is split politically, its embarrassing.
A good overall place to work. Excellent work/life balance with a management team that is overall caring.

Interesting for sure. The director asked me in my interview about my husband. What does that have to do with my skills and abilities? Is a smaller company and they pride themselves on being "healthy". Maybe shouldn't be over forty and overweight or may not get hired.
My previous employer had good solid growth to further expand
Co-Workers and Management Staff helpful and knowledgeable.
Learned ISO requirements and what an ISO company culture looked like. Management was well structured. Co-workers worked well with each other.
Amazing technology to work with - laser-optics. I learned how to work closely with research and development engineers and the design process. Documented design and instructional information.
Adequate company. Management is challenging at times.  And the work is unique and exciting, Requires attention to detail. .............................
Lots of legacy equipment and processes made for a great learning and challenging experience. Lack of new products was/is detrimental to survival. Purchasing could be a challenge.

IF you have experience in the industry it’s a great place to work.No forced overtime,advancement etc. but some jobs workers are treated like dirt.My job had no advancement (according to HR) but in some ways a lot of responsibility and STRESS.Was there 4 years and it kept getting worse.In summary management did NOT support my job (only one  of its kind in the factory) too the point you could not believe it’s the same company.
This is an good ole boys brotherhood of Delphi management. If you need a paycheck wonderful place buy zero advancement unless management sees you as someone who will push their agenda
I truly love my job. This is the type of job I've been looking for my entire professional career. This is the first place I have worked where I feel like I will retire from.
Good place to work, management is supportive, employees are cooperative and helpful. You can apply and move to other departments , if you qualify you will be trained in new department

Good employer. Many years of work and experience. Company got lay offs. After 25 years had no choice but to relocate to east of the united states. Highly recommend company for those living on east coast
Great place to work for.  Good benefits. Good company to work for with lots of on the job training and advancement opportunities.
Really interesting and challenging work. Very inclusive leadership team. Lots of opportunities to grow. My only issue at Excelitas is that the racial inclusivity could use some work.
Great place to work for. Everyone was nice and had a good time being there. A lot of overtime. Good benefits. Fast going and plenty to do. Never a slow day.
Good company to work for very interesting things to learn there also good things to learn from engineering their of making optics for laser and planes for military use

Excelitas has a lot of potential to be a great company to work for.  But, there are too many senior leaders that are more concerned with getting new business and climbing the ladder instead of focusing on their employees and the business that they currently have.  Continuous improvement is frowned upon, constructive or destructive criticism is nonexistent and the leadership team never leads by example.  The expectation is always bottom up and never top down.
Lots of on the job training and advancement opportunities.
The management doesn't even bother to take serious about what the employees feedback to them. Doesn't appreciate what we done for so many years. Treat employee with no respect.
Understaffed, poor leadership and management , untrustworthy, lack of team work. Made days stressful, and often went unappreciated after long hours meeting deadline's.

I was consistently told by my manager that I was at the top of my pay grade and there were no promotions available after shattering expectations year after year and being the consensus best at my position. I was finally told that a raise/promotion would be available earlier this year and after six months of waiting I was then told again that no raises or promotions were possible. I put in my notice shortly after only to be told in my exit interview that I was ~$10,000 below the median salary for my position and nowhere near the top of my pay grade.
Great place to work.  highly advanced work environment.  good managers.  good benefits and wages were ok but Boulder is a very expensive place to live

Not Happy with this work place they just hire people temp and get rid of them when the job is done. Management promised being hired at 6 months and i was working for 9 months with out hire benefits or anything including holiday pay etc.
Very friendly place, peoples are nice , job required many different skills . Building new products was challenging but very interesting and it was a lot of fun and satisfaction.

Great job security, benefits, and culture. Positive place to work. Many different shifts to choose from per your life style. I work Wed thru Saturday 10 hour days. But they have many different shifts to choose from.
Challenging work and deadlines in a rapidly changing field.
Adequate company. Management is challenging at times.  And the work is unique and exciting, Requires attention to detail. .............................

A very good place to work good people everything was fine the company just decided to relocate The business to Denver Colorado and Singapore I had hoped to retire here unfortunately it is the nature of the business profit over people
Very Good place to work, I'm just looking for a change of city and work around where I move to. I have been here for a while my experience with excelitas has been great.

Their very considerate and understanding. They really care about their employees. They involved you in meetings. Your opinion mattered. I would recommended friends to Excelitas. Its a great place to work for.
but what is good for me may not be good for you, that is why I Decline to fill in this area people need to make their own decisions on liking  this company
Always looking for work, when asking supervisor for work, never gets back to you. Makes for very long days. The way things change so fast you can never keep up.
Great group of people to work with, not a stable company.
Excelitas was a great place to work

I learned a lot while working at Excelitas. I feel the managers should have been more in touch with their employees. It was an ok place to work. Good benefits, and PTO. Sometimes work was a little hectic, but it wasn't too stressful.
trabajar con presion la mayoria del tiempo en especial con los clientes ya que la calidad de los servicios y el producto es de primer nivel y el producto el cliente lo exige casi de manera inmediata.
Wide range of photonic products to meet variety of applications for medical, industrial, consumer, and defense customers.  Application and product management team is very supportive.
love the manegement, make the workers feel good about there job, we assemble power supply and other components, need to no how to solder wire, you will be doing lots of electrical mechanical assembly

Very difficult place to work. I put forward my best effort, and only received negative responses from my superiors. The workplace, due to the products we made was frequently 90° in the summer, and was not sufficiently heated in the winter.
Everyone is nice and friendly. They seem to work as a team. Great place to be exposed to domestic and international tax.
I learned and grew with the company each day. Advanced my career with 3 position moves to various departments. Helped out anybody who needed it. Great place to work.
No advancement, most employees are temps. Management only cares about production output and constant cutbacks. Management shows favoritism towards their own ethnicities.

My typical day was conducting HR support for the site, working close with Exempt and Non-Exempt employees. Through my many years with the company, and prior to the change of management,  I was able to advance my knowledge in several areas.
Was excellent, I was a contract employee for five months.
Busy workplace with good people. Job responsibilities require one to wear multiple hats and multi-task.
Hit the floor running and staed busy all day.
Very interesting work always busy. I enjoyed working at Excelitas lots of very nice people.

The lack of unity and clear vision keeps this organization stagnant. Co workers were wonderful! Flexible to accommodate, if you have a day time appt. Management, while they were supportive in certain situations,  lacked employee relations and conflict resolution skills.  Often felt reprimanded for speaking up to assist with changes or offer solutions. Pay range is on the lower end.  Otherwise, if you need short term place to work, and you can tolerate the cons, go for it.
Staff were great. Hungry for updates and communication. Oppressive surroundings. Needs remodeling.

This is a horrible place to work and the culture is extremely toxic.  It is not condusive to learning whatsoever.  I suggest that if you are interested in getting into the medical field, don't work here.

Collaborative culture and open to hearing the opinions of all the staff.  There was some turnover in the departments.  Mostly, everyone at BMC was kind and hardworking and willing to work with others.
A typical day would consist of the receptionist assisting the physicians of their department.

The CEO constantly refers to the company as a 'family' but when it comes down to it, it isn't one. If it weren't for a few individuals and the need for a paycheck, I would have left sooner. Horrible pay. Most of management is not qualified to be a leader, let alone a manager... especially the Director of HR. Who knew memorizing a few HR laws got you a director level. HR is not a resource that employees look for due to

I accepted the “psych NP” position... was told by CEO I’d have an assistant and flexible hours. Bold lies. They stuck me in a supply closet, patients would call it “the dungeon”, barely had room for a desk let alone a computer. You either interact with a pt or no one. No help. If you like seeing patients 8-5 then returning calls and doing prior auths from 5:30 -8 or 9 pm without administrative appreciation then by all means take this job. Biggest regret of my life.

BMC does not appreciate their employees, they do not like current employees to move up in the organization.  The CEO just wants his staff to do more for less, cutting corners where you shouldn't.  Do not appreciate staff with experience because then you would need to pay them more.  There have been some questioning hiring practices, and they do not fill positions with qualified employees.
thing that makes it a little difficult.  The pay is not great and there is not much room for advancement.   It also seems that consistency between managers needs some help.

I loved working with most of the people at the Med Center. I started out in records then move up to Medical Assistant. Most of the Dr's, co-workers etc are great people to work with. It's a company you can stay at for years.
Employees with licenses are replaced by non licensed staff to save money.
I enjoyed working at BMC especially the people I worked with. It is a smaller practice compared to a larger corporate environment so there was more cohesiveness amongst the staff as a whole.
Newly hired for a phone triage position. Phone RN for a busy 6 physician Family Practice. Assess patient concerns during phone interactions, triage emergencies.

I love the people at Boulder Medical Center, but the management is very disorganized. There are exceptions to every policy and things change and employees aren't notified. The pay is not great especially for Boulder. The employees here are amazing and very patient oriented.

In the time I was working at BMC, I saw 2 amazing business office coordinates do their best to make the front end work. They worked with my schooled when I went back to school, and with my time when I needed to kids to certain appointments. However, with time change, comes change in management. New manager comes, I felt like she hated me from the get go, since I started and because I was all "natural" I would never fit in her "click."  I wasn't planning on leaving, but she had other plans. So I decided to move on and leave before she had the chance of firing me.

There was no training program for new employees that needed to learn the software and then turn around and train it. There was no opportunity to be taught by an expert on how the program worked. There was a false sense of accomplishment given by direct management only to be blindsided when upper management was present. They will always flounder in their small time culture and it is sad for all the dedicated people that take so much pride in taking care of patients there.

No one cares about you just a body. I would never recommend this place. I quit because management treated you like a number. I didn’t see my manager once while working there. Every one seemed stressed and was just trying to pay their bills.
RN wages significantly lower than the state average when I worked there. High turn over of MD staff. The company has three different locations, Boulder, Lousiville, and Foothills.

While the company was very open to a new model of care in the beginning, they did not at all support me in this new role. The staff was very nice but management deceiving  and cut-throat and only money oriented, not the patients and clients.

Boulder Medical Center is a large company but it has a small company feel which makes it a great place to work! It is such a great place to work that there are employees who have been with BMC for decades. Because we are an out-patient clinic, there is a work-life balance that you can't find at hospitals - no weekends and no night shifts! You work hard while at BMC but have the time off that you need to rejuvenate outside of work with up to three weeks of PTO earned in your first year. Most of all, its the people at BMC that make it a great place to work. You can see how much they enjoy working with each other and our patients every day!

I've worked at Boulder Medical Center for 8 months. I was told on my first day that "you landed in a good place" and I am happy to report that this is true! My job is fast-paced, which I really like (never a dull moment). Everyone I've met, including my supervisor, is very supportive, accepting of my ideas, and is interested in helping me grow in my position.

The lack of unity and clear vision keeps this organization stagnant. Co workers were wonderful! Flexible to accommodate, if you have a day time appt. Management, while they were supportive in certain situations,  lacked employee relations and conflict resolution skills.  Often felt reprimanded for speaking up to assist with changes or offer solutions. Pay range is on the lower end.  Otherwise, if you need short term place to work, and you can tolerate the cons, go for it.

At Boulder Medical Center there are many specialties, therefore an environment that encourages growth. The hardest part of my job as a float, is when I am unable to fill the shoes of the MA I am filling in for. Administration is very supportive.
I have enjoyed the experiences of the different departments I've had the opportunity to work in. The physicians I have worked with are very knowledgeable and caring individuals.
Amazing coworkers and doctors. Some flows in upper management.

The hardest part of the job was learning the doctor's needs for scheduling. The most enjoyable part of the job was seeing patients who were happy. Most of my co-workers were wonderful. Management could use some communication work. A very busy medical center which is part of what made it enjoyable for me.

I worked in the orthopedics deptment and did 90% paperwork.  The people were very nice,but I expected to do much more patient care.  I did move over to the urgent care where I was allowed to do more patient care, but because of the fact that they were staffed with all RN's except for me again I was limited on what I ws allowed to do.  They are very out of date on equipment and pay.
It was fine. Not much to tell. Some decent people to work with.
Large company with a lot of doctors and staff.   Patients love coming to this clinic and they also bring in their other family members because they get one on one care.
learned a lot on the job for multiple providers. Kept busy all the time.
the teachers can be up and down patience... people working are hard to along with in the data processing department
Department members work well together.  Manager is always open to try new ways of doing things
There is little or no wiggle room in your job and day to day function. A manager is always reviewing, checking and berating you on your work.
management and benefits were poor. got sick and management did not understand.

I was given the freedom to work independently on projects; we all were.  Large reports were run and it was broken up into section and we were all given a piece of the pie.  Clear instructions were given to all of us at one time.  This made working on things much easier as we could all ask questions and get immediate feedback.  We knew what was expected and had once weekly progress meetings.

Nice people. Fun work-place. Good managers. I see about 28 patients a day, doing heights,weights, vitals, treatments, immunize and give meds.,answer phones all day in between, and re-new medications to pharmacies. i fill out referrals, reqisitions, and help the other staff out. The hardest part of the job is trying to get everyone's needs met at the same time some days.The most enjoyable part of the job is the babies and kids.
was a good place to work worked for one dr assisted her with her pts supervisor was kind of overbearing

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.
My experience so far has been great. I've worked in a faster-paced program as well as a slower-paced one and both have been enjoyable so far.

working at this company is good but the manager and Sr management they doesn't help because i been worked for Northrop grumman for 5 months they changer my shift first and second for fourth time and  then i need help from human resources but still same thing i like to worked and help the company grow and Sr management keep changer my shift because my family i leave company and quit jobs it fun work for company

The senior engineers are really skilled and helpful at teaching less experienced engineers the methods and ideologies behind great engineering projects. The management structure rewards hard work and the PTO structure rewards loyalty. I always felt work life balance was really valued, but sometimes overtime was available on a voluntary basis. I felt it was easy to work with my manger to make a roadmap for my career. I felt a strong loyalty to my team, and a drive to do good work without the “family” culture that cuts into a lot of places and can be kind of uncomfortable at times. I can only speak to my team, but it seems like a group of driven individuals who have a common goal. It’s an exemplary culture.
Work life balance is very good. Process management could be more organized. Education and training opportunities are good, especially if you can take advantage of the college tuition program.

Good stepping stone if management likes you. You will often be left to figure out your job as the training is non existent. Managers don't know how to do what you do. Only certain groups will be able to grow and advance.

Management and VPs job hop and play politics to advance their careers while leaving employees at the whims of their decisions. The “mission” and the customer drive the workflow since leadership has no clue how to lead or accomplish anything beyond winning an election (read promotion).

Company prides itself on diversity and inclusion, But fails to back it up. When a program gets cancelled the management side get placed immediately and the employee side gets to fight over scraps or temporary positions. You will work lots of hours. Have zero work life balance. And be nothing but a number to the company. When they decide you are no longer welcome or needed they will find a reason to let you go. Unless your really good at kissing rings or living your life under the radar you will have a hard time staying sane in this company.

They have various programs at the company so you can always switch between them. Also the work is technically challenging and interesting. 9/80 schedule is a good perk that allows to take care of errands. The pay is good for seasoned employees. Benefits are on par with other defense contractors.

It's a good company. Manufacturing jobs are just depressing to me though. If you plan on becoming an engineer this is a good place to work. They will pay for your education and will possibly hire you as an engineer when you graduate.
Lack of on the job training. Throw you into deep waters with lil training. Unfair treatment and very stressful environment. Had to seek out help on my own to do my job properly.
Weird work culture. Engineers really look down on the hard working maintainers and technicians. Be prepared to have a few unfriendly run ins with security and or management there.

Good co-workers, good management, flexible hours, 9-80 with every other Friday off, sometimes 10-80 allowed with every Friday off, paid overtime when approved, good benefits, Melbourne Florida is on the beach.
Great place to work. Always had support from managers and co-workers. Programs in Sierra Vista provided the opportunity to gain experience in domestic and foreign business activities.

As a senior software engineer you can expect to make WELL under the industry average, while working hard and achieving your goals every year, only to have the management give you a "meets expectations" grade and keeping you at the same level year after year.
Work flexibility is great!!! However, I often find myself searching for other opportunities elsewhere. Management has its picks and chooses of who they show favor.

Too much work for one person for a full time job.  Maybe two people.  I started and we lost 2 people in our department of 4 then I was expected to take on work from the 2 people that quit. Very poor management skills.  I found  another job quickly!
The job was okay put the pay was not good I felt I needed to get pay more currency. For that type of work. Put the supervisor was awesome very nice and respectful guy.

Interesting and important work that challenges you to grow your skill set. You will be part of a team that is providing the best products to our military. Opportunities to be involved in specialized classified projects.
Best job I ever had. Left for family illness and not able to return. I would go back in a heartbeat if at all possible. The submarine program was great.
I worked for the Baltimore location and it really had a pleasant atmosphere. I really felt wanted and included in every decision made at this location. overall just great place

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.
Great place to work. Had a great time and met some great people. Had the opportunity to work at multiple sites on both the east and wet coast. Would love to come back.

There is good and bad regardless of where you work. If you maintain a positive attitude, show up to work to actually work, then your experience will probably be favorable, however, if you see work as a social club, get involved in office politics, and feel you are super special and therefore entitled preferential treatment, you will probably not have the best experience. Every company is a "good" company and every one is "bad", at the end of the day your attitude, contributions, and overall work ethic will decide if it's "good" or "bad".
Experience will vary greatly in the organization and team. My team was helpful and friendly.
Northrop Grumman is a fabulous place to work, offering a diverse and inclusive culture, state of the art capabilities, and a genuine interest in doing the right thing.
This job really was enjoyable with it being remote and having a tight knit group of coworkers who all worked together to achieve success. I do not have anything negative to say.
Have to say Northrop will do what i can to keep people after a contract ends. This typically means work is pretty stable. My coworkers and managers are all pretty great.
Good work life balance
If you are more traditional in beliefs/values and management style, it is a good place to be long-term. Most programs are sustained and upkept by older systematic approaches but pay is great.

I don't have anything negative to say about this company but the medical insurance is too expensive. The day goes by so fast. It is a fun place to work, it is challenging but it's a place where you can absorb so much experience. it could be fast pace or relaxing. People are friendly. Management is  is willing to work with you on getting you into a different position or stepping into the next level if you really want to; you set your goals. They have tuition reimbursement. It is easy to transfer to other areas or other states. They are very flexible with schedules; 9/80 schedule is awesome.
People are very helpful and welcome you. Benefits are good but not the best. Happy to be working but the pay is below what the industry pays. They lowball you and they’re unorganized.
this is a terrible place to work.  i hated every moment of it.  the managers are idiots and it seems to be run by people who don't ccare for humanity.

A stable and always striving to implement improvements to the organization. A very safety awareness program is in place and is communicated and enforced to the working community to improve ever ones environment.
Overall  it has ben a positive experience working at NG.  mgmt support can improve and career advancement can be slow.  i would recommend NG over all and for the most part enjoy working here.
My company was purchased and absorbed, took forever but got a sweet pay raise for my troubles. They pay well, only wish they would have replaced our old leadership with better
Great company to work for. 13 year air force veteran, straight to Northrop after separation and I couldn't be happier. You can work 40 hours a week or over 80, with overtime. The extra money is nice
Long hours pay was great time away from home no room for advancement. Travel was great. Job opportunity wasn’t there. Too many bosses. Plenty of overtime
Great company, hard work pays off. If you work hard and keep track of what you’re doing you can bring that up at your midyear and end of year review and get rewarded for it
I've only done an internship with them so far, but it was a great experience although it was remote due to the pandemic. Hoping to work on site soon as a full time employee, we shall see how it goes!

NG provided the rigor necessary to be knowledgeable in common industry practices. You can learn a lot if you work for the “right” manager or organization. Advancement is possible as long as you play the game (know the right ppl and be at least decent at your job). If your aspirations are much higher than middle management, unless you’re one of the “chosen” you’ll need to leave or you’ll be stuck.
Was there for almost 8 years, only got 1 decent pay raise. Overworked and underpaid. I would not recommend. Customer was very demanding on unrealistic expectations.

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.
Great company to work for!
I learned a lot working at Northrop/Grumman and always felt that the work was worthwhile and important. The worst part about the job was complying with often ridiculous government requirements.
Opportunity to be involved with cutting edge work. Growing pains and management causing turnover, but that is to be expected. Supportive immediate manager, flexibility.

Northrop Grumman is such a big place that you can make your own destiny. If you are intentional about getting yourself on a well-run program, you will have a great experience. If you just wait for things to happen, you probably won't be given the best opportunities.
Enjoyable work experience! I've worked for Northrop for the past fifteen years.  The management and co-workers have all been easy to work with and the situations have all been fair and equitable.

Very professional environment. Management was always supportive. Very customer oriented with emphasis on customer satisfaction. My manager went out of her way to help me accomplish goals and be successful.
Good company to work for. Handle your business and perform daily job function and you'll be fine. That's all I have to say in regards to northrop grumman

The company was always able to respond to any questions about the job specifically. Out going with events for the family. Very compassionate about time off and any family issues. Flexible about the off time schedule. Precise about your Avenue to advance in the work place.

Best company I have ever worked for. I wish I was still working there. My department really worked well as a team and I always knew what was on the agenda. Everything was well thought out and planned.
Great place to work, the infrastructure is second to none I've experienced,  staff owns there work share.  An amazing group to work with, regret having to leave that job.

I was really looking forward to working at this company, but within less than a month of my first day they shared with the team I had been hired into that funding, which had been originally allocated late the previous year, had been substantially cut by as much as 50%, and that we were to stop all work and time charging immediately.
very tiny pay increases, they are quick to punish good workers yet allow riff raff to do as they please.  they don't follow up with promises, "forgetfulness" is prudent among requests, etc.

The company offers really great benefits, the culture is diverse, supportive and they encourage growth. Upper level leadership is as expected mostly blind to the minute details of each employee and I'm not stating that as a negative. Middle and lower management could definitely use some work. Micro-managing is abundant, and some managers haven't quite grasped the concept of delegation and/or proper delegation of tasks. They are however very accommodating to help you find the right fit for you talents and skills, but sometimes there isn't a position available. Their ideas on what a manager should be is a bit outdated as well. Enlisted military beware... they DO NOT understand that those who have been SNCOs know how to be leaders and have been for 15+years,  nor do they pay you the same.
Worked with very nice managers and coworkers. Family atmosphere and everyone was treated respectfully. Pay was decent but raises could have been better.

Have been supportive during pandemic. Work from home is standard for everyone that is not essential factory or working classified programs.  Good mix of commercial, NASA and classified programs in Gilbert.

I worked at several defense contractor companies and they're all relatively the same. Northrop does have better vacation time, 3 weeks to start. Pay is better than competitors. Management is poor. They hire you without having a role for you, which seems fine until you realize the managers want very specific skills. I came in as an RF engineer and when I met other managers to get on a project I quickly realized they were looking for programmers. I think you need to stay here a couple years before you start to get any work done. Overall it's not much different than other defense contractors.
It is a good company to work for however the promotions will come hardly.
Work on new technologies and company invests back in people.  Was able to complete two masters degrees with assistance from the company.    Opportunities to move within the company.

Good place to work but like any company, training can be better. Lots of new young people  that needs better leadership. Sometimes direction is lacking and morning meetings are grilling sessions. Other than that, the products are cool and rewarding to work on.
Company offers really good benefits.  If you are a contractor it can take a year or more before you can get hired permanently.  The pay could be a little more

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.
Good pay and raises. Building aircraft is not a bad job. Fun people to work with and for. Mandatory overtime is what I didn't like. It was supposed to be a 4/10 shift but turned into 6/10.

Manger revolving door. Zero synergy in any department. Incompetent persons at every level, aging key stake holders not caring. Benefits are good after you work there long enough. Unless your salary. Might be better.

Depending on which site you will begin your career with Northrop, you can advance a lot in your career. Good benefits and education allowance. 9/80 schedule is awesome. My manager always tries to help me and makes sure whatever my goals are, that they are met. People I work with are all considerate and are willing to help.
The Sunnyvale site is a great place to work with a lot of camaraderie and people who take pride in their work.  Management is variable through the site and always changing.
You work hard and are compensated for said work. Great benefits and yearly bonuses. No real complaints about the compnay. Though it gets extremely hot.
Highly compensated cog within the inefficient machine of the US DOD. Not much actual work to be done. Lots of paperwork preventing actual work from being accomplished.

As with all companies, you'll have good and bad programs and organizations. I feel like Northrop Grumman might be trending to not as good as it used to be. Definitely the case for my current program. Some toxic upper leadership is really hurting our team.

If you enjoy working the same tasks each day then this would be the place for you. There is not much career growth because it is the mentality of "do your time" before promoting. However, I have seen people get promoted because they are the favorite, so really it doesn't matter how hard you work.
This is one of the best companies that I have ever worked at. They work with employees for your individual success. Pay raises and benefits  are adequate.
Overall NGC is a big company with good benefit (not the best), but the organization need to have a better manager to help their engineer to be success.

If you like a fast paced work environment where your work actually matters look no further.  They make parts for military aircraft like the F-35 to rockets.  They pay is great, you get regular raises on a consistent basis, they also give yearly "merit" increases kind of like a cost of living increase but you have to earn it, yearly profit sharing based on scrap rate, accidents and other factors.  They like to promote from within as well.  You get more support from you team leads than managers only because you interact with them more, managers help make sure the process runs smoothly and that the team leads have the materials they need to keep the shop floor running efficiently.  They do operate on what is called Six Sigma, efficiency = speed.
Good opportunities for advancement, provided you apply for them through the company's system.  Management was pretty disorganized.  They didn't know the details of what they were managing
Basically the most basic company ever. Lot of opportunity to grow and develop skill sets and expanding useful knowledge. Would recommend to all friends and family.
I love working here.  While work life balance is not possible since we are very busy, everyone is very helpful.  My manager is a wonderful person and very helpful.

Was a payroll processor ran all weekly  and biweekly reports and made all necessary corrections before the confirming of the payrolls. Such as all time loaded correctly, direct deposit is correct  and all employees were paid correctly with no missing hours.

Northrop Grumman has a great culture as a company. Competitive pay and good upper management. I feel like a valued employee. The only reason I am moving on is because NG doesn't really have a commercial space presence.

It was an awesome experience, however the culture needed a little development. A typical work day was from 0730-1430, several meetings per day with very little time to complete your work. Management expected you to complete work on time and if not, completed at home. Many managers did not have to leadership experience to to develop subordinates. Hardest part of the job was navigating management and leadership to get approvals. The most enjoyable part of the job was the people.

I was very experienced at my job and worked at NGC for 15 years as nurse case manager for work comp and accommodations. I was a SME.  The job was very busy. I had to work with HR, ER, Legal, and the work comp adjusters and management. I worked with EH&S.  I received awards.  I had 2 awards for the accommodation process and work comp process from Platinum awards. I wrote articles in the daily news for NGC that came out everyday and I had articles in the daily news for  at least one to two times a month that dealt with health, wellness, accommodations, and work comp. The hardest part of my job was management. The most enjoyable part was working with the employees who were on work comp and employees that  needed accommodations.  I also enjoyed the VOICE ERG.  I was on the board.  There was an opening for the management job where I worked and I did not get it.  They picked in inexperienced outside person to get the job who only had HR experience.  My manager before the manager I had who picked the outside HR person called me and was upset I did not get the job. He thought I should quit too. I quit and gave 2 weeks notice and left.  The department fell apart in 3 months.  Now I work for General Dynamics IT and I am the manager for work comp for this sector.  I carry a case load of 200 employees.  I have received numerous awards.  Even though I have been at GDIT for 5 years, Northrop Grumman is the better company to work for and I miss it so much.  I really did not want to leave, but I had no choice.
Northrop Grumman treated me very good, I worked there for over 40 years, and they were supportive through out my life, the best employer I could have ever asked for, and I would do it all again!

Overall great company to work for though depends heavily on your team. The original team I started with was amazing but after three years it's a vastly different team due to promotions, shifting departments and attrition. I would definitely recommend working here despite this for the job security and compensation is tough to beat. The work is varied and interesting as well.

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.

You can go as far as you want here. Management wants you to keep climbing to new areas and roles. They are also ok with you staying in a role if you are succeeding at it and are not looking to advance.
Great place to work. It's rewarding seeing your hard work fault in an awesome product. The company cares about their employees, their career paths and work life balance.

Great work life balance. Daily scrums are kind of useless since some people don't show up but generally everyone is very nice and encouraging. Work can get monotonous and slow sometimes but glad to see new managers embracing new tools/technology.
37 years doing some of the most interesting work.
I started in May, 2020 in the early days of the pandemic, so onboarding was all remote and somewhat chaotic.  My manager did a LOT of work to make it successful.

Working at Northrop is heavily dependent on your team, some days you'll get a decent amount of work and others you will get close to none. Management isnt really helpful and raises are very small. You will notice the bigger raise once promoted, but now they take forever to process your promotion. In addition, if you want to move to another team in another department or building, they're generally not very open about it. The good is that you will have a great work/life balance, gym is open if its in your building, people are nice and smart!
Wish I stayed and didn’t take a voluntary layoff

I worked as an engineer alongside production. Promised every other Friday off, and day shift. That ended up being the night shift, 10 hours a day, 6 days a week. People who only worked 45 hours a week were told they need to pick it up. I left that program and came over to GBSD as an engineer with the promise that I would work in "X" city alongside a mentor. I'm actually sitting an hour away from "X" city, and the "mentor" is in another state trying to train 12 other people at the same time. Its so mismanaged I spent weeks without even a computer or a desk. I was finally given a task to do after being here 4 months, and people are too busy to help me out with training. I have no idea what I'm doing every day, and its like pulling teeth to get answers to my questions. Some people love it here and have great managers, I just got the short end of the stick I guess.

If you weren’t one of the people who sucked up to the bosses then you didn’t get anywhere. If just did your job to the best of your abilities you were looked down upon. If you were lazy and a suck up then you get promoted
Great place to work.  Positive work environment with opportunity for growth and career advancement.  Lots of positive mentorac to help develop your career.
Overall the benefits and coworkers are what make this place awesome. I enjoy the recognition that is given by management and other employees. Reviews are given frequently which determines bonuses.
I enjoyed the work, the people I worked with, and most of the customers who visited and had to be logged in the system.   At 71, I would gladly go back and work their.

1575 is a cool new office that houses both manufacturing and the office. Tries to blend functionality with some perks of tech companies. Lunches in the cafeteria are expensive. Engineers co-mingled with finance. Nice cubes with doors that can shut. Pretty quiet environment. Difficult to move up as many promotions are time-based.

Northrop Grumman has excellent programs to work on via many contracts with the US Government and Governments around the world.  Contracts support the warfighter.  Benefits and compensation is comparable to other Defense Contractors.

Definitely a company of baby-boomers and less millennials. Company's process and implementations moves slow. It trying to move towards be agile but people are still slow to be innovative and embrace it. Still stuck in old way of thinking which takes forever to create change.
I was an intern for summer COVID-19. The work was good, and they put a lot of work into making an inclusive remote-work environment. I am thinking of working at the company full-time.
When you have an employer that values you;  as an employee you give 150% toward the job you are doing.  The workplace culture was one of inclusiveness and respect.
401K allows you to invest in Fidelity Brokeragelink using any stock symbol on the exchanges  Great company to work for.  Salary is pretty good.  Flexible work schedules
The management at the director level has zero regard for the safety, well-being or health of the employees. They are concerned with one thing: meeting their bonus markers.

Many of the jobs are bait & switch. This is understandable if you have to wait a long time to get a clearance so that you can't do the type of work you applied and interviewed for, but this still happens even after you have your clearance and have been with the company for a while. I think a part of the problem is that they are usually short of people and or the roles they need they are not getting (qualified?) applicants for--so you are kind of dropped into these open spots and that's where you're stuck.

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.

There are some great people working at NG, but it won't be enough to keep you around. Everyday things change and there is no point in relying on a plan. They would rather run you ragged then defend you if anything comes up. The projects can be cool, but unless you handle stress and lack of direction I'd steer clear.
Job Work/Life Balance is amazing.
encourages innovation & self discipline actively promotes higher education

ME in manufacturing area. Lot of different projects and disciplines to work on and opportunity to work overtime. Have to learn how to work with people from different backgrounds (operators, specialists, inventory, supply chain). Can be really bureaucratic at times.

Home work balance is great and the company for the most part makes you feel apart of something bigger. Management has gotten too clicky with under qualified workers getting positions because who they know. But overall good experience with room for development/growth.

The tasks from a daily perspective challenge people through variability.  The culture is heavily focused on the quality and reliability of the products to support the warfighter.  Great products and excellent customer base with solid revenue growth potential.  Many leaders finding a path to promotion, but few internal candidates moving into leadership roles to fill the voids.  Values diversity.
Management don't care about there employees. They are only interested in the company goals.

I always had a great time with the work and people at Northrop Grumman.  The compensation was commensurate to the position and experience.  I had a very reliable team that functioned well together, but also had a diverse set of individual skills.

I got assigned a software role despite being a mechanical engineer (I have a cs minor). The work was very intellectually stimulating. The office and facilities were decent--nothing spectacular. The fellow interns were nice and smart people.

NG has always placed technical excellence at its peak goal. Though I suffered layoff due to force reduction, NG was never unfeeling or mechanical where its employees were concerned. A top shelf company.

My experience at NGC was excellent.  My management chain was very supportive and outstanding leaders. The group of individuals I worked with were outstanding from technical, professional, and personal points of view.

Do not work there. Absolutely horrible. Management only cares about their monthly bonuses. They treat you like dirt. Worse place I’ve ever worked out. They lied during interview about pay and hours available. Nothing management said was true.

90% of the business requires a security clearance.  Really looking for people with clearances right off the line. This narrow requirement puts programs understaffed and settling for less qualified people because they have a security clearance.  Contrary and backwards thinking if you ask me.

My manager was trusting and allowed me to do my job without micro managing my daily activities.  He was one I could brainstorm ideas without fear.  There is an insufficient number of staff to get the job done well and effectively.  You are pushed to the limit to satisfy another's commitment.  There is a lot that could be said but it would fall on deft ears.
Northrop is an excellent place to work. If you are looking for a secure organization that will give you a sense of purpose, this could be a great place for you.

Ngc is a nice place to work, you'll get to work on challenging products, with a rewarding feel due to the nature of the work (military). The benefits are nice as they use the 9/80 schedule, have flex time, and OT even for salaried employees. However, it is a challenging job, and you should expect to work pretty hard.

The company does a poor job of growing the entire workbase. Only focused on top performers club, and no opportunities if you don't get in. No transparency on who did what to get there and a tendency to move the goal posts and a better luck next year to those who did not.

I liked the job, because you get to learn about so many things.Navy boats make America strong.The only thing I disliked was that the Workers Union promises you so many benefits and at the end when I quit my job, I never saw that money???
As a contract technician, I performed certain tests and wrote reports. Work intensity varied in its pace. At times, short deadlines but other times there was time to solve issues.

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.

This company averages 2 to 3 minor or major reorganizations a year within Mission Systems.  While this might make sense from a management perspective, at a lower level its pure chaos and is adversely affecting the products that are created and now employee morale.  The company has an identity crisis and outside of space and air doesnt understand what to focus on.  Upper management has also shown a complete disdain for employees by forcefully selling off 6400 people and a huge portion of their Cyber, IT and internal R&D talent 2 weeks before Xmas including two of their most productive sys architects in recent company history.  Benefits, tuition assistance and pensions have been cut or minimized and its now just a very average defense contractor with below average leadership and vision.  Too much of a reliance upon Agile micromanagement for system building.  Stay away from this company if you are Cyber or until the dust settles.  You might find a great program, but do you really want to work for a company that sells you off like cattle?

stressful place to work management have no clue what is going on most people are mean if you are new hire hard to find help if you have question about the job you doing it is hard to find some one who will help you
I was a summer intern at Northrop Grumman during Covid, this internship was just exposure to the company so I did not learn too much and often times I was not utilized.

I retired from Northrop Grumman in 2011 after 27 years at the Corporate office and loved working there.  Northrop was like a big family and takes great pride in the products it makes and each and every plane that comes off the line. I miss working at Northrop Grumman to this day and working with all the wonderful people I met along the way.  Best Company ever!!!
The only way to get promoted is to either sleep with your boss or be kin to someone. There is no way to work your way up on merits or hard work and the pay is good for this area.
Although working at Northrop was a good experience I feel like the need for more hands on training was needed, as well as they need to update old equipment
Very stable place to work and great people to work with. The culture is great people are very helpful. The management was okay, could have more young people in those positions.
Great job, awesome benefits, plenty of overtime if you wanted it.
Good place to work. Understanding people. Challenging work. Willing to go the extra mile when unexpected issues occur in someone's life.

As a female engineer in the aerospace industry, I've never seen so many female program managers and regular managers in one company - this is HUGE progress in this male-dominated industry.   Almost everyone is technically top-notch.  There is a reason why this company is doing so well.

NG is not a bad place at all to work. You can make average money, get decent benefits etc but it can be quite dry especially if you aren't an engineer. Sure you could work here and have a pretty nice standard of living it is just boring and dry. Feels a little like the matrix. A cog in a wheel in a cube doing mindless work. Would go back though if I was in a pinch to reset my life if I fell off the wagon and had to.

NG has domestic and international operations with excellent and mature engineering, business, HR, and T&E organizations. Their peer reviews are key to their success. Highly customer focused, employees come second but are well managed and highly respected professionals who are well trained; they have well equipped labs and have on-site advanced technical degrees available through local universities that are located onsite at main NG campuses such as Melbourne Florida.  Some outlying NG sites such as those in West Virginia are much poorer in employee support and satisfaction; and have fewer onsite employee services such as training and HR.
like most places - Northrop has its ups and downs - it's a pretty decent place to work - sometimes we are under the gun to meet a deadline but overall people are pretty cool including the boss

Worst place I ever worked as an IT professional.  Back stabbing and out right hostile co-workers and clueless management.  The first day of work I was warned by the hiring manager that they had a "person that was difficult". He was talking about the insane b*c that drove people to quit.

I came to work everyday that I had to work, was never late, was willing to help and assist everyone that could use my experience. I did learn alot about reworking coated components and removing them. My soldering there was always shinny and clean, no pin holes, no insufficient solder, no pin holes., etc. I enjoy soldering and building boards, working with wires of 30 awg for test purposes. I just got bored when it did slow down at work and that made me want something different to challenge. I did enjoy my

Northrop Grumman is a great place to advance your career. I enjoyed working for Northrop Grumman for over 14 years. I got opportunities to advance my career and they pay for education as well. The work-life balance is very good.
Good team dynamics where everyone is focused on delivering a quality product to the customer. Some room for growth, but your career can stall if more senior employees do not move up or on.
Work-life balance
a typical day at work- on site and work from home
decent place to work. pay could be a lot better. so could management. once your on the production floor its hard for you to leave managers dont want to let you move up

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.
Terrible management very clicky. Employees not willing to help each other. patrionizing among newer employees. Very limited unless you have a clearance, those that do act entitled.
-Company has lots of resources
I've worked for this company for nearly 10 years and have had the opportunity to grow and learn many new things.  I would recommend working for this company.

It was an awesome place to work b4 NG bought out OrbitalATK. The usual big corporation, you're  no longer a person, but a # and a $ as they slowly, but surely strip the progressive raises, a point system, more ridiculous rules, etc.
I retired from Northrop Grumman and I would return if offered a position.   There are opportunities to advance or attend college to further your career.

Highly specialized job inside Post Office sorting hub fixing and maintaining machines that searched for certain poisonous chemicals in the mail.  ( I didn't work directly FOR the Post Office, though). Northrop is an outside contractor.

I worked for Northrop Grumman I.T. when they acquired Newport News Shipbuilding. I worked with amazingly bright, kind people from the original organization. While I was not laid off, other people were. NG wasn't hesitant to cut labor costs to increase profit.
This is a great place to work! Work environment pleasant, management friendly and helpful. Learning tools are provided.  Everyone works together to achieve goals.

The worst part can be being enclosed in a windowless space for 8-10 hours a day, with no access to the internet for music or something to make the day a little easier. No cell phones, smart tech etc keeps you nice and cut off from the world... Huge culture around living to work.

Ok company, not the best i worked for in mg 35 years in software development role.  IMHO Aurora location is more concerned with being extra inclusive of homosexual community/workers than heterosexual individuals.

This place provided a sense of purpose when working on different projects. I was able to grow and had a great manager who help support me to branch out and learn new things. I would recommend this place.

The work was interesting and I was busy most of the time. Management was good for the most part but there was some managers that were hard to work for and expected too much even when they they weren't my manager. The hours were flexible and family is important to the company. The benefits were really good. I did feel like I was being held back and was kept too busy to be able to advance my career and receive the additional training that was available.
Best place to work, great management support an work life balance. Carrier growth, training, tuition, job rotations, mentoring, managers care about professional training and growth .

I had over 30 years experience in Quality & knew there was always more to learn.  Aerospace is a great learning arena. I spent over 10 years with this facility, resigned earlier this year. The biggest downfall was the lack of communication, insufficient training & hiring unqualified management. (Ex. hiring a facility Quality Manager that had no previous experience in Quality, much less Aerospace). Trying to do your best meant dealing with ignorance & arrogance on a daily basis. Integrity was practiced by many, but not by most of higher positions. This place may look great on paper but it can be a very toxic work environment that can weigh on a persons health & well being.

Great place to work. Very organized company with a matrix organizational structure to ensure that employees a career development goals are met. Functional managers and program leadership collaboration is key to employee satisfaction and retention. A company that truly care about their employees. Multiple programs at the Huntsville location provide immense opportunities for employees to develop their full potential and grow within the company. Many social and community activities including Employee Resource Groups! Great place to work  for all generations!

Work environment sucks rules are out rageous people are fake in it's like working in a high school environment.  It's like going back to school all over again with how many people are willing to tattle tale

Overall I love my work, my team, and the mission. I feel rewarded in my job. Compensation is good. Promoting within a single role is fair. Trying to expand to other departments on a stretch assignment can be difficult, but worth it.

Management has gone downhill since I first started a few years ago. Very competitive and manipulative, office politics are more important than genuinely recognizing hard working employees. Faked sympathy when employees lost loved ones to COVID-19 or otherwise -- they just wanted them to go right back to work because of lack of staff. Employees left because they were pushed out (politics) or they were tired of the environment, even some long-term employees who had worked there for over a decade. Overworked and underappreciated.
Work day was 9 hours

This review is for the Azusa location only and I have no experience with other branches of NG. The management is tone-deaf. You probably have  better results talking to a wall. The work was not steady, very few large projects, not much else. Compensation was decent, but terrible benefits and getting worse every year. I worked there a little over 1.5 years and I knew by the 6th month, this wasn't where I wanted to stay. The place feels like a state prison from the moment you enter. People are robotic and cold and no much socializing going on.

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.

It's an okay place to work. However as a government contractor their medical benefits are not the greatest. Company culture is okay. Most employee activities are employee initiated, so not much on employee appreciation.

Northrop Grumman made me enjoy my choice of major in college even more. Not only did they provide me with opportunities to grow within the company, but I was exposed to multiple professions and teams on each program that taught me new skills I never would have learned in school. The communication between management and employees is carefully structured to ensure not only proper communication, but involvement from each level. Whether it’s a starting point or an ending point, Northrop has so much to offer , with new opportunities being added daily.
Its a good place to start your  career  an doesnt make you feel like you won't be able to grow alot of good opportunities to develop an move up in a company just need to have the mindset.
Opportunity to work in a manufacturing environment.

I really enjoyed the teams I worked with during both internships. The team was always supportive of me, and even people who I did not directly work with were willing to help guide me in the right directions.

This is a really fun job. If you are not looking for something that is insanely challenging, and can handle lots of rushing/down time then this is a good job for you. (You do still need to know your stuff for those out of the norm times tho)

Not a bad place to work, great place to advance, rather quickly. Problem is, there is no accountability for people who mess up parts, or leave machines not properly 5s, it's almost like 5s is there, only for the name, and not utilized, or followed at all.

I worked as a High School Technical Intern. I barely had any training. All of my training was on an outdated website that taught me things irrelevant to my job title. My manager seemed as though she had no time for me, because she was busy meeting deadlines and so was everybody else. It seems you have to already know how to do your job before you get here. Unless you get lucky and have a great manager or coworkers that are willing to train you, I warn high school interns to stay away. The pay was the only reason I stayed for as long as I did. Oh, and don't get me started on the "meetings".......

In my experience, Northrop Grumman is an excellent company who values their employees more than most in the industry. If you need to have someone hovering over you to ensure you get things done correctly and in a timely manner then this is not the place for you. If you are self motivated and value the quality of your work then look no further.
Only left due to politics, otherwise good company to work for.  Flexible scheduling.  Collaborative, friendly environment. Very welcoming for those new to the workforce.
Great place to work. With lots of voluntary overtime. Ability to move around in the company and learn a lot of things. Pay is ok. Benefits are great a little over priced but great coverages.
Northrop is a good company to begin your career. Management has a disconnect with employees and do not believe in promoting based on merit. Overall, I was pleased with my time at Northrop.
Good glad to work there's contract work was over.  Don't have much else to talk about. There ok it's been awhile. Would like to work again. Had a good job.
Grumman was a great place to work with some really good benefits. Managers were very open and easily approachable. Really good culture with a lot of training assets

Very territorial work environment; people hoard work and resources.  When you accidentally venture into someone else's work responsibilities, you will be pushed aside, not welcomed. People actually yell at each other when they're upset. Program managers seem to think that kind of behavior is okay. Lots of organization and process; average teamwork.  The parking lot is full of weeds and cracks.  Missing hooks in restroom stalls - no place to put one's gear. Very tight work spaces, even for senior staff. Someone had the idea that Agile processes are facilitated by people crammed together in former computer rooms. Little pride of ownership evident in the upkeep of the exterior facilities.   Makes me wonder about the quality of the work done.

I learn something along my job duties almost everyday. It stress free depending on your position and duties. You have a manager that may not be on your current team but they are actively involved in your needs and answering any questions you may ask.

Good company, I knew a lot of Northrup employees and they were all happy. I was dealing mostly with managing alerts for systems. When they went down I would go to my go-to Linux guy and he would fix it.
I would love to have continued being a employee at NG unfortunately I was layed off due to government contract ending . Hopefully I will have a chance to be employed with the company again
excellent place to work. very rewarding. great people who accept me and like working with me. can always get the answers I need. I look forward to going to work.

They are very focused on the mission but will take care of the employee as well. When a contract is lost or funding is cut from it, they work with the employee to find a place within the organization rather than cut them. This process can and sometime have taken more than a few months. This dedication to the employee is why they stay with the company.

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.
Productive and work with work life balance and good people.  Nice place with they won't rush for things, so we work with quality jobs & Proper documentation and proper comments in the code.
It’s who you know & nothing else matters.

The lab I work in is very informal and relaxed. We can openly discuss any issues that arise without fear of reprisal. We are afforded ample time to complete work assignments and the hours are fairly flexible (come in early or work a little late).
If I didn’t have to move I’d still be there today it was a great company to work for great atmosphere and very family oriented they always made you feel welcomed and awarded your achievements

Overall, the internship was extremely enjoyable and gave me a good look into what it would be like to work in the defense industry. My team was very supportive and tasks felt easily achievable because of this.

they will tell you what you want to hear to hire you. They  will do it for enough time to get you but then screw with you. Do not believe they care for you family life or personal life. It all about business needs
I have worked at Lockheed and Northrup they are similar good companies. When I walked in to Northrup I thought how I felt just like at ,Lockheed I had a sense of being at home in this company.

Don't work here at all. Its not a safe place to work and when u do get hurt they make an example out of u by posting your injury "pictures" everywhere for everyone to see. Just to remind u of your injury that u would like to forget about every single day.

This is like working in a factory a lot of walking not much support from management learn as you go you’re on your own. This Was a job that she’s been filled by a entry-level technician that can be trained and mentored

if you are considering working at Northrop Grumman Beltsville be aware that there are a lot of ridiculous personalities who are allowed to continue working despite numerous complaints against them.  Supervisors who work 2 or 3 hours per day and disappear for hours.  They show up again the next day and want to know why you haven't completed all the work in their absence.  This company is not willing to update practices because most employees have been doing things the same for 15+ years and DO NOT want to change.
Great place to work. With lots of voluntary overtime. Ability to move around in the company and learn a lot of things. Pay is ok. Benefits are great a little over priced but great coverages.
As a whole I Love working for the company, there's so much room for growth. I like how we come together and move people around to help other job sites get task  completed in a timely manner.
I have enjoyed my time at Northrop Grumman. My manager was great to work for and always gave us the opportunity to learn more. There is also a lot of chance to move up.
I never expected to be treated so well in a huge company. Here, i am valued for the skills and expertise that I possess, and am compensated fairly compared to other companies I've been with.
Review rankings and promotions are too subjective and heavily skewed towards younger workers. No real career path unless you make one yourself and get the required buy in from management.
Good company, nice working environment. Manufacturing areas are very safe. People are very professional. Benefits are generous. You can make self improvement. Many opportunities for advancement.
Northrup Grumman is a great place to work and has a lot of room for moving up in the company if you are willing to be involved. The company is very flexible aswell
Great place to work. They have a great culture and there are a lot of ERG (employee resource group) options to chose from. There is a sense of belonging.
Enjoyed the experience with this company along with helping them meet or exceed in the DFARS expoerience.  This is a place I would definitely like to return.
Lots of opportunities to move around the company.    Good pay and especially feel a sense of proper in providing the Warfighter with the Best tools to defend the Country.

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.
Very good place to work. Great team members and project opportunities. Leadership places great value on diversity and inclusion. Project and technical opportunities abound.
Is a good company, had a great experience and met wonderful and diverse co workers. The management needs improvement to work side by side with employees and to respect them.
Lots of growing opportunities but mostly in Palmdale. Experience as an employee greatly depends on the team you hire on to. I've had a mix of managers.
I thoroughly like my work. The management team is very supportive. There are unlimited opportunities to move and grow as well as develop new skill sets.

They have strong values and a good understanding of family values . I have had the pleasure to work with some very amazing people who have helped me grow and develop a understanding of composite work and going forward in my career

Overall this was a great place to work but it's really the people you work with that make it that way. As far as management, they have gotten better and more responsive since I have started there. However I feel there are people that end up getting away with a lot because managers are afraid of low morale and people retaliating against them if they do punish those that aren't doing a lot of work.

Northrop Grumman Corporation is an American global aerospace and defense technology company. With 90,000 employees and an annual revenue in excess of $30 billion, it is one of the world's largest weapons manufacturers and military technology providers.

This company is all about numbers. I worked a contract for this company through the post office. They are only about numbers. We had not company functions outside of the company and they were always up in the air if the contract was going to be renewed with the post office. No job security and management sucks.

Great atmosphere with fellow coworkers and easy to find or ask help from others. Getting technology related materials (ie laptops) does take a while as it goes through management but otherwise there is a lot to learn and people willing to teach.
My day at work is pretty competitive. I like doing what i am doing at my job. i learned a lot of new stuffs every day. Working in a government agency actually makes me feel good.

Through everything all employees feel that we are only there to make the company money.  Most Defense companies give three weeks vacation and 10 paid holidays.  NG gives two weeks vacation and the almost week off at Christmas time is made from the holidays not given throughout the year.  When it comes to the benefit to the employee or the company it is the benefit to the company.  Year end reviews are terrible, only 1% of a department across the entire company are recognized for a raise or bonus.  Often times you get no raise and never get a bonus no matter how much you work, how much you save the company or the money and engineering you provide.  The annual ratings on management are very poor.  The company prides itself on diversity as that is the only thing it is succeeding at.
Build harnesses and feeling appreciated for the work you do.
Northrop grumman is one of the best companies you will ever work for.

It was ok, but if you are trying to take time off and u got hurt at work and had no time to use they use it against you to fire you. Contract managers may be corrupt. They are the government too much money to be there

Their internship program is good. Depending on where you work, the staff may or may not be helpful. This means they know you are an intern, but prefer working with someone with experience. Clean facility, great cafeteria, great environment.

Outstanding working environment.  Upward progression is likely if willing to relocate.  Management supports individuals goals and encourages training. Your military experience is definitely valued and highly encouraged.
Good place to work. Nice coworkers. Options for advancement and movement to other departments as well as other offices in other locations.  Great opportunities to give back to community
The rotation culture at the Baltimore campuses allow for employees to continue to learn and grow without feeling stagnant. I have never experienced this in my 20 years of working.
Good place to start career with potiential to promote and good pay benefits. However, insurance is kind of high. So consider it when you do the salary negotiation.
I started as a Systems Engineer on LITENING program and moved into IRCM programs due to my DOORS software experience. Now working as a Program Quality Engineer (PQE).

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.

Transitioned the operation I was in from defense contracting to commercial manufacturing. It was a very rewarding experience. Management could not have more accommodating. I remember the degree of effort and collaboration it took to make the venture successful. I enjoy hard work and it was a time that made me feel very much a part of the team.

The job can be a strict 9 to 5 job or more depending on how driven you are.  You can get paid overtime.  At times the performance culture can pit organizations against each other.  Management skill can vary greatly.  It seems at times that those who can present themselves the best are elevated far above those who can actually perform the work competently.
loved working there. great work environment. easy going people and worked with you to get the job done. everyone got a long grest which made working ther eenjoyable.

Here you will work on products that support the warfighter and defend our country.  Your work is a mission.  The management team here cares about that mission and it is apparent the vocation is more than about profits.
It was a great place to work I unfortunately left due to a transfer for my husband's job and I would love to go back to the company again if given the chance

Although we are working on military aircraft the management tends to rush whoever they don't want to make them fail  ! They did not respect the technician when it came to management not like the technician and would pressure to make that person fail so that technician would get fired ... it was like a buddy buddy system.
