I have enjoyed working for this company and they provided me with assets to advance my skills and abilities.
Great place to work.
Over all great company to get with. They have a lot of contracts to offer many positions and movement if you so desire.
I learned alot working for this company as far as how to work. I picked up another trade I would use the rest of my life.

Transitioned many times from TRW to Northrop Grumman. Well connected people who do critical work. Highly professional in all areas, including administration. Take care of employees and many job opportunities for growth.

I appreciated Northrop Grumman's Program Managers recognizing my need to excel: "promoted" me to other contracts where skills were challenged and met. It was exciting to work in the nation's capital and working on IMPORTANT contracts for the nation's security. Travel to other locations wasn't often, but was vital to accomplish the contract goals.
Not enough work to keep me busy, manager informed. Noted that other people had same problem.
Wonderful professional environment with many opportunities for career growth. Extensive selection of Northrop Grumman Clubs to join for many fun sports, hobbies, community service etc...

This company has been dealing with funding shortages for over a year now. The environment is not stable, the morale is awful, the employees walk on eggshells and are all afraid for their jobs. On top of that, management is just shy of incompetent 9 times out of 10 - everyone is too busy watching thier own hides to watch out for the people for they are supposed to be managing. The Oxnard office has laid off so many people it's a joke. Apply here at your own risk.
The over all work environment was very satisfying. People are friendly and very appreciative of the work you perform to keep the systems running smoothly.

Overall I enjoyed working for NGC. There isn't any job security when you are working for defense related contracts such as the Command and Control systems. The work is interesting, some of it is cutting edge.
Northrop Grumman is a good place to work, pay and benefits are good, there is a learning curve, but the opportunity is there to learn.

The atmosphere is great most of the time. At times it can be stressful, but you work on your own merit. You can stay pretty busy. Great coworkers and cutting edge technology. Most departments get along quite well.
I taught basic first aid to newly recruited Soldiers for the US Army

This is one of the worst companies I have worked for. They function as a staff agumentation company. Although you are led to believe you are a Northrup employee and they care about your well-being, often time this is not true. My experience is within the Public Health sector which is not the primary sector for NG. Many of their manager are not effective in their roles. They are offer unattached to the work being done. The management typically only interact with the client when their is a problem. NG does not manage their work by SOW. They tend to just 'hand you over the client to do as they please'. Their is not a lot of direction as to what is required on you as a NG employee. Moral is very low and there is a great deal of backstabbing. Many of their atlanta public health contract (CDC) are being recompeted. They are losing a great number of contracts based on new HHS contract requirements. NG is not honest about the status of contract and tend to wait to the last minute and layoff their employees.
I enjoyed my time at Northrop Grumman and found the employees to be intelligent, hard-working, team-oriented, professional and easy to work with.

An amazing company, understands the military and provides a great culture. I would love to work the rest of my life at the company. They will help you with obtaining your goals and leave you in a good place for retirement.
Too bad the level of business couldn't be maintained. Challenging work with a great group of colleagues.
Working for Northrop Grumman IT department was exciting each day the work flow went very well.

Northrop Grumman and the employees are completely professional in every way. Quality is stressed and built into every product. When you work for Northrop Grumman you know you work for a copmpany that has it all together.
daily jobs was transpotation unit handler to department in yard they need to builed

Company is very reputable but lately getting as bureaucratic like government. Some projects are run very well others not, depending on management. Under Obama administration everything was getting worse because of lack of funding and contracts.
This was part of the INS project. Taking good fingerprints, putting in the correct information, helped our clients reach their goal.

My experience at Northrop Grumman was outstanding. I worked started 6/1984 at the age of 24 until 4/2010. I learned everything about my profession, how to be a professional, how to work under pressure of deadlines, how to lead and how to push myself beyond what I thought I could do. I truly enjoyed my experiences working at Northrop Grumman.
Great place to work, with great benefits. This company has contracts with the CDC and for those in Health IT its the best place to be.
I liked working at Northrop Grumman a great company to work for I would still be working there if there were more government contracts to work on.
I relly enjoyed the people at NGC in the IT dept. Had to close a business down in St. louis and my position was filled. Would go back if position opens up.

As my first job out of college Northrop was a great company to start with. They have a great tuition assistance program and helped pay the full cost of my Masters degree. Also, Northrop is a great corporation to put on a resume and is general well respected in the defense community.
Excellent inspectors seeking zero defects. Great QA team members
Executive Management Culture:
I would recommend this company, Good management and communication. What you put into it, you get out, advancements is a plus. Great Training. Benefits are good also.

No work/life balance. I worked several weekends with no compensation as I was saleried. No extra pay, no days off. Turn over was high and the hours were long with no benefit.  Life events (such as heart conditions or sick pets) were frowned upon.
The facility is too small for what they are trying to do. There are not enough staff to handle the work, not enough space to operate, poor management in my department and you are over worked.
You'll get plenty of work to do and can expedite your career growth. Best to get as much experience as you can and get out. Job security is decent since there are always dumpster fires.

If you are fresh out of college or looking to move into pharma from another stem field this is a great place to learn instrumentation and more cutting edge techniques because they will have you up and running on them within a few weeks whether you like it or not.

There is no limit to what you can learn at KBI if you have the drive an time.  Tons of different assays and protocol are at your hands.  KBI prefers to promote internally for management positions even when qualifications aren't met.  This causes strain on the analysts with a break neck work flow on top of a massive work load.  Perhaps it will change in time, but more qualified managers need to be brought in to help the analysts.

KBI is a company that knows that it is bad.  It is a unique level of self awareness that keeps anyone new from gaining too much ability to change anything for the better because management knows you will eventually leave.  The ones that have been the longest have done so by maintaining a toxic work environment that leaches every bit of energy from you before they eventually discard you. On the bright side this mess of a place allows for new graduates and early career starters a great entry point into industry due to the lightning fast turnaround time.  I was lucky enough to be one of those individuals to get a chance to get a good feel of the pharmaceutical industry and now I am an even luckier individual to leave.  My biggest advice is to get in and expose yourself to all of the areas that you can so you can leverage that knowledge to get a job somewhere that cares about you as a person and understands the benefits of strong company culture and fostering professional growth.

HR policies are not good. They don’t care about employees. Employees are treated with disrespect and there is no work life balance. They keep on finding mistakes in your work and keep hammering it in every review. Such a pathetic company to work for.
Decent company culture. Somewhat fast paced. Technology is a bit antiquated, and processes could use some updating. Great place to get your feet wet in the BioPharma industry.
I worked the night shift. My crew was filled with guys who had animosity towards other coworkers. Several poisonous personalities. Lots of people left after I left to work elsewhere.

If you want to get your foot in the door in the pharmaceutical industry, apply here. If you just want a paycheck...do the same. However, if you plan to leave the company, disregard everything that you learned. If you care and have a great work ethic, you will be frustrated on a daily basis due to lack of proper management in most areas. You will also be frustrated by lack of positivity as you will hear a bunch of complaints. No true Quality professionals should apply here unless you just need to pass the time and collect a check. It could be a much better place if management were changed.
The workers there like to invade your privacy.  They like to steal.  They do not get punished for it.  Depends on the person caught stealing HR will not help.

This has to be the worst management team I have ever been around. Literally! The manager and supervisor are never on the work floor or doing anything. They play favorites some are high key prejudice and advancement is nearly impossible. The team gets deviations everyday. If I was anyone applying for a job i would stay far away from this Place. I would give 0 stars if I could.

They hire you as who you are and mold you to become who they want with adequate training. Everyone is trying to help you integrate into the team. You can learn more stuff especially if you're new in the bioparma field. Just come in with the right mentality and good work ethics and you're all set.
Work Life Balance isn't a HIGH value at the Company.
There is a very toxic work environment in which negativity is pervasive.  Climbing the ladder is slow and degree-dependent.  Overtime is expected but not rewarded.
Very busy with daily tasks but pay and opportunity for better remote structure is highly needed.

If you would like to retain any self worth or value when you head home for the day, don't work here. After being laid off, this was one of the only places willing to hire me quickly. After a few months of working here, I soon realized why; the quality of work and the company itself is so poor, nearly everyone begins to find a new job within about a year of working here. It would be very rare to see a scientist that has more than a few years of experience that has found the will and determination to brave the exhaustive and oppressive work environment long enough to be promoted. The lack of experience in management and rampant disorganization permeating the entire company infuriates the strongest of souls and slowly eats away at any prospects you would have to develop a career at KBI.

As a CRO, there is always incoming work. However, as the company has grown, there is less value on employees as individual assets. Instead, my department became heavily driven by revenue only, leading to overworked and undervalued employees.  It can also be difficult to move up in title/salary depending on which group/department you are a member of.  Some departments-- finance, manufacturing, program management-- seemed to have many more promotions than Analytical and formulation departments.  I was also told that I could not receive a promotion until I headed a method development study-- the only problem is my small group did not do such activities and were never given such contracts/studies to perform, making me feel stagnant in the position I was currently in.
Great Company to work for in RTP.  Growing fast and hiring.  Strong company in there sector.  Would encourage people to work there.  Local company gone big.
Overall, compensation and benefits are fair. Work environment is pleasant.  Advancement opportunities are limited.  They offer alot of extracurricular team building opportunities.
If you have to work here, and you are halfway intelligent, dedicate your off-time to finding a new job. You will not do any science here. It’s more like being a gerbil on a wheel.

No work/life balance. I worked several weekends with no compensation as I was saleried. No extra pay, no days off. Turn over was high and the hours were long with no benefit.  Life events (such as heart conditions or sick pets) were frowned upon.

Under valuing, and under utilization of most employees. Difficult and extremely inefficient work space that never improved! Extreme disconnection. No effort by upper management to create teamwork or company atmosphere.  Rarely on-site.Lots of talent under the roof that was never brought together.

•	Supporting the Document Control group which includes Lead Senior Document Control Specialists, Senior Document Control Specialists, Document Control Specialists, and Document Control Coordinators in the implementation of tasks

Lies lies lies! Want to be treated like a space filler.... that’s about all you will get from this company! All promises that were given at the interview were lies! HR is against you! No management in place!

A roller coaster of challenges, changes, customer demands in a supportive environment where management with their eclectic sense of humor but driven attitude achieves miracles on an ever changing timeline.
KBI is a sinking ship, the HR is a total mess.
Very stressful work environment.  You may not ever get an opportunity to get a raise.  People are placed in positions that are not qualified.  What's promised is never given.

Its is a job. There is nothing else that I can say about working for this company. Its more about who your friends are that the quality of your work.  Being on the secret gossip email chain is the key to sucess.
Poorly managed facility which will be out of business soon.  Employees have no experience, training, or professionalism.  No organization or plans for the facility.
Scan, image, organize and maintain documents,adhering to the company's document lifecycle procedures, and archive inactive records in accordance with the records retention schedule.
A positive environment provides lots of opportunities to learn. Some times there are free food like salad, sandwiches, pizza, and candies.
This company is going through serious transition.  Management is out of touch with employees. It's great for a new college grad or Seasoned Vet looking for a paycheck.

There are many great employees at KBI. However management and communication are ineffective and need to be improved.  Advancement really depends upon which department you work in and who you work for.
I was temporary contractor helping them do IT work for a week so I can't speak too much about what it is like there. But from what I saw and experienced, it was a friendly and nice place to work.

An incredibly disorganized company....seems like there is no one in charge.  Management only cares about profit and not following any proper procedure.  Company is devoted to those in their 20s and older, experienced, workers are denigrated.

Its a growing company with a lot of opportunity .The managers lack direction.I learned a lot in the field starting off but it started to become stagnant after a while.The workplace is inconsistent because its newer and the foundation its shaky.
This is a growing company and there are lots of opportunities to improve efficiency, as many processes were not scalable when implemented Management is decent. Compensation is fair.
Good start up company when I worked there.  Business plan has changes significantly since I left the company in 2007. Most of the original management is still there.
There is definitely job security at KBI for anyone who can do the work.  The culture is very friendly, however there are the general challenges of working for any CRO

I miss it.   Was a  good place to work   Staff was friendly.     The hotel was absolutely great location   beautiful rooms  And. Great view.     -  pay was fair.   Restaurant was awesome.       Was a great place to work
I have been with the company for 2 years and I have nothing but good things to say. They value internal growth and the well being of their employees.
The bar for workplace ethics and respect  is set high.
Choose to be happy. The company will treat you well. Pros and cons of working everywhere. Nice people mostly helpful. I’m a happy person and don’t let people get me down. I enjoyed working there.

I was the lead barista for a Sage property in Nashville. The job was easy. However, for my experience I Brough to the company I feel I should have been more valued as an employee. Management was easy to work with and corporate level employees were respectful and professional. I would work for Sage again, but not for the pay I was offered.

I miss working at the Logan I have learned so much from this hotel and liked the whole team that I worked with as always was on time loved going to work and getting my job done was my passion at the Logan

You learn something new every day! ..From food preparation to time tempertures to properly labeling food items complete with date & time! You get to schitch station as you go about your day depending on whats need be done! You can move around freely and you can either prep cook help out in the walk in freezer diswasher cafeteria sweep mop help keep place looking nice clean beautyfull! It was a pleasure to recieve the executive chef in a sanitized well organized kitchen! Id loved this place!

The hotel I work for is fun and inclusive. Our GM is very hands on and teaches. I became a manager with Sage at the start of Covid. Company and management give you the tools you need to succeed. I've been with the company for 8 months and it has been the best career move for me. Thank you Sage for giving me the chance to get hands on training and allowing me to part of the team

My interview was great with the chief of engineering  but I sensed some tension from the assistant GM she was very cold and short. My first month working there I realized it was the most ghetto unprofessional toxic place ever! People were sleeping with one another drinking and smoking every department acted like children gossiping about this gossiping about that! I was appalled and disgusted. The hotel itself was horrible condition inside and out quite surprised the amount they charged for guest to stay at such a place. About 2 months later they switched management company’s but still same BS. I expected so much more. Shockingly never really had problems with the guest more so just co workers
I credit my time working at several Sage properties to where I am in my career now.

Poor organizational leadership and corporate direction, most are overly concerned with saving money at the expense of old and low-end  technology, problematic applications, and inadequate staffing levels, which include low or non-existent bonuses. And when occupancy rates and hotel traffic dropped, the layoffs immediately started, not even providing the normal industry standard 2 weeks notice/severance. Extremely poor character organization to separate loyal employees in such a manner.

It was good place to work. I went there with no knowledge in new field of Hospitality but I was given the chance to learn. Management was good; Management willing to offer education to prepare me for work. Work culture was welcoming to all. The hardest part of work was dealing with anger and unsatisfied customers. And the enjoyable part of the job was meeting people of different background every single day.
Everyone at Sage cares about people, they want to help everyone they can and make the process easy and positive.
Great place to work, loved everything about the place and company. I’m very happy with Sage Hospitality. I would definitely recommend this place of work to anyone.

Moved from Colorado to georgia and moved up to sous chef. Was good until they hired new team members at the start of the pandemic. I was furloughed for two months then told I no longer had a job.. Basically no job security.
Great cultural environment to work in  if you enjoy meeting and experiencing working with people from all over the world. Developing organization for employees of all ages.
The benefits working under sage hospitality is fantastic. Not only is the pay great, the health insurance and othe benefits working with them are great.
The job was ok and easy. Lot of work but the team is great. I worked there for a little over a year and left to get more pay. If you like hotel work this is a good place to start.

Unfortunately my experience ended rather abruptly due to the Covid 19 pandemic.  I had some health issues that inhibited my ability to work to the level of effectiveness for my position.  At the six month period I was let go during the company furlough and was told I would not be re hired.  This is unfortunate and I will be seeking help from H.R. to see if I can return in the future.
Great work environment, great team, great benefits. Sage wants to see you grow within the company and they are willing to give you the tools needed to progress in your career.
Chaos, it was a dumpster fire with no accountability.

I miss it.   Was a  good place to work   Staff was friendly.     The hotel was absolutely great location   beautiful rooms  And. Great view.     -  pay was fair.   Restaurant was awesome.       Was a great place to work
I love the team I work with and everyone else in the hotel is great to work with, so it makes the job easier, but getting promoted or any bonus takes awhile.
It’s a great place to work in associated are always straightforward trying and do in there best to accomplish there job to keep our guest happy and satisfied
It's a good place to work. I really miss it there. The people or great And very helpful. I just love the working there. Has great review. Company is the best.
I enjoyed working for Marriott. The workplace was a positive one. Management was supportive. Manpower was always a problem since most hotel jobs vary by season.
It appears that Sage has lost their way.
leadership is weak , no one cares including the managers . Not a positive work environment . Everyone hates their job .
Due to new company direction, the position I held is being eliminated with no opening to retain me at my present salary. Sage it a progressive company.
If I could I would work there again

I've worked for various hospitality companies, and I can say BY FAR that Sage has been amazing!  I feel supported on a property level as well as from our Corporate Office.  Our property is able to make individual decisions that benefit our staff, culture and of course our clients as well.  In over 3.5 years here, I have been through many changes at this hotel, and all have been executed collaboratively.  My favorite part of the culture here is how many people explore opportunities in different departments than they were originally hired for - lots of room to grow and find what makes you successful!

My days weren't horrible. Some days were better than others. I enjoyed a lot of my co-workers. The head management is very professional and generous. The lower management on the other hand could have at the time used a few adjustments. But then again nobody is perfect. The hardest part of the job was keeping busy during slower seasons. The most enjoyable part was being able to meet a bunch of new people from around the world.

Senior management doesn't care how many hours middle management works and will take little to no action to help or assist in daily operations. "Leadership meetings", daily meetings and unrealistic demands for deadlines drown you while daily operations compete to do the same while your GM shops online, looks for houses and goes out to eat for 2 hour lunches. Lack of supervision from corporate over senior

Be aware to work for sage Means no advancement for labor workers. No employee meals even though there are two eateries on location. Pay is really low for downtown. You will need two jobs or a roommate to make it by. No promotions have been offered and its been a year! Everyone is super relaxed and cool to work with. The job is great But the Pay is horrible

Wages were lower than expected for the amount of work asked of you at times and raises from annual reviews were low as well. High turnover rate and Sage doesn't like to pay employees overtime unless your department was short staffed. Everyone was friendly and you tend to know everyone in other departments, but there was lack of communication from higher ups.
Sage is a solid company. Some areas they could improve upon are compensation, interdepartmental communication and collaboration.

"Perception is everything" is a phrase that was taught over and over, and it is resemblant of the interview process. When I interviewed I was very excited to be a part of a high class establishment. When I began working, I would be reprimanded for doing things incorrectly though I had not been trained on proper procedures. A typical day at work involves figuring it out yourself with flippant or no training. The hardest part of the job was no support and easily becoming a scapegoat for someone who had minimal interaction with their department and has no respect from their department.

Company motto praises integrity but Sage does not practice what they preach. Upper management lacks hotel knowledge & diversity and I am amazed at how they stay in business.  Employees are not treated fairly, and are overworked. Company has no concept of employees work load and they are expected to perform  multiple job duties in short periods of time.  Try to complain and you risk termination.They do not like to pay overtime. Work here at your own risk.

Boy i missing working with sage. A great company reliable. You always had a team to support you. Only downfall was the pay for the work you do. If the can match other offers from competitive company would be the perfect job!!!

This was an okay employer however they lack in management. We had a manager that knew the store had worked there for 2 years and they put another manager above them because of race yes I said race. The store crumbled & Glad I'm gone will never waste my time with anything like this again.
Team oriented and positive work environment. Great hospitality management company . I am greatfu working with sage hospitality. Our manager are very friendly and helpful with our needs
A typical day at work can be both hard and enjoyable, the people there are almost like family. We talk ,we laugh, we help each other,If there is a problem that we can't handle supervisor will step in

I miss it.   Was a  good place to work   Staff was friendly.     The hotel was absolutely great location   beautiful rooms  And. Great view.     -  pay was fair.   Restaurant was awesome.       Was a great place to work

First of all the lobby was not at proper temperature. This place lacked passion, customer service, team work, integrity, security. Too laid back and not effective. Truly embarrassing to work at. Felt ashamed. My suggestion did not matter.
Great company to work for if you are in Denver area.  I was in the take over team where we worked long hours and not enough support.  They only give less than 3% increase in your yearly review.

Specifically, the Napa Marriott is run by very crude managers, neither care about their employees. The assistant manager often just overworked because she herself is afraid of the office manager: who lashes out at employees constantly and humiliates them both in private and in front of guests. I was hired as a part-time Front Desk and worked more than 40 hrs/week, each shift at least 9hrs.

Hotel was eventually sold, but I got out before that happened. Was promised movement on a regular but never happened. I knew more than my manager. But the location was amazing, the MGT was amazing, Corp was great. The job itself was just low wages throughout the industry.
Sage has offered me the opportunity to grow personally and professionally. We have a very collaborative environment and the company fosters a very positive working environment.

The general manager is a inept idiot.  He swares he knows all even though he was fired from another hotel in Atlanta and didnt even go to Gm training cant run front desk cause he say he dont know how cant even change a room from dirty to vacant ready in the system but hes a GM REALLYLOL.   If you do be mindful he will micromanage you.  Make passes at you. Lie on you and tell lies to cooperate to get his butt out of hot water..HR is a joke cooperate doesnt even investigate what goes on with employees but will run lower management out the building.  No monthly dinners no talking no thank you but dont be late they will cut your head off...trust me dont work there. ..that place is a joke

Beautiful Hotel, Just low pay and it can be very stressful at times like all hotels in the world.  But sometimes it can be rewarding, especially when your working with great Co-workers that go on-and beyond.  The pay needs to be higher, health benefits need to be revamped.
I recommend everyone to stay this hotel because you will get a good service. I worked here as a maintenance engineer and I recommend a person who I know a technician one to join it.

Working at Sage was satisifing and yet challenging in all aspects.  The Executive Management at Sage is one of the best that I hav experienced.  It is a place where they know who you are as an employee. I would highly recommend Sage as an emnployee.

Management was awful. Had four GMs in my year of being at the location. Assistant manager only cared for themselves and lacked communication. Confrontation was something she did not like especially when guests were yelling and screaming at her staff. She was about retaliation and was very into your personal business than motivating her staff.

Management treats you as if you are incompetent. 30 minutes to clean a room, regardless of its condition. A lot of talking down to housekeeping. Management treated me as if I was an unintelligible foreigner.
Great work environment and company culture.  There are many opportunities for advancement, especially in Denver where Sage manages multiple hotel properties.
Sage cares about their employees and believes in promotion from within. The benefits are very slim which is hard when you have such great hotel discounts. Overall a good culture and staff.
Room for growth, it was ok, need more productive Management. Pay employee a better wage for the work that is require of them. Take care of your employees and your employees will take care of you.

Sage Hospitality has a great culture, focussed on the hotel operations and the communities they operate in.  Associates are an important part of their mission and their operations are quality driven.  Work life balance could be better for the executive team.
Great company to work for! Offering several opportunities with the expansion of their hotels. Wonderful leaders to work for and a great culture and people are very appreciative.

A typical day at work includes preparing the dish pit, cleaning all pots and pans, communicating with chef about any issues. I learned how to prep food items, how to be a good communicator. The management was not bad, worked around your schedule and allowed time off. The hardest part of the job could be pressure under a fast pace. The most enjoyable part was the people.
Sage Hospitality is a great place to work with the right attitude. They have a very good benefits program. I've been with Sage for 1 year . I look forward to what's to come
Sage is an upscale, progressive and forward thinking company, that is focused on the community, associates, and partnerships with owners.  Enjoyed my time there!
Can support yourself with wages, but don't expect to ever make any decent money or even earn new tasks to grow and develop within company, merely experience to out on your resume.

I miss it.   Was a  good place to work   Staff was friendly.     The hotel was absolutely great location   beautiful rooms  And. Great view.     -  pay was fair.   Restaurant was awesome.       Was a great place to work
Great place to work, learning experience, quick pace, employees are helpful and love the environment. Managers are helpful. But sometimes over worked.

a typical day at the logan is like any other restaurant/hotel collab, you serve breakfast, brunch, lunch and dinner. There are very busy days and some slower days, The vibe of the day is generally based on which sous chef is working that day

Turnover is very high.  No set schedule if your working on certain positions.  Some managers are great, other higher ranking managers of the hotel are so inexperienced for their roles.  No hotel director during the weekends which seems pretty odd.  Most workers do pretty much whatever they want.  Too many slackers, and of course you have other good hard working people there too.
they had bad stuff and they had lot bugs all over the kickets any other stuff there word going on the hotle and they have not been clean the walls angthing was going on there

An awesome place to work with great a great culture. Structured and able to transfer throughout the company of available. There is a great open door policy. A typical day at work is filled with empowerment and team work
Sage has a great culture! In the couple years that I have been with Sage they have grown in their real estate division. It has been a joy watching them grow and being a part of it.
Worst company to work for. A pregnant employee was told that she would not be getting paid while out as having a baby was not a life changing event...

Task Force Management with Sage was fun met famous people and Management always welcome you to the team and team building everyone was proffesional.I would definitely love to work for this company in Portland Oregon.

The 5 star rating in the "Job Work/Life Balance" category is because I didn't need it in my job due to the fact I worked overnight.  The 1 star rating in all the other categories is GENEROUS because the company really deserves NEGATIVE stars!

I was properly trained by one of the best cleaners aboard. i had a rough time getting to and from when it came me and my family relocating. I am grateful I added some housekeeping experience with Sage Hospitality.
No two days are alike.  Opportunity to travel.  Development of talent is a focus. More technology is needed to keep pace with growing business environment.

This is my first time working in hospitality, but the turn over is awful and for the most part people do whatever they want to on the clock. The hard workers are few and far between and accountability leaves much room for improvement.
Management was often good, but in the wrong company. Sage does not pay well to their associates and the hotel was run down. Just not a lot of common sense to go around in upper management.
Great company with strong values in Corporate Citizenship.  Wonderful leadership.  Forward thinking culture with emphasis on People resources and employee development.
Sage Hospitality Provided a Friendly and Productive work environment. The whole staff worked together and made it a pleasure to work there. My favorite part of the job was the Customers...
Sage is good overall.  Certain business units are not as good as the company.  This experience was good and exposed me to a lot of different things, it ran its course and I had to move on.

I love my job here at Sage Hospitality! I feel valued as an employee and see a lot of growth potential for myself and for my team. The perks are great and the leadership is transparent. They do a great job of highlighting promotions and celebrating wins throughout the organization, even though there's thousands of employees across the country. For example, there's an update that goes out every week to celebrate promotions, community service projects people participated in, even when celebrating when employees welcome a new baby to the family-- we all get to celebrate each others wins and happy moments, even if I don't work side by side with each other.
I have been with Sage for number of years, in the last I have been an interim for the company and I enjoyed the traveling and opportunity to visit, learn and apply my experience.
I would say other than the rate of pay wasnt enough, but I wish I could go back if it wasnt downtown. Also with my rate of pay, I couldnt afford to work there.

The answer was always "You need to cover the shift."  "We work a minimum of 10 hours every day no matter what."  During the interview process, same management boasted about the quality of work/life balance.  As a department manager, I understand the needs to cover shifts but other management could also lend a hand.  Instead they take multiple vacations and "work from home" which doesn't make sense for a hotel manager. I constantly work over 60+ hours a week with many back to back shifts.  Days off are few and far between.

I miss it.   Was a  good place to work   Staff was friendly.     The hotel was absolutely great location   beautiful rooms  And. Great view.     -  pay was fair.   Restaurant was awesome.       Was a great place to work
Typical day at work is dealing with guest, must be sociable
Management do not hold leaders accountable and expect others to pick up the pieces.  With known issues that go unaddressed, while simple brand procedures are not followed.
I enjoyed the Managment. The pace is nice. The only thing I did not like was no holiday pay and you have to work holidays. The pay was really good and so was the heath benefits
This job like any job has their issues but overall the company is a good company. There are nice benefits and the incentives are good as well. I would recommend this job to anyone.

Starts out well.  Promise the world and micromanage the heck out of you. Typical day includes being micromanaged by the hotel GM. Learned that if they want you gone they will find a way. Restaurant GM is high functioning and fair. Hotel GM is a micromanaging piece of work with low morals. Sage corporate seems fair, but needs to rein this property in. Hardest pat of the job is the hotel GM. Some of the mid management and employees are great people that deserve so much better. Clique of restaurant morning staff with no morals whatsoever.  Knowing what I know now I can honestly say, if you aren't desperate for work, don't bother. You'll regret it!

Tons of favoritism, nobody stands up for what's right, and you barely getting hours to make a decent living. Cliques in every department, tons of gossip, and not many happy employers. They'll go above and beyond for guests, but not for the employees who contribute to daily operations and guest experiences. Management sucks BIG TIME!

I worked here for almost a year. No supervisors in the beginning  management barely around popped in a few times barely available very dismissive and non nonchalant when it comes to issues. Not welcoming at all. When they finally hired a supervisor they hired someone who had no idea what they were doing which hindered you rather than helped you! You're basically on a sinking ship..  Communication is non existent management never helped directly with any guest issues, everything had to be handled by ourselves and when it went wrong everything fell on you. So much stress for no reason but the workers here were wonderful they were the reason I stayed for as long as I did.Absolutely no room for advancement from my short time here they will look outside before they promote internally especially at the front desk. I've seen it happen multiple times. The only thing I miss about this place is the people I worked with. If you do chose to apply here make it a stepping stone or a part time job. This place it wasn't horrible the pay was nice but I'm happy I left.

Renaissance Hotel in downtown Pittsburgh. Guests were always fantastic; however the managers were all good friends and literally acted like a clique of high school girls. Even when going above and beyond expectations, they would nit pick just to start their own drama. Awful. Not to mention employees regularly got sick eating the food that was provided as well as a few guests in the restaurant on property.

I would review the company ,  sage hospitality as very stressful, no work life balance, very one sided, a place where gossip rules the day. a place where your told your appreciated, but not shown the same.

When I first started there, I was a server.  When our then supervisor left, I was quickly promoted to the position.  I am still currently in the position.  There is a lot of teamwork among departments and I have learned scheduling and banquet serving  as a result of working there.  My favorite part of any job I have had is meeting new people and as this is a hotel environment, I have been lucky to meet people from all over the world.
•	Possessed an expert level knowledge of property management system (PMS), Microsoft programs, and various other front office operational equipment.
●	Total sales, marketing communications, catering sales, event management, revenue management and public relations for $30 million business.
SRG is a brand to be reckoned with.  Great concept restaurants, growth potential.  Decent benefits. The CEO's care about the brand they've created and genuinely care about their employees.
I just love the people that work that it was so nice and wonderful I take pride in my work at Sage overall I love the job it was some great co-workers and everything that I love
The managers would watch as we killed ourselves while being short staffed. Promotions were not given and there was little recognition for good work.
Fast pace and always keeping a smile on your face. ready for all challenges and provide solutions . never to say no and be creative and how to say yes.

My typical day at work was correcting everyone else's DAILY mistakes.  A lot of the time these were the same "mistakes" being made over & over again; in reality, it was just laziness & an "I don't care" attitude--all by people who claim to have been in the Hospitality business for years.
Sell sell sell, take inquires respond to emails phone calls. Much energy is needed to do this job, 50%inside 50% outside duties.

My company was a union owned and everytime you go to management the excuse was well that's up to the union. Somebody's always late union, ect. So what does and can management actually do ? 0 No room for advancement.  Pay was decent and benefits were the only thing I miss and my colleges.
Sage Hospitality is a good company to work for:

I miss it.   Was a  good place to work   Staff was friendly.     The hotel was absolutely great location   beautiful rooms  And. Great view.     -  pay was fair.   Restaurant was awesome.       Was a great place to work

Good Company to work for in most departments. Co workers and management need to work better together in some departments and other departments work very well together. The hardest part of the job was the hours and working Holidays and some weekends. The enjoyable part of the job was working with the managers and customers to make sure things got completed.
A typical day at work involves attending to multiple guest needs. Day to day operations vary. Signing off on payroll and maintaining multiple budgets within the front office departments.

I do all the ordering for the front desk/gift shop and the club lounge. I also do the forecast for the club lounge. I enjoy working with the guest helping them plan their stay and making their visit memorable.

Good Denver based company in hospitality. I worked in a three person accounting department and had several challenges each day. The Director of Finance was always available for teaching new procedures and brain storm new ideas.
Expectation is high of corporate employees to work on weekends and holidays (consistent with the hospitality industry in general).

If you are looking into this company for maid services or food services I would not suggest this company. Their pay rate is horrible compared to the hours you will have to work, after working there for several months they switched me from full-time to part time with the excuse of "I was not able to work enough hours" (because of medical reasons) so I was unable to get paid vacation time or paid holidays even-though I had acquired a lot of time for both of those before being transferred. They switch management quite frequently with hardly any warning, and they have a high turnover rate. In my 11 months working here over 10 people quit and 3-5 people were fired for unreasonable means.

They talk a good game but this company sucks! They’re always hiring because nobody wants to work there. They treat all there employees like garbage and they will lay you off in a second with little or no warning
Company takes care of their employees in other different states. Do not recommend anyone to work for Sage in Texas.
Sage offers opportunities to work at many different locations nationwide, while offering 401(k) and benefits to employees. They offer training, knowledge and room for advancement within the company.
Business model is to be deliberately understaffed. The GM & Director of Operations will want 6/12's of hands on task related work if the position is salary. They will use you and lose you.
Monitoring swimming guests, perform measures for emergencies, assist other lifeguards

Lack of Management. Little to no communication, especially between departments.  High turnover from entry level to upper management. Low pay considering the amount of responsibilities. Sage runs the operation lean.

A typical day at work is get your cart ready stocked with linen and soap, shampoos, conditioners, etc.. in a timely manner. when cleaning the rooms all must change sheets on bed and out in fresh clean towels in bathroom. dusting all furniture, and vacuuming all rooms everyday. Usually have about 10-20 rooms a day depending on business. I have learned a lot my time here, how to clean properly and making sure there is no hair in bathrooms. I've learned that most guest that come back repeatedly, how they like their rooms cleaned and what kind of extras the will need. You can learn a lot just by how the person is and how long they plan to stay! The management is awesome, they are always there if I need help or if I can't help the customer myself then they are always their for back up. The hardest part is that its physically hard because there's a lot of moving, bending, lifting etc.. but mentally its easy remembering what goes in the rooms everyday. The enjoyable part of the job is the wonderful people you work with. I love everyone of my co workers and we truly are the meaning behind team work.
hard to sell sprint when sprint sucks, management installed microphones to listen in on employee conversation, fired people for no apparent reason other than personal vendetta

Sage is very personal with their employees. You will learn a lot and the people they have have in place can certainly lead and answer the questions. Only problem is that they are based out of Denver. So unless you live there, options for promotion are limited.

Fourteen years of experience in the hospitality industry with emphasis in management, including the responsibilities of general daily operations, strategic planning, site resources, financial planning and analysis, marketing and sales initiatives, internal auditing, and franchise site selection and evaluation.

Sage is a new company in the Indianapolis area (midwest region) and it took over two hotels in the airport area. Basically anyone is employed here (experience or not). Managers don't care about you, and tend to involve your personal life into work. Managers didn't let you know what benefits you had, what the values of Sage were, so I basically had no knowledge of the company I was working for. Sage might be good in the Colorado area, but in the Indy area, they are horrible and don't know what they are doing. HORRIBLE company to work for.

Horribly understaffed with a high turnover. They know very well they expect too much from their administrative on up associates with insufficient pay. I was hired as an HR Coordinator with the responsibilities of a Director, but with the pay of a Clerk. The GM very well knew I was non-exempt, however she'd still slam me with emails and requests she expected me to get done while off the clock as if I were exempt salaried. GM of the property was two faced and will suck up to corporate in order to save herself from the shady things she does. When voicing my concerns to corporate, they didn't take me seriously therefore there was no change. This job caused me a great deal of mental stress that led to nights of no sleep. Even associates would mention out of concern I looked tired and beat down. I had no choice but to leave right before I had a mental breakdown from everything being piled on me without enough resources.  Do NOT work for Sage.

They are an awesome company who truly care a about the work/life balance of their associates. They also care about the associates overall well being. Do not miss the opportunity to work for this amazing company!
Excellent profitable company with above average compensation, just understaffed with large workloads.

I miss it.   Was a  good place to work   Staff was friendly.     The hotel was absolutely great location   beautiful rooms  And. Great view.     -  pay was fair.   Restaurant was awesome.       Was a great place to work
In San Antonio , the Eilan Hotel is managed like the local Dairy Queen . Management is Horrific and it all starts with the GM and in this property , he has no Clue. So many people have left since Jan
Great company to work for, great people and wonderful benefits.
Enjoyed having own office and only having to worry about answering the telephone
Growth potential and a culture that is committed to being the best of the best. Very driven to the satisfaction of associates guests and ownership groups.

Staff get along and the work environment is friendly overall.  Ownership and upper management sometimes make decisions that make you scratch your head, but overall if you are a hard worker, it's a great place to be employed.

They talk a good game but this company sucks! They’re always hiring because nobody wants to work there. They treat all there employees like garbage and they will lay you off in second if they have too.
If you'll notice, the only good reviews are about sage in CO, nothing local here in OH.
The management company grows as it brings in more hotel. It advances its technology to meet the needs of the business.
* A typical work day was always positive and up beat.  They made you look forward to coming to work each day.
Sage was a good place to work at from the start. I just wish they would have thought about selling off properties before hiring me. Very unfair!!

My position was eliminated when Sage took over my hotel, and I was given the choice to take another management position, or not have a job. Little did I know that I would be forced to do this new job, as well as my previous one, while my title was given to another manager.
Been in this bsiness for over thirty years. Can't ever seem to get a response when applying for one of their positions.

I worked there for only 18 hours because the job I was doing was not the right job for me, but getting paid was HARD!!! They started working me before they had even officially hired me (in the new hiring system, so that I could get paid). I started working on the Friday they got paid, so I had to wait 2 weeks to get paid, which was fine, BUT it took them 5 days AFTER I was supposed to get paid before I finally got my check, because they hadn't officially hired me in the system until THE DAY BEFORE the day I was supposed to get paid!!! I went in on pay day, and from then until I finally got my check they kept telling me "It will be here tomorrow", so I would call the next day and the next day and so on, and they kept telling me this... I will never work with that company again, and I don't advise it to anyone else!!
They work hard to support their hotels. They have many outlets to get the information  to you. Great Support.

A typical day at work consists of diiferent day to day duties that help run the hotel. Everyday is different, some slower than others. I've learned a lot working for Sage Hospiatlity LLC but I mostly learned what type of upper managment traits I want to take from my managers. I would say learning to communicate with my managers has been a hardship for me but has also taught me how to see other perpectives. The most enjoyble part of my job is the people I met. They are only in my life for a brief period of time but the impression left is so big. Not only do I make a difference for them but at times they make a difference in mine as well.

I worked for Sage Hospitality for over six years. They gave me the opportunity to learn any area of hospitality I showed interest in. The General Manager and the rest of the Executive team all supported me in my professional growth and allowed me to go from Front Desk to Front Desk Supervisor to HR Coordinator and Payroll support. I was able to continue my career in HR because of the experience I got while working at a Sage property. Sage is the best employer I have ever had and not because of the career opportunity alone. I had real connections with the people I worked with. I felt like I was with my second family when I was at work and that made me want to get up in the morning. The hospitality industry as a whole is not the highest paying industry, but Sage maintains a competitive benefits plan and wage structure. I have never believed in a companies culture as much as I believe in theirs. This is a wonderful place to work.
Great Company to work for. They are willing to train if your willing to learn. The company directors are always asking for input and allow the local Management make decisions.

Sage has 8 core values that incompass the company. The last of the 8 is to give back to the community. I believe that they are one of the best companies to work for if you believe in giving back, it is a great company.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
Overall this was a good job for students looking to get started in the food service industry. There were many opportunities for advancement and good management.
I felt so supported in this office as an undergrad student! Highly recommend this job to any students that are looking to gain valuable skills and want to make some extra money during college.

I Edited together a video piece for one of their live streams, I received the footage and had a 5 camera shoot cut together in about 3 days. They live streamed it over youtube with a lecture beforehand. This was a really rewarding and collaborative experience. The piece was great and a lot of fun to work on.
I really enjoyed the crew I worked with on 3rd shift but the heavily progressive campus politics began to effect day-to-day operations in security duties.
There are a lot of moving pieces, deadlines, emails, trainings etc.. fast paced environment. Lots of resources for trainings. Numerous step by step guides on proceedures.

Managing day to day operations. Learned about Medical Education and the different pathways offered.  The hardest part of the job is the location.  If you do not live near the campus, the commute is a tough thing to get used too.
Follow the daily attitude and guidelines were once you learned them.  Following whatever mgr and lead desired was rule, spoke for the for whole office

Poor management at best. The benefits and salary  not very good compared to other facilities. The staff where I worked we're not very friendly and seem to be " dug in" the community and are not very good with diversity.
Great staff.

Working in EHS, there was a clear mission and purpose to my job. I learned so much over the 8 years there anc developed strong working relationships. For the most part there was great collaboration and working together as a team. Benefits and time off were most generous. I always learned something new. Being off site from main EHS division had its own set of challenges.

U.C.C.S. is a terrible place to work if you are not a teacher or administration. No raises, substandard products, and maximum results are expected with minimum help. Employees are driven to the point of burnout, with little to no compensation. I could go on and on. The reputation this university has in this community is undeserved, considering the way they treat the blue collar workers. They should be ashamed of themselves. I’m sorry I wasted 14 years of my life, giving my best to this unfair and hypocritical institution.

No support from management! I’m a nurse practitioner that worked directly with a physician. There was no support from management, so if you do not have a good relationship with your physician or do not agree with the way that they treat patients, then you are left with zero options!
As a grad student you're expected to work a lot of hours, so you really must enjoy what you're doing. You'll get to know some of the brightest people in your field.
I worked in a department part of the facilities management. A lot of experienced people that you can learn from.  I worked 4 days 10 hr shifts. I couldn't work for long enough and I wish I could.

Do have great retirement options and benefits. However are very political and in my opinion not very friendly. Are very goal oriented regardless of other circumstances. Just want to toot their own horn about doing bigger and supposedly more important stuff than actually caring what they are doing. Very little oversight of PI's

If you're a college student looking to make some money over the summer then I would highly recommend working as an RA or Night RA. The hours are very customizable, although the easier hours such as the afternoon and early evening are first come first serve.

Great place to work for. The benefits are very good, more so than the medical. The management and the chancellor  have kept every one up to date and I have never felt like I was out of the loop throughout this pandemic situation.

A great place to work especially with a school schedule, they work around it very well. You're treated with respect. There is trust so that there is not someone breathing over your shoulder constantly.

Not a good place to work for people who are older.  To much ageism by the management who will always prefer training, advancement, and special projects to those below 50 years of age.  Management was very consistently biased.

The University has incredible physicians, nurses and team members, however they lack leadership and management skills. The managers and people in leadership are among the worst I have experienced.  Overall, it is incredibly difficult to succeed or advance your career.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.

Management is amazing. As a student employee, management understands that school comes first. They are more than willing to work around our school schedules and any other work schedule their employees may have. They understand that their employees have a life outside of work!
very fair management and compensation. The energy of the university is very contagious which makes for a very fun workplace environment. problem is there is too much red tape
I received recordings of focus group studies that the university had conducted.  I would transcribe, edit and send back the files when I was completed with them. The people are very supportive.
I was only a contract worker, therefore I am not comfortable giving a review about this organization other than to say that I am a proud graduate of this school! Go Mountain Lions!

It is a very laid back work environment. I would show up and just text someone on the team what they wanted me to do and I would do it. I was taught the skill required of me if I did not know how to do it originally. It is run by the government so the bureaucracy makes some things incredibly slow and annoying. The productivity of the workers was mediocre. I liked the guys I worked with and appreciate the time I had to work there.
Adjunct instructor for 15 years - a great place to work! GREAT students - best ever! Great leadership; trusting leadership; innovative. As I said, I've worked there for 15 years!

Educational.  Empowering.  Door-opening.  Community-driven.  There are many things that come to mind when talking about the benefits of the University of Colorado at Boulder.  5 stars.  Absolutely incredible.
I was promoted to this position and it was a great next step in my career in Higher Education. I learned new skills and was able to connect with more departments to complete tasks and projects.

Working at CU boulder gave me a chance to hone and improve my kitchen management skills. There I was able to develop, manage and execute a breakfast menu for 150 athletes. Create and manage the inventory system for the entire kitchen. Manage 15 college employees during the lunch service to provide food for over 300 athletes.

While classroom time with students could be rewarding, the "office dynamics" between graduate students and tenured faculty were tense and toxic. I often felt like I was taken advantage of by faculty who thought a simple thank-you would make up for it.

I quite honestly left CU because of my time as an RA. The university couldn't give a spit about you and asking for help from higher ups gets you nowhere. Stay away unless you absolutely have to do this to get the housing.
Helped pay my way through college.
UC Health previoiusly Poudre Valley Health was instrumental on my introduction to Internal Medicine. UCH provides not only amazing medical professional but medical resources.

This is a great place to start out as a green coder, there are opportunities for advancement. For the most part management is available for questions, issues but there have been so many changes lately that it is challenging to know who to go to. If you need help they will go out of their way to help you. Great company with wonderful benefits, I just personally find the work monotonous and hate sitting for eight hours. This is not the company's fault. If you enjoy medical coding this is a wonderful company.

The environment of this facility is centered around education. The staff supports the medical school & those who rotate through. The caseload offers great variety & the attending are very knowledgeable.

I love working here. UCCS is a better place to work than my last school job, USC. I didn't think I would find something better than USC, but I did in UCCS. I want to retire at UCCS. The only thing keeping me in Colorado Springs is my job at UCCS.

I learned a lot of things during my final year project both technical and logistical aspects. In here, I learned that safety is the important thing in a work place environment. As an engineer, I also learned the importance for management skills as well as working in a team.
I was able to learn about local food and our impact as consumers to make a change to a value based food system. SWELL helps fuel student success and is a life changing program.

Responsibilities include oversight for over 650 vehicles in the areas of:  vehicle maintenance and repair, bus services, driver safety training, auto allocation, vehicle accident claims and coordination of DOT, DOE, DOR permits and regulations.  Manage the daily functions of fleet operations, drive sustainability and growth using key performance indicators. Primary point of contact regarding vehicle replacement.

CU was alright though my PI was a jerk. She insisted I do my PHD in her lab, when I finally told her I didn’t want to she said that I wasn’t “intellectual” enough to pursue a PhD and that there was no point continuing my employment in her lab. I also experienced a bit of racism. People would legitimately call me racist names. CU is nice but the culture is not very inclusive. This is oobvious by the lack of women and POC employed as scientists and not cleaning ladies.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
Really become a part of your community and enhances your college experience. Help families and prospective students understand the environment and make a big decision about college.
it is a large organization, expect different work environments for each campus and department.

Staffing is usually an issue especially on night shifts and hospital planning leaves much to be desired. The sense of teamwork is what keeps me going to work everyday. I feel safe with my coworkers around because no one lets things fall through the cracks.
Math department has great staff that help you succeed in your classes and work with your schedule. They have opportunities to work more during summers as well.
I enjoyed working at the university. My department was filled with outgoing, knowledgeable, and helpful people who were always willing to go out of their way to assist you if they could.

Have been rewarded in experience and teaching with my employment at UCD. The staff is a good solid mixture of senior and transitional professors. The opportunity of teaching the offered varied courses is the best reward of teaching at UCD.

i feel the supervisors are encouraged by senior administration to badger their subordinates. it seemed to me that if you were to inform on your work mates and be a miserable sort of person, you would advance to lead and then supervisor

As a millennial, I didn’t think I’d want to stay at one place for too long. CU is a place that I can seen myself at for a long time. Not without its challenges, but overall, a place filled with passionate people focused on doing incredible work.

I worked at UCCS for 25 years and had a wonderful career there.  For the vast majority of my tenure, I had a terrific boss who was both supportive and empowering.  So, like any workplace, a lot depends on the culture your boss sets for the office.  It was also exciting to work at one of the fastest growing Universities in the nation--always new challenges to meet!
The overall experience at University of Colorado Denver was a pretty positive one. There is a lot of opportunity to grow ad learn new skills. The people there were helpful and friendly.
Racim place to work there . Coworkers very hostile.

The University of Colorado Denver has some of the best psychology professors I have every encountered. Most of the instructors there are involved in their community and provide a different experience from many other institutions.

As a research assistant, I never felt fully supported by my advisor.  I also felt out of touch from resources that I should have used more often.  I was performing my research alone, and I felt very isolated by that.

Large university with a well respected teaching hospital and medical school. Nurse practitioners are valued team members. However, advancing in your career can be difficult because of the academic structure.
As students, jobs CU provided are flexible that we can work and study. Fair payment and did learn a lot based on the job. Coworkers, supervisors, employers are supportive.
The title.

As a big institute and as the environment dictates here, you have to be very competent and on top of your project. I think there's small margin for mistakes but in general, there's no place for being lazy

Recent Graduate.  My passion comes from witnessing an illness in my family that had a name, but never made sense to me.  I want to understand and research how the human body acts and reacts, and how new technology can manipulate nature and improve the quality of our lives.
The university of Colorado Anschutz Medical campus is a great place to work in. I loved the research i do and what it represents in the real work. truly great/
Pay must reflect the amount of work a person does, if it does not then people feel as if they work does not matter. As sad as it is money does make all the differences.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
You can get great experience here and the benefits are fantastic. The pay is fair and competitive in the market. You will work hard but also learn a lot.
CU has a culture that is not relevant to the real world. It is political and slow moving and if you have ambition and ethics, you should work somewhere else.

The university provided me with the necessary tools to execute as a professional in my field of Music performance and education. This entity focuses not only in a great education but also in the progress of personal and professional development.
I enjoyed working with the faculty and the researcher.  I enjoyed the work and left to take a more challenging position. I worked in finance, grants, payroll and travel,

This company has a excellent benefits program. The work hour are fitting to every employee. I worked monday - Friday. I learned that each and every client is not the same. The most difficult part was when no matter what I did some clients just didn't get it and relapsed.

I thoroughly enjoyed my time as a Gateway Guide and the supervision that I received helped me to be a better clinician.  I got to experience different issues and was provided the supervision needed to navigate those issues.

Was a great part time job for 21/2 years that became a full time job for my last year. Great people, management, students and staff. Very professional and helpful at all times. Fun and enjoyed driving all over Colorado for the college. Enjoyed being involved with the different sports and events that took place.
University of Colorado Hospital is a productive and professional place to work. Doctors and nurses are well trained and take care of their patients well.

I would like to start off by saying that CU really does put a lot of effort into their culture. Many of my coworkers went to CU and loved it so much they became employees. That being said, I have very little to complain about.  I ultimately left because I was very frustrated by my role.  I didn't feel like it was a good fit for me and my goals. During the interview phase, I was certain that I would be in love with the role as my previous job encompassed some of the same duties.  Sometimes you just don't until you try a new role on. Leadership was very supportive of me throughout my time with CU and they were very gracious when I resigned. I would definitely recommend CU for an employer and I may consider them again in the future if my professional goals change.
I would suggest this workplace specifically for students that are coming back to school for a second time. I love the workplace culture and the people that I get to work alongside.

I love the place and the people and have truly enjoyed my tenure with the University of Colorado. Being a government entity, things take longer to happen than in the corporate world so took some time getting used too.
The university researcher position allows you to explore part of what your undergraduate studies helped you to develop. Working under professors can be incredibly helpful and challenging all at once.
Great work environment!  There is a great work/life balance. High level of academic professionalism.  I absolutely love coming to work and collaborating with such great professionals!

I run engineering programs at an off site location.  Since beginning, I implemented a mechanical engineering technology program.  We have brought on mechanical, civil and electrical and computer engineering since I began.
Working in the Athletic Department at the University of Colorado-Colorado Springs proved to be a great advancement in my abilities to coach and lead young student-athletes.

I applied for the transportation position without any preconceived idea of this position. I have been here three months now,  I can honestly say that the management cares, the passengers are very respectful. The equipment is well maintained any issues are looked into immediately. The pay I feel is good, the benefits are excellent, once again as in my summary you feel like a person who matters. This is my opinion about my personal experience. Wish I would have done this years ago.
A traditional professional environment with few rewards. Strict guidelines and often a high-stress, fast-paced atmosphere. Work hard and receive adequate training.
I loved my work-study here! It gave me so much knowledge and background of information that I really needed. If you are a student here and looking for more lab experience - APPLY HERE!
Though the location, and the doctors I worked with seem to be pleasant, there was always a negative vibe about the management and that made everyone very uneasy.

Beware. A bunch of "librals" who talk a really good game when it comes to fairness and equality, but at the end of the day they stay on code and are lowkey, sneaky, and racist. Don't let the smiling in your face fool you. Management and supervisors are cut throat, micromanaging, bullies.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
Great benefits, salaries don't keep up with industry.  Can be highly political, but can also offer great flexibility.  Wish there was more emphasis on hiring within to maintain experienced staff.

It was a tolerable place to work. Free drinks, and they already have food so you never have to bring your own lunch. Some days are slow, but for the most part it gets busy. Like really busy... some employees work hard, some not so much.... and you have like 3 different managers (if you’re working kitchen anyway) I mostly worked dishes. Which I didn’t mind. It’s a nice work environment with its perks. But get ready to get a little dirty while working
Great working environment with peers and classmates. Typical day would open and close tool/equipment and workspace areas used for assembling mock-ups and constructing other components to a project.

I was able to quickly get up to speed coming from a SQL Server background.  The University data warehouse is set up well and allowed me to ETL everything i needed to successfully create reports.  Nice work environment.

I worked for CU for many years, in several departments. I was highly regarded and given commendations and raises for the work I did... that is, until I fell on the ice and got a spinal injury. I needed to take time off and had to get accommodations because of the pain. I ended up missing a lot of work because I couldn’t sleep due to pain.  All of a sudden, all the good regard vanished and the university itself and my coworkers basically abandoned me.
Supportive culture all around!  Good management, caring, kind and encouraging. Promote from within- mentorship.  They also help graduates find job placement
A good place to start and continue your career. However, at a certain age they may lay you off. It is a good place to work and usually has challenging and good learning experiences.

The culture makes it incredibly hard.  If you do not fit in with your team, you will not make it far at all.  The seniority which exists doesn't allow for the opportunity to enhance policies and procedures, as there is a resistance to change.  People are in roles and positions which they do not have the qualifications or knowledge base to accomplish.  The departments are completely siloed through each campus, and each school, and so on, with no consistency required.

A typical day at work is very active and requires excellent decisionmaking skills.  You are exposed to a wide variety of research endeavors and problem solving in the export compliance realm.  The workplace culture is collegial and team work oriented.
Great place to work while in graduate school. Would have preferred to stayed with the university after graduation, however there were other opportunities that arose.
The benefits for the position are very good - retirement, vacation, and health care. The work tends to be more interesting and varied than in the private sector.
Enjoy teaching future engineers.  Classrooms are easy to use and easy to find.  The department staff is very helpful in addressing textbook needs and student concerns.
Very stressful  environment but I would really not recommend working here. It is difficult to live in Boulder with the high cost of living but, if you live farther away it does get cheaper.
Working in Research labs at CU boulder was very relaxed. I had great coworkers and project supervisors. I was a great learning environment and opportunity.
I worked as a Postdoctoral Fellow at CU Boulder for 2 years.

The University of Colorado Anshutz is a top-notch academic university located in Aurora, CO. The environment is challenging given the poor likelihood of obtaining R01 Grants today from NIH. When I was there the payouts were 8% or lower. Everyone is looking for funding to continue their research. I loved everything about my job except the very difficult, almost impossible funding climate.

Staff obviously cares about students and want then to receive a wonderful education. Being on a campus that also houses two nationally ranked hospitals generates wonderful learning opportunities and professional connections.
I didn't mind going to work. I really enjoyed my boss, co-workers and there was always something to do so shifts would go by quickly. It was my first office job and it was very enjoyable.

I currently work reviewing IRB forms- management is lacking some have been here too long in management and don't have a good concept of working loads - hiring the best candidates etc. We have a few people in the department I would describe as incompetent. I worry about the safety of the research being reviewed

A relaxed environment with good equipment and staff. The campus is absolutely fantastic and student body is a pleasure to serve. Pay could be better, especially now that minimum wage gap is shrinking, but it's also equal to other places for similar work so all things considered not bad. Great benefits if offered with position. Low stress, good work/life balance and plenty of time off are true positives. If you looking for something less than full time, knock yourself out finding something better than this opportunity. Only con is some later shifts may be required, but typically offer a shift premium also.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
