productive, creative and fun academic institute

I have worked for the University for about a year now and all the promises they told me to begin with are complete lies. Management is very unorganized, you are not paid appropriately for your job title, very low raises, expected to work harder and longer but for no extra compensation. Division very unorganized as a whole.

Very hard to get into unless alumni, some departments have little/no room for advancement and are very difficult to break out of. HR department is currently in chaos and has been very irratical for 10 years. Workflow is feast or famine. Unusual management mix in my area. My job is very technical, it took 2 years to learn it. The most enjoyable part is the " programming ". Workplace culture is pretty good. Love working in higher education.

It is never a dull moment working in a methadone clinic. Job is challenging, stressful and fulfilling.  The training is great, you are trained to be a first class therapist. The hardest part of the job is the changes with forms and case load.
They are very discriminatory, I would not recommend this workplace to anyone who wants to keep their sanity.  There is no help for those who are being discriminated against.

However, my questions were always answered, exceptions made when needed, and support always there.  It was a pretty straightforward position interviewing youth and caregivers for a youth violence prevention research study.  We got bonuses for every 5 interviews conducted, competitive bonuses for the most interviews in a week, etc.  Then when it got hard to convince people to participate, we were able to pay them more and were paid more ourselves.

Absolutely HORRIBLE employer to work for!!! They treat their employees with the utmost disrespect and lack of feeling. The "supervisor" was an 18 year old girl who was in charge of personal training who would spend her time taking about her personal life and how drunk she got the night before then taking responsibility for her position. The pay is TERRIBLE. As a HIGHLY qualified personal trainer I only was paid slightly higher than minimum wage. There are NO raises or opportunities for advancement.
UCCS was a wonderful place to work and I enjoyed everyday. The environment is truly one of a kind and welcoming. I would love to go back and work here again if given the chance
Good place to work. They offer good learning opportunity as well. Work culture is "University culture" and work does not get done as quickly as private enterprise.
I am surrounded by positive people on a daily basis. People are clearly passionate about the work they are doing and this contributes to a great working environment.

The REC is a great place for students to work, there are flexible hours, the building is organized well, and there are jobs for all different types of people including some who are not crazy fitness enthusiasts.
The best company I have ever worked for because I felt like I was doing the work that I was required perfectly based on all of the requirements that I had to follow.
Very poor work environment with gossip controlling the decision-making. The Institutional research office is unprofessional and sexist in the extreme but tries to hide it.

The quality of the work-life at CU is highly variable depending on who you work for; much of the medical school is known for exploiting their hard-working PRA workers, Post-Docs, and grad students, but there are some groups who treat their employees well and perform excellent quality research and education services.

UCCS is a great regional employer and the staff and faculty really care about the students. There is a lot of decentralization, which in some ways can be beneficial but in a lot of ways, is causing a lot of frustration, confusion, and unnecessary walls to be put up. Administration seems really far removed from staff; faculty demonstrate they feel superior to staff, and there is a constant battle for resources; time and money. Many positions are underpaid/undervalued (which is partly an issue with the very limited resources coming from the state), and this is causing substantial turnover.
I had a good overall experience with the school and how they treated the players, coaches, and staff members part of the university. City and fans were great, just a good overall experience.

As a Learning Assistant (LA), the bulk of responsibilities involved providing support for students attending lecture and being accessible for assistance outside of these lectures. I've learned more about the material by relearning what I've learned the first go around. My professor was of great support and provided ample guidance. The hardest part was balancing work outside of school, a full-course load, and having 10 hours of LA hours per week. Being able to help a student is invaluable and supersedes any stresses I had in terms of time commitments.

Work consists of helping patrons with ticketing and seating in the various shows that all perform at the ENT Center for the Arts. Involves some work with a fairly complex computer system, but otherwise a very simple job.
Awesome place to work! Interactive times with students makes the job and interesting and fun on a day to day basis. I love the way team building helped helped form bonds.
Great Place to work and Be! I enjoyed the social interaction with students faculty and staff. Working with students in a social and professional environment made it fun and interactive.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
Love working with students, but overall lacking in leadership and development opportunities for non MD staff. Lot of turnover in the last two years, which may have skewed my perspective.
CU was always willing to work with my work schedule, and supplied great benefits. Only downfall is that you have to pay roughly $100 a month for parking if you do not live on campus.
Assisted Professor in the Administration of the course Time Series Forecasting. Helping the faculty in entering the grades of all the students. Helping faculty in teaching few concepts to students.
Great place to work and search for an internship. I learned a lot while having the internship, especially in the areas of civil engineering and construction management.
I would highly recommend that you not work here unless there are no other options available to you. Its a highly dysfunctional place to work with a total lack of leadership.
Great work/life balance but hard to move up due to very limited opportunity. Take advantage of the benefits to balance out for the job being lower paying than similar positions.

I have studied under several professors and have had a wonderful experience here. I feel intellectually stimulated and challenged. In my time at the University I have learned a lot and feel excited to learn more.

I had a good experience working for the university. I had a part time job working with the university while I was a student. I would say it's a great position to be in for any student as it is convenient to take classes on the same campus that you work on. I was unsure of some of the higher ups and how they treated their full time employees but my time at the university was great.
Nice environment and good community!
Not too many opportunities for advancement, once you go over the mid career level. System is slow in general, but a lot depends on the department.
Very fast paced, so I was always busy and had something to do. Very little down time, so the shifts went by very fast. It was great to build more student relations.

The University provides good benefits including a great contribution to their 403b retirement plan but the pay leaves a lot to be desired. Getting hired can be challenging as they seem to most often hire from within or hire people based on who they know (like their neighbors children). I worked in a laboratory that was completely toxic and a huge liability to the university in many ways. CU was either unaware of the atrocities occurring there or was simply turning a blind eye to them. Getting hired, at least where I was, was either being in the right place at the right time, or simply knowing the right person who could get your foot in the door. Promotion/merit raises were basically non existent, unless you knew someone or sucked up to the right person. It was absolutely NOT based on the amount of quality hard work and dedication you showed. CU has potential to be a great place to work but be careful and choosy about where you accept employment within the organization. There are many wolves in sheep's clothing hiding within, who are more than happy to use you up completely.
Some situations are not desirable to me but overall it's good experiences to have. I learned a lot in the experiences and I got more confident about working after the experiences for sure.

Although I was not paid enough and worked more than was documented the skills I acquired working with the university I found extremely helpful. The opportunity to grow and and actively take part in improving and helping the community I lived in was unbelievably rewarding.

I work EVERYDAY (weekend included) my working hours far more than 40h/week.I have no personal life and running a stressful lifestyle.Anyway I would say, If you want to work in someone's lab MUST be a very healthy person and never get sick.

I enjoyed both earning my undergraduate degree at UCD as well as working in multiple capacities, in different departments.  UCD is a wonderful learning environment and provides many opportunities to  grow.

It's the "good, ol'boy" mentality... especially in Student Affairs. Arrogant leaders who fire good, longtime employees, often without cause. Those who are fired are replaced by leader's "buddies" by appointment avoiding legitimate searches for the best qualified candidates.

The Lab managers were wonderful people and everyone around was full of knowledge and often helped those who needed it. The learning experience was incomparable to any other for-profit company in that they were watching out for your best interest.

Fantastic mentors helped to guide me in my endeavors to research ferromagnetic fluids, ferromagnetic clusters, and iron nanoparticles in both the Chemistry and Physics departments at UCCS. this taught me to collaborate with others in the lab, designing experimental procedures, collaborating with other universities, and how to begin the process of theoretical research.

I learned a lot and had a great experience working in the Communication department as an Undergraduate Research Assistant. I was paid for my contributions and it also boosted my resume and helped in the post-grad job hunt!
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
The university is  not very good with the benefit package and there is wasteful spending of monies. Employees are charged $75  for parking per month which is ridiculous.
Training is adequate, workload is sometimes overwhelming. Benefits are good. Supervision is lacking sometimes and staff is supposed to know what is going on before training.
A typical school. Some teachers are great some are not. You get what you put into nursing school. Like all schools; tuition increases and pay scales do not.
A research job requires
I didn't want to leave the job, and if i could go back i would. My Managers were amazing, job training was great. the people i wrked with were really great people.

During the classes, I learn interesting subjects about the environment and how architecture take an approach using the elements from the environment. Study at CU Denver was very nice because I know new people with different culture and my knowledge is increasing.
Great team work, Charge nurse were great, a lot things to learn, staff was wonderful at training new employees. Benefit were very good
•	Work with departments to invoice grant sponsors for research expenditure reimbursement
Typical day - there was lots of work - loved working with the students, staff and professors.  Lots of opportunity to advance and learn.

I started off working as a financial loan assistant, over time they needed student staff to do more than they were required to do.  Due to budgets decreasing, I was cross-trained into web development as well as document imaging which were two different departments.  When I asked for an incentive for the workload I was given, the Employer refused.  Since my workload and job requirements increased along with my experience and knowledge of the departments but I still was only getting paid minimum wage for 2 years; I had to resign.

Would like to give an additional 5 years of service to the community.  Continued knowledge in healthcare. Advanced from CTA to referral specialist. Participating in most prpgrams there and incetives off campus support.

Lecturer for review courses in mechanical and general engineering for both the Engineer in Training/Fundamentals of Engineering (EIT/FE), and Professional Engineering (PE) license exams. Courses include Basic Engineering Practices, GD&T, Principles of Mechanical Systems and Materials, and Application of Mechanical Systems and Materials for the PE examination, as well as Material Science, Statics, Dynamics, and Strength of Materials I and II for the EIT/FE examination.
I was only a lecturer so I didn't have any benefits or even an office (there was a space provided to hold office hours).  The math dept has nice people and helpful staff.
The university offered a flexible schedule to its students and therefore made the perfect working environment. Everyone had a very inviting personality and the workload is manageable.
The culture at UCCS is very laid-back and friendly, all departments work as a team.  Because most of the employees are also UCCS students, the job schedule works around your other priorities.
Management is taking a fiscal approach and wants to get rid of higher paid employees.

I really enjoyed the challenge of my position and the people with whom I worked. The work was fairly routine, not having a great deal of change but always challenging. My supervisor and Director were great process managers but very poor people managers. "Policy" rules were applied differently by employee and not with any consistent standard. Performance expectations were also different based on who was liked and not liked. There was always a significant level of stress as to being "watched" and monitored to the microscopic level. This was a sentiment shared by many, not just me.
I was a work-study student at UCD and it was a great way to build up work experience while being a student. My work schedule wrapped around my class schedule.
New state of the art facilities
Best place to work as a student, they work with your school schedule and help you grow. I will always appreciate the opportunities given to me by uccs
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
Portrayal of different cases for the Medicine students was a great way to help them develop skills needed for their job once they graduated as a Doctor.

Worked for the University of Colorado almost 25 years. Best job I ever had. I learned many things and was treated very well. Would recommend anyone in Colorado looking for a career to check out the University.
slow to adpat to new technology, pay could be a lot better, parking is a hassle, if you want yo get a spot arrive early. the university does not allow working remotley.

A productive and collaborative environment for any college student. As a writing consultant and writing fellow, I aided students regularly with college level assignments. I also helped students understand and communicate.

Good place to work with great benefits but the salaries are average to low.  The vacation time accrued is great and the retirement plan is amazing.  Working at the Anschutz Medical Campus keeps all doctors close and rarely do you need to go elsewhere for medical care.
Very negative environment.  Lots of gossip and back stabbing.  No good training and high expectations with little to no reward other than normal wages and benefits.
The University of Colorado is an excellent place to work and has great career advancement opportunities.  Science drives the mission and is noble and incredible.
It has been a while since I worked there but my boss was super....very supportive.  The faculty and staff were all very nice and I liked the interaction with the students.
I worked here while going to graduate school. The job worked well with my school schedule. I appreciated the experience for teaching and tutoring. I would consider going back.

Too much politics, inbreeding, blackmail, fear of being let go, control. The supervisors say one thing, but do the opposite and should an employee object, they always find a way to blame the employee.
Was very fun with all the people working there. Everyone was friendly and the work was not overbearing. The others were working so there were no conflicts there.

I worked at UCCS for a good deal of my undergraduate studies, and was sorry to leave. My position was in the Languages and Social Sciences Center, where our primary task was to tutor our fellow students in language classes. I enjoyed my time there tremendously, but left a few months short of graduation due to management issues which persist to this day.

Working at the Facilities Services front desk at the University of Colorado Colorado Springs was a great job. The main objective is to direct work orders to the proper facilities team. This job also requires event setup, report creation and management, project assistance to upper management.
everyone was a team player
University of Colorado is a proactive, progressive learning institution with a strong opportunity for upward mobility and progression within the school.

Processes were solid in receiving and distribution of hospital medical supplies  Specialty was the operating room. Average 160 cases per day. Worked with various healthcare providers including surgeons, nurses, and Md's.

The University of Colorado campus has it benefits and its negatives. Benefits are amazing, PTO, health insurance, etc. Compensation is in the lower tiers unless you are faculty. Job security is quite good, but opportunity for advancement within the same department is low and would require relocation to an alternative department. No job culture existent at all. Work place respects 8 hours per day 5 days a week, in most areas.  As with most large employers, politics is prevalent. It is not about you or your contribution to the team effort, its about how you can make your boss look good to their bosses. Humility and ownership are rarely displayed, especially when dealing with faculty.
I studied in Univeryof Colorado in Colorado Springs for almost two years and started to work there as well. My job was to organized paper and aswers phone calls .
An incredible place to work at with. An organization with a very inviting and inclusive culture where high quality is never undermined yet the pressure of work is not overwhelming.

I cannot say enough good things about the Dean of the Kraemer Family Library.  He encourages skill development, places the utmost importance on diversity and cultural competence.  These issues are of great personal significance to me.  I was very sorry that my position was only a temporary placement for the Spring Semester.  I hope that someday, I will have the opportunity to work at or with the library again.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
Good Company to work for. Strong dependance on Vendors and Outsourcing.  Could work towards more in-house application development to secure the Charter initiatives.

This is a great place to retire from. Great people and atmosphere. A lot of training opportunities. The hardest part of the job was dealing with certain supervisors. the most enjoyable part of the job is working with the front line crew that I trained and worked with.

I know what to work on every day and I learned good time management to help complete the tasks assigned to me. I have learned a lot about how the University works, and that has helped me as an employee and as a student.
Don’t work here. This place is corrupt- from top to bottom. You can last here 1 year- if even . The environment in almost every department is toxic. Be careful of HR.

Some departments have top notch management; others not so much. The culture varies as well. I have appreciated the ability to get my graduate degree using staff tuition benefits and am ready for a change.

Located in downtown Denver is the most important point why CU Denver is a good place to work and make connections to people. Lot's of chance to learn because of the abundant resources I can use including Anschutz Campus.

Great benefits and salary is decent. Lack of advancement depending on the department you are in. Job title is misleading as almost everyone in my department has the same hired title but hold very different roles. Management and leadership is okay, again, depends on your department.
Best summer of my life
I worked for berwick electric and did not work for the university. I was a foreman on building the new library at that time. Very nice library and enjoyed my time there
I'm just a part time teacher's assistant, grading papers for undergrads during the school year. This is my third semester in grad school, and my third semester as a TA.

Hard work and work ethic comes second to social acceptance and networking. Who you know is key to success within the University. Also, promotions are extremely biased and leadership promotes from within.

I appreciated the opportunities given to me. I do believe that they prefer younger workers. The schedule was flexible with business hours and opportunity to work remotely. I enjoyed the team approach while I was there. I enjoyed a fast-paced  but pleasant work environment. I did not work in the University facility form 2012 through 2018 but appreciated the support they gave me as an affiliate worker.
Great place, great environment, lots of bars in the city, relaxed. Friendly boss, everyone is friendly, sometimes a little bit too much. Working pace a little slow but that is great.

As a student employee, the university staff/employees make sure to work our hours around our class schedule. They are very flexible, and it really helps when you have a test or assignment you need to complete. If you get your work done, it's not a difficult job.
I had this job with my Professor in the school for writing the paper and grating two courses in the school. it was very good and I tried very hard in that performance.
I enjoy working at the University of Colorado, but I am looking for a remote job in which I can work from home.  The University is a professional environment with dedicated staff
Great place to work, great benefits and people.  There is the opportunity for advancement.  Great work/life balance.  Organization that follows its mission and cares for it's staff.
to much people talking about each other and there was to much drama and poor mananment manger dont deal with or help with the employee problems out cast many people
I have many positive things to say about The University of Colorado School of Dental Medicine.
University is big and policy is well addressed. But science is different. People are stressful. Some but not all professors are not nice to students/associates.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
Productive place to work. I enjoyed what I learned there, but I wouldn't want to do another research project. The hardest part of the job is the research.

I had the opportunity to work in the Neurology Department of the University of Colorado's Aurora campus.  There I worked with the Education/Medical School Admissions department and assisted with administering testing for incoming first years.  This position was very flexible with hours and I enjoyed the opportunity to work with different departments on campus.
at least several laboratories at Anschutz medical campus are poorly run with low productivity and unhappy employees.  The quality of research work is very laboratory/supervisor dependent,

The University of Colorado functions much different than any other place I have worked. Departments are their own little company but all fall under the School of Medicine. Each department is much different. For instance, the Department of Family Medicine offers a very flexible schedule and allows work from home where other departments don't offer this. It is great if you have a family because of the flexibility. The only downfall is that if you are not faculty there is not much growth. There is movement but it is typically lateral.
I left for a Federal position, but wished I had not. It is a good place to work.

As an unpaid student research assistant, the hours were flexible and the principle investigators are great. Graduate school was rough but everyone in your lab is going through it and pushing you along. I would recommend this institution to any student.

The opportunity to be with intelligent and aspiring professors and students who soak up knowledge and wish to change the world. Once you get through the experience of working for this place you will find many opportunities to advance in the business and industrialized world.
Great place to work. Great retirement benefits and great people to work with. Very enjoyable work environment. Totally recommended to anyone looking for nice place to work
The state is no longer competitive in pay, hours worked, longevity of benefits or any other area that it used to be leader in.  Private sector now outbids them in all areas.
The professors I worked for was very helpful with the sites I was working on. As well as providing me direction on my research projects that I had took time to pursue.
Too bad my position was eliminated.  I adored UCCS.  The students were great as were all the members of the staff and support team.  I enjoyed my autonomy.
A top notch research institution on the outskirts of Denver with great resources and excellent faculty. A beautiful campus and a terrific place to work.
Worked as a front desk attendant swiping members in to the schools gym. Performed gym cleaning, supervision and ensured a safe environment. Short flexible shifts.
Relaxed teaching atmosphere and cultural environment.
Emotionally draining and management does not support staff or clients. Its all about the money. There is no career advancment opportunities. Everyone is underpaid, overworked and underappreciated.
It was work study so when ever I do not have class I worked so it was convenient for me with my schedule and life style at that time that is why I loved there.
Administration gives too many people the power to make decisions. No one is safe. Co-workers will throw you under the bus just to save their own skin. I would never recommend UCCS to anyone.
This was a great place for me to grow and learn. It was my first job in a professional setting and it was a great experience. All of the coordinators were friendly, helpful and welcoming.
Good individual project trust to be completed. Wonderful staff to give praise in job well done. Great referrals and references. Great skills they helped me to improve.

The research team at the UNC Denver Lab was a great place to learn and grow.  I enjoyed the time with my team mates and my teacher. I was given many opportunities to apply the knowledge acquired at the school and learn more.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
Great crew, great challenges, restrictive management.
Working at  University of Colorado  provided me the opportunity to meet people with diverse cultural backgrounds. I also enjoyed a lot of interdepartmental collaborations.

There are plenty of great jobs at UCCS.  The management can be difficult to deal with as they worry about their situations far more than the employees under them, and it can create some work dynamics that are very stressful.

Make sure all the documents are up to date and uploaded into PSAM. There are a several equipment pick up per week that I had to pick up and bring them to the storage room. The hardest part is doing inventory monthly.

The jobs indicated in this summary were a work-study or part-time position, which allowed for flexibility to attend classes and complete my degree. Due to the part-time nature, there were no benefits such as medical, dental, or other benefits.

The environment and the people I worked with were AMAZING. I always felt welcome on the campus, the work was fulfilling, and there were excellent benefits. I am still sad that I had to leave this position. The only reason I did was because I moved to Florida for my husband's job. Great place to work!

While being a teacher assistant at the university I learned a lot. It gives the opportunity for many different years of engineering students to work together and learn more about what the program is all about. While giving younger students a look into their future.

I was a student worker and it is the perfect temporary job.  I worked alongside the fulltime staff and while it seems like they enjoy their job, it is not where I find myself growing professionally.  It is a slow paced work environment and is not very difficult of a job.  Only times where the office picks up is at the beginning and end of the semesters.

I teach students from CU who come to DC for a semester to intern in some of the most dynamic and interesting places in Washington.  I strive to incorporate their class experience with their professional workdays.

work day was great i was very independent when not busy drew blood for other departments and checked in patients when needed and did vitals etc.Management was great and so was the Culture.The hardest part about the lob was putting in the insurance information for labs to see if it would be covered and the most enjoyable was working with patients and an excellent staff..

My previous manager in this position was a lot better and I had a lot of opportunities to grow with my company while I was in school. It was stressful to have this as my second job on top of school and my primary work.
Great dental school, great comprehensive education. Gain experience in all aspects of general dentistry with experience in digital technology and treatment planning.

Great benefits, would stay if I made enough to live off, I enjoy my co workers, it's a great location as well. We are given good breaks and PTO but I wish the pay was a little higher as the cost of living in CO has sky rocketed.

It's hard to get in the CU Denver system since a lot of people transfer within the system, but once you get a job there you are basically set. There are great benefits, work life balance, and in some places great work environment. CU Denver can be a little political at times, so getting hired isn't easy.

The work environment and the work I was doing was very fulfilling and I was learning things very quickly within their systems. However, only being a temporary employee made things such as my future their uncertain. I was doing more and more for the department but still not full time. I did not enjoy get drug along for eight months and being told that they would have the money for an for in the next 4-6 weeks.

Great work environment, the professors are all wonderful to work with. The only downside is the pay, even for a part time position. Given the cost of living in the greater denver area, we do not make enough.

Worked as a researcher in the field of clinical - translational - basic science.   Work environment was pretty good, and fluctuated from relaxed to stressful.  Good teams to work with.  Sometimes collaborative work moved at a snails pace, but that was how the system works in funded research.

It is a great place to interact with each others. When the rush comes, it usually is really busy. They always messed up with the schedules. I bet some of them have time to work but not scheduled. Some of them does not available. They scheduled.

Really enjoyed teaching undergrads about these subjects and having the opportunity to invest time in college students.  Also, enjoyed grading and providing feedback on papers that will help them with there future.
Great place to work, good bennies and time off. It's a teaching hospital so I learned a lot working at University Hospital in Aurora Colorado. I would recommend it.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
Great place to work. Even as a student employee you are appreciated and a vital part of the university's work force. I would not have left if I had not graduated.

I’m a full-time student I would like to get a online job because I’m planning on studying abroad so I can work from home. I have many experience with many active jobs such as the gym, yoga and gymnastics coaching. I also have experience working in the kitchen I enjoy cooking making many different cultural meals.
The work I loved to do, but the work environment was very hostile and competitive at times.  Not an enjoyable atmosphere. This job has a very high turnover rate.
This is a great place to work if you are wanting to grow in the research community. The past 6 years working here have been really rewarding and the experience gained here is very valuable.

I really enjoyed teaching and instructing the labs, but the worst part about the job was the grading. As a grader, you get paid less, you work harder, and people are always coming to you with problems.
I was a graduate teaching assistant. There were no benefits with the job as pay was per diem per class.
Its not a nice place to work at.  You are treated like garbage by people in superior positions.  The hours are bad and the pay is very lousy. Dont work there

Typical day consisted of 8-10 hours of fast-paced, collaborative work. Management was highly trained. Workplace culture is formal, professional. Hardest part of the job was keeping up with a fast-paced environment. Lots of deadlines. Enjoyable part of the job was always learning something new.
It was a temporary job while being a student at the University of Colorado Colorado Springs. I learned many items from managing, organization, and time-management
UCHealth is growing and changing, you will learn a lot and advance if you want to. Work life balance is good  and the culture is changing for the good.
I worked as a student assistant at the university. It was nice helping students to solve their tech-related queries and always try to come up with an alternative solution.

a place where you do a lot of multi task while having a blast of fun while working. the people that i worked with starting from the managers to the professors and facility members i have helped are very nice and intelligent people.
Positive work environment. Each mistake was turned into a learning moment for everyone. A chance to learn topics in other fields. Works around your school schedule.
Pay could be a lot better. Limited facilities for drivers. Used to be better when overtime was offered doing charters. Benefits are good when offered.

Theres definitely a lot of positive things about CU. The benefits and time off are hard to compete with, but the structure separates certain faculty and staff from accountability for poor performance.

The team in the department I was in was excellent - very professional, friendly, the manager was kind and supportive.  The workload, however, was very heavy.  Lack of support and infrastructure is fairly common in university settings and UC Denver is no exception, as they usually focus resources on scientists and researchers who bring in funding.
This employment was a hostile work environment and management did not recognize their employees. Management was hired based on years of experience instead of degrees.
I have worked for this company for four years and it has provided me with a good job to get through college. I have earned three raises and now have the highest position for a student employee.
Busy with Contractors, State Monitors, School Deans, Finance Director, on going project, inspection of buildings and facilities.  Supervising maintenance, and planning of future works

It depends on the department as there are dozens of places to work on campus, but of three places I've worked, all have had terrible leadership with Administrators who micromanage and do not understand how research is run, or the amount of time it takes to effectively and efficiently do a job so that things run smoothly.  Those who suck up to the right people are able to move up quickly and make obscene salaries, getting paid to be mediocre at best, incompetent at worst.  Many leaders on the campus are held to zero accountability and leave the lower level administrative staff to clean up their messes.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
Great benefits, bad salaries.
Fun job:
its ok,  i like it  ,  I did no have to work very hard and got paid a lot of money for doing next to nothing,  just the kind of job american worker like.
Wonderful place to grow within your career. Excellent Doctors and staff. I will miss this place and can only hope to find an working environment that's just as beautiful.
Staff and job duties were interesting and different from what I had before in jobs. Great manager still friends today.  Worked well with my school schedule.
good place to work. Training and advancement is good. People are good and willing to work. Pay is a bit low but the benefits are great. Includes low cost health care.

Management in flux constantly.  Doctors are not managers, especially surgeons.  Administration and Physicians have completely different ways of managing departments, and surgeons really just want to operate.  Too many cooks, not enough cooking.

University of Colorado likes to think of itself as a competitor with the big universities in the country but is still a country university.  Most of its accolades come from the fact that it has little to no competition.  It is difficult to see the University of Colorado becoming "world class", as it likes to see itself, when it continues to train and rehire its own people after sending them elsewhere for their specialty degree.   If CU wants to be better, it needs to diversify, hire experts from world class universities and MAINTAIN THEM.   Turnover for outside experts is too high.
I worked here as a part time job while in college. It was great because it worked well with my school schedule and I got experience in my future profession setting.
This is honestly the best place I have worked, they work like a team and the supervisor and management staff was top notch.  I love working here and hope to come back in the future
Be available in individual, couples, and family counseling, schedule and document appointments, create treatment plan, participate in individual and group supervision.
I worked as a pharmacy student tutor for other members in my class. Pay was great for a student tutor position. I was able to work my own hours and could flex them as I saw fit.

While working for catering, my manager was very high strung and would get mad if you made any mistakes. Working at the Roaring Fork was enjoyable because it was easy and the jobs were the same every day.

The research position was a dream at first, flexible hours, good pay, nice people, promising managment. I worked hard and felt appreciated. Sadly when the project hit a bump it all got put on me, I was forced to work overtime, often left on my own flailing, and after a short amount of time, and a lot of efforts, I was still terminated suddenly. CUs lawyers fought my unemployment claim and thus I received no benefits.

Enjoyed the structure of the job.  Seeing confined women recognize their actions and making a change to have a better life.   The structure of the program to reconnect families.  The facility followed state and federal regulations to ensure compliance with law.

Good place to gain strong analytical skills. . Additionally, working as a Chief Research Assistant has given me extraordinary leadership and time-management skills. I have been entrusted with managing and running an NSF workshop for the behavioral sciences and ontologists. I have been able to run projects smoothly and effectively while ensuring the best outcomes.

short staff  technicians quit frequently, management concentrated on gossip not actual facts. favoritism, if management like you your fine but if they don't like you no matter what you do , you always going to be in bad with management.

A wonderful place to work. All the people at the university were top notch. The work was great and the benefits as well.I would recommend this place to all people who enjoy a great working environment.

I learned a lot about research and was given the liberty to explore my own ideas. It was really conducive to fostering interest in research and gave great insight into what it means to conduct research and get involved in academia.
Great place to work for students. The school insures that students work schedules are made around their class schedules. They pay well for the position being part-time.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
t is a great place to work and go to school would spend a life time there if I could really enjoyd the campus and would recommend it too anyone definitly
I've never worked in an organization this size before; so I don't know if this culture is normal. Each school does their own thing and takes (is given?) little direction from their campus or system.
It was great working at University of Colorado, Employee friendly, nice work life balance, excellent management. It offers very good Benefits to its employees.
The management was incredibly awesome. Learned a lot from co-workers . Very neat place to work. If was a very good paid job. The dental plans and medical plans were awesome.

This mid-sized university offers lots of support for faculty and rewards them through a solid benefits package. The students are great to work with, and I look forward to staying in my position here for years to come.

The program was just to help students earn extra income and build resumes. The professors were great to work with and always willing to help a teaching assistant with any questions or professional references they needed.

While working at the University I encountered a multitude of wonderful cooworkers, but management and other supervisory positions created real barriers to innovation because of ego and preference. Digital record keeping, automation of large scale distributions, digital marketing and social media are current good practices in today's office environment but were not preferred practices on the Anschutz Medical Campus. Very happy to innovate elsewhere!

There are some places that have a great work place environment and others are horrendous. Be careful when selecting a lab. Postdocs are not given retirement and are treated not quite as faculty, but not given the benefits of the student discounts in exchange.
The level of working totally depends on the level of the research program. Sometimes, it is hard. It needs more time for myself to work on it. Sometimes, it is easy, you can nail it within hours.

The new CEO is not present for the most part, the other one we had before her, you would see him make rounds even on the weekends. She just seems to be focused on money and not satisfaction amongst staff
not much to say good place to work and have a job. For the most part let you do your work. Good manager. Could be better for advancement but not bad. Enjoyed
Never worked for the University of Colorado but do not have the option to state that in this program.
Grup işinden ziyade birey işi. Her kişi kendi çektiği vidyodan sorumlu.

I have not had a position within the University that was defined, well, prior to my being assigned to the work.  I have worked extremely independently for many years developing programs and maximizing organization with each program I've managed.  I have enjoyed this work, greatly, as I find I am excellent in a fast paced environment where my organizational and problem solving skills can be put to use.

The Family Development Center at UCCS was a wonderful experience as a pre-school teacher and a parent of a kindergarten student.  The facility was clean, asthetically pleasing, safe, and child oriented.  The equipment was well cared for and kept clean for the children.  The teachers were dedicated, educated, creative, and child oriented. The administrators, were hands on, enthusiatic, and always available to parents as well as teachers, and children.  Being a certified behavior specialist, and  first  grade teacher for many years,  I was given the freedom to develop a creative, interactive educational curriculum based on the needs of my nine 3-5 year olds in the part-day program.  I only wish that I could be with the children five days a week instead of two.  We had so much fun!  This experience led me to completing an early childhood internship at Pikes Peak College in 2004.  If I was still living in Colorado Springs, I would have loved to teach full-time at FDC.
Adjunct professor of finance. Treated well by staff and dean of college. Good working relationship with other professors. Good interaction with students.

Growing pains, I would stay as it evolves but can't live on the low pay. Beautiful facility. Good management but it would be helpful if management communicated with employees about the vision and  it's direction.
Great location for an assistant who is looking for full benefits.  Little room for advancement.  Friendly staff and a fun environment most sterilization and processing work.
I learned a lot about the correctional system.  The hardest part of the job was working inside the walls of a prison and the numerous procedures required.
Great staff and wonderful environment. The benefits were awesome and the leave was bountiful. Parking wasn't all that great, but the atmosphere was refreshing.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.

I worked at the College of Nursing on the Anschutz Campus which is a nice campus. Unfortunately, a lot of attention is given to the medical school because they have the biggest population on the campus, so not as much attention is given to the other schools. Since this is the case, and the majority rules, many funds are geared towards research for the medical school and not the College of Nursing. I did like working there until the end partly because of the political atmosphere and it was getting to be where if one person complained about anything, everyone had to go out of their way to accommodate. It is impossible to make everyone happy all of the time. Staff seemed a little underappreciated by management. The focus was more on hiring the best faculty which is understandable to attract students. However due to the creation of new programs, sometimes staff support was not in the loop, causing issues that were preventable if there had been better communication. Despite these issues that occurred, I did enjoy working at the college specifically with faculty and staff.
The role of the undergraduate research assistant was to support the PhD candidates through their research. The work was research based and exciting. New information was learned daily.

A typical day at work was primarily self-directed by each individual as they planned their own lesson plans for delivering to the students. Acquired knowledge from  this experience involved 1) an in-depth orientation into the educational environment, 2) a wonderful opportunity to create teacher/student relationships, 3) I developed a tremendous level of respect for my peers and the professors guiding me, and 4) the acquisition of my degree which I had wanted to complete for years.
CU Denver, is a great place to work!  As an employee of this great institution, you can also be a student.  Your dependents can take advantage of the tuition benefit as well.
Career growth opportunities are less and in general slow paced.
Workplace environment and compensation are extremely variable depending on department and principle investigator. Benefits are excellent and campus is lovely.
No room for advancement, long work hours and they wanted staff to spy and report back to the project manager what was going on inside participants homes.
Slow paced work environment. Temporary assignment, but had to sped up the process all the timer to meet deadlines. Very friendly, but very slow  surrounding. Have to be proactive
Good work culture.

I was able to translate my educational experience into practical problem solving working with one of the leaders in electromagnetic computational analysis. I highly recommend doing research at the University of Colorado Denver. It has strengthened my connection to the school and the staff at CU Denver.
I enjoyed working for the Univ of CO. I felt that the university supported my effort in my job and provided solid benefits. I would work here again. Thanks.

My work day starts with checking the canvas account and keep the students updated with their course curriculum and help them set up their tasks every week, I learned the most important thing to communicate with C level people.
Fun to work on campus. As a customer service person, I enjoyed working as a Lab advisor. I teach Electronics I to BS students which help me brush up some basics too.

This is a place that has provided me with a place to use my skills while challenging me to become a better professional and person.  I appreciate the people I work with and the culture of the workplace.
Got to mess around with a bunch of equipment or events or productions. Learned A LOT. Got to also manage equipment and learn how to properly take care of said equipment.
Excellent school with amazing teachers. Would go back in a heartbeat if I could. Learn more than you could ever imagine and then some. Would recommend to anybody.

The University of Colorado overall is a great place to work.  The staff and faculty are always a pleasure to work with.  The research work environment is very relaxed and laid back.  However, many positions are grant funded.  This doesn't allow for security in regards to long term employment.  Also, compensation is not as competitive as other organizations and could be improved to adjust for the increase in the cost of living in the Denver metro area.

There was always work to do when I came in, but something new would come up out of nowhere and it was possible we would have to stop due to some unknown reason with another person in charge. At one point my supervisor moved to another job, and left myself and my co-workers without any sort of supervisor and no guiding information on how to proceed.

Fairly easy work, but can get incredibly busy at times. There are times where I am challenged but unfortunately there's not enough of those opportunities to really show off my skills. Room for advancement is hard to come by. I've learned a lot about inventory management and purchasing procedures.
As with any graduate position you work many hours until the work is done.  It will depend on your mentor and project.  The hours will really depend on the project
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.

At the University of Colorado Denver, I was able to learn important life skills why developing and nurturing younger/ newer students. This environment was based around education and each students pursuance if knowledge. Leadership, professionalism and support is what this job was based on.

As a student going to CU Denver, this job was perfect for me. The management understood that I had to worry about passing my classes, on top of excelling at my job, so I was allowed to study and finish homework assignments as long as I did my job. If I wanted to learn anything in the tech space, I was able to communicate with the tech lead for resources to read and/or projects to complete.
I am a Independent Contractor with the University of Colorado. I conduct all of my work in California and communicate with Colorado when needed. My experience has been a pretty positive one.

A typical workday includes cell culture, DNA manipulation, seminar attendance, biochemical assays, and accurate record keeping. I am constantly learning new techniques, assays, and research from peers. The management provides great opportunities and welcomes new ideas. The work atmosphere is fun and exciting. The hardest part of the job is explaining unexpected results and formulating new hypothesis. The most enjoyable part of the job other than performing bench work is acceptance of a manuscript by a journal.

It is an educational space with deal plenty of new students and young generation. You need to update your knowledge base to work here. I believe working here is fine if you can adopt with the time and hard work.
There is a constant stat of being challenged which is something I thrive on. Co-works were professional and respectful. Wish the team had move input on how to better solve problems.
Very fun place to work. Guaranteed shifts. Educational support was phenomenal. Very few weekends and time to do work per MD request. Fulfilling work environment. Great for those willing to learb
Have a great team. From management to staff they work hand and hand. Pay could ne better but other than that it's a phenomenal company to work for. Meeting patients and new provider are a plus also.

University Hospital is a great environment to work in and I'm pretty sure and it teaches you a lot and you do get trained and all times pretty sure it's great people to work for and I know they teaches you multitask things to do make beds bathrooms trash it's it's a lot bio everything else it's a lot to
Allows time and funding for educational advancement ,one of the best compensations in the industry.

I went to Graduate School at UC Boulder and got a first rate education in Theatre Studies.  They gave me my first tastes of teaching in the field.  I wish they had prepared me better for career development.  Then, UC Denver gave me some opportunities to teach.  I already filled out a review for UC Denver.  Your fields may be screwy.

Met great people trying to obtain their degrees. Very flexible job and decent pay. Pay was based on work-study requirements therefore it might be applicable solely to individuals that receive work-study unless stated as hourly.
Good place to work with various opportunities for advancement and, lots of training, and good communication. Many different departments with opportunities for different levels of education.
Students are encouraged to be mindful of their peers. The Student Government supports all students on campus by addressing student concerns with administration.
Love the job, but had to move for schooling needs. Learned skills such as communication, learning, time management and bettering myself into working hard and resiliently.

By far, working at the University of Colorado was the most rewarding and satisfying job that I've ever had in my career.  The physicians were great clinicians, researchers and many have become well-respected administrators in their respective fields.  It was exciting to read the latest research accomplishments and advancements in the treatment and eradication of certain diseases and conditions.
Great place to work and learn. The benefits packages for students are non-existent, but the experience is very valuable. Great professors, peers and environment.

It is a very typical day for a teacher to attend his office hours. I learned a lot from teaching throughout the past years. I am pretty much the boss of myself. I just like to be on time, so my real boss has never said anything to me. We are sort of friends. I do not think there is nothing can be considered to be hard for this job. I did have fun with students, especially when it comes to the way that they do their home works, they basically listen to what did I say, and apply it to the assignments.
Too many managers in too many meetings to try to make decisions.  Need to streamline organizational structure.

I worked with the Pre-Collegite program at UCCS which helped first generation college students who were still in high school, get a head start and get some college credits over the summer. I was fun working with the students from all different high schools and working with the staff on campus.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.

As a member of the financial aid and scholarships office, I learned a lot in the years that I worked in the office. When my supervisor left, shortly after I was able to find a position working with children more, but the office itself was very welcoming and supportive of my learning while I was there.
already reviewed on previous page.  I would and do recommend this employer frequently as they have so many opportunities for advancement and to move about to gain different experiences.
I enjoyed teaching the classes assigned to me. My schedule allowed me to balance life and work. I was able to continue studying on my own and I was also able to enroll in classes .

University of Colorado Denver school was good for being able to balance a school and work schedule, however, the environment is very poor. They do not value their workers and are unwilling to pay people what they deserve.
They taught me a lot of necessary skills in order to strive for higher level positions. I learned many communication and leadership skills that are necessary for professional work life.
A good way to get involved on campus and to also gain experience for your future career. Staff was helpful and the kids were motivated. A great experience overall.

The hospital is a good place to work the negative reviews just come from the department I worked in. Our manager was her way or the highway. I did love the comradery between the nurses and all other staff. Overall I would work there again but on another floor. The benefits are good and they also give you a pension which is very nice.
It was a great learning experience and was able to expand my skill set. I also enjoyed my co-workers and working in a learning environment. There were also plenty of learning opportunities.
Your experience depends on your employer and your drive.                                  Even though it's a university system, it's still a business.

Non-faculty personnel are responsible for own identification and pursuit of professional development. High racial and gender bias across campus, including for students. Very few person's of color / women of color in roles of high responsibility or leadership; minimal respect for the front line / worker-bee staff; high interest in doing more with less at the expense of personnel.
Good place to work with the professor over some research work. I was working with the civil department for creating an application for doing some research.
Scheduling- As a college student they work with me

The culture of the workplace was one that was very friendly where everyone was willing to help you if you needed it. Also everyone I met there was very driven and passionate about a certain topic and it was fun and interesting learning about their projects as I worked on mine.

Great place! Great medical school! Nice location.I have been working for this school for almost 15 years. I feel like it's a home for me. I want to change my career for some special reasons, not because I don't like it anymore.
Depending on department it is hard but rewarding work. Working it the GME Office is one of the highlights in my professional career.  Would recommend it to any one.
Your experience in the CU School of Medicine will depend on where you work, but their Department of Family Medicine is one of the best in the country.
At the University of Colorado, you have the best staff possible. Everyone is well organized and professional in every sense. Rich in many diverse cultures.

Would manage lawns, take care of equipment, and enjoy the scenic views that Boulder has to offer. Arrive at work 7am daily, work till 1140 and break for a forty minute lunch then get back to work. Each day had a specific job that would be focused on. This was simply because lawns, bushes and landscapes grow quickly.
A typical day as a TA involving tutoring students and entering grades. I enjoyed tutoring and reviewing the exams for the students. The students love hearing stories from those in the field.
UCCS is a good place to work.  The benefits are great.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
One of my favorite jobs by far. They are fun, innovative, educational, and diverse. I would highly recommend Center for Advancing Professional Excellence.
Frustrated with the way the culture and the system is at the moment. Many people working here feel the same way. Pay low comparable to similar positions.

I found my particular position enthralling and valuable work. However, the supervisor and physician I worked with were abrasive, inconsiderate, and unwilling to instruct me with useful information. I was constantly being told to accomplish more than was possible and denied the necessary tools to complete tasks. Ethical considerations I felt were necessary were repeatedly ignored delaying progress or requiring me to complete tasks I was not comfortable with. I was given no opportunity for advancement, but asked to complete supervisor and leadership roles without compensation. Ultimately a lack of defined procedures for using employee benefits and a hostile work environment lead to a loss of will to work in an at will position. Do not take a position with this employer without clearly defined expectations and an ability to refuse additional requirements repeatedly in the work place.
Great benefits but limited opportunity for growth. The management is in disarray and often times does not have clear directives or expectations.

I was surrounded by faculty members who were influential in my career path and provided me with the resources to learn more about geography and to succeed as a student.  My coworkers and supervisors were professional and fun to work with.  Whenever I had completed my work tasks I was free to do my homework.

Everyone is very supportive and all resources needed to complete assignments were provided. The management team are willing and able to teach any new skills the job requires. This is a self schedule employment in which I was able to manage my time and work while attending school. The job allowed me to learn the arts of 3D modeling and online database management enabling me to grow as a creative researcher.

I taught lab of UCCS. I learned how to build labs, and interact with students. The professor that I worked for was extremely helpful. The work place was good. The hardest part was grading all of the papers.
This is a great system to work for and improvement continue to be made that benefit both patients and employees. The system have a vast amount of resources that assist in providing outstanding care.

This job pays well for a student employment opportunity, but the upper management doesn't understand the job. During the time I worked there there were 3 managers whom quite, and the new one that were brought in had no experience. While they tried, they expected things from the department that could not of been delivered by untrained student employees.

Working as a teaching assistant required communication and coordination of my schedule with the Professor on a weekly basis. It also required working independently and asking the appropriate questions to grade assignments using a grading rubric. I had to self monitor time management and coordinate pick up and dropping off of assignments with business services. The independence was the most attractive attribute of the job and the only downside was receiving a text to pick up assignments after I made a six block walk to the car.

My day begins with preparing the operating room suite for the days cases.  I enjoy using my skills to create the best environment for my patients.  I then meet my first patient of the day, this is where I get a few minutes to have someone trust me with their life.  Next, we are off to the operating room for surgery.
Excellent midwife practice.  Enjoyed working relationships with midwives, nurses, other providers.  Multicultural, multilingual patients.
The University of Colorado has provided a fun and productive work environment during the completion of my PhD in Computational Bioscience. Colorado also has a lot to offer.

Outstanding location, beautiful campus and great staff. This is an excellent university to work for. Typical day is 8am to 4pm. I teach class three times a week and the requirements are not to strenuous.

I have only worked in the capacity of a grader and now research assistant. It is nice environment to work, everybody is willing to collaborate with you to get work done and also, there are a lot of social activities organized amongst the staffs that brings about togetherness.
ARTS is an agency that is significantly needed in today's society. As a clinical worker, ARTS provided many opportunities to learn and grow.
Worked as a grader and tutor in Engineering Learning Center. Pay wasn't great, but it was a good review of engineering curriculum. Very willing to schedule around other obligations.

It's an exciting environment with many learning options. The teaching hospital setting means that treatments are cutting edge and evidence based. Physicians are dedicated and excellent at what they do. Working with the pediatric population is very rewarding.

Great coworkers and management. Compatible with school schedule (school comes first with boss). Repetitive but new experiences everyday as well. Relaxed and friendly atmosphere. Secluded and independent work style. Customer service through phone and email. Helping students in the orientation process.

A very diverse employment experience, you are constantly learning despite working for the educational. All employees are working and caring for the students. Everyone is friendly and helpful, which is how it should be.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
The work and schedule is flexible, the co-workers are fun to work with and the work environment enables you work long period with being bored.
-Event Planning
I am enjoying working at the UCCS Family Development Center. My employers have worked with my school schedule and are very kind an understanding. I have great bosses.
I learned a lot from my bosses there and it was always a very pleasant work environment. Mostly the work I did was autonomous and I rarely got assistance from others unless I asked.

Sophisticated institute with advanced research, technology, and networking. Strong collaborations between departments of the university. Not well compensated for the challenging and long hours of work.
Great place to work but hard to get on as full time. I work 8-5 with holidays off. Management is pleasant and my co-workers are friendly.

I loved working at the University of Colorado Denver because of the amazing support I received. This was my first real job and I didn't have any experience working in a office. They trained me from the first day working. I now have 12 years of experience working as an Administrative Assistant.
Fun job because the team that you work with, learned so much about computers and technology and students working there.

Get to know many new people and best of all young students with ambitions. Make new friends. Learned to build good customer service. Get to work close with leaders. Co workers are nice. Hardest part of the job is having good management.
My job was enjoyable and it was made all the better by my great coworkers and a great boss. The location is amazing. Out of the colleges I have looked at the campus was the best out of them.

Good starting position for many students looking for a part time job while in college. Main duties were customer service in the Registrars Office, which included but not limited to enrollment verification for the students class schedule adjustments transcript verification and purchase.
I enjoy working there. Especially the People I work with.  We have a Great Team and it makes the Extreme Work loads seem easier to deal with. Overall its a Great Place to Work.
good benefits; good location; variety of jobs; doctors are good to work for; lots of different positions; healthcare opportunities; work for the health of children
Amazing place to work as an undergrad researcher.  Flexible hours, great staff, and quality support all around.  Hardest part is getting to my building and not paying an arm and a leg for parking.

Work in the Cancer Pavilion scheduling patients for MRI, CT, labs or doctor appointments. Request records as needed including pathology samples. Enter referrals and work with our authorization departments to request authorization as needed.

somewhat an ok place to work as a student worker, they are really flexible with student worker, i will recommend it to any student worker. but not great for a full time employee because of less pay but great benefit.
I was a graduate student teacher for six year at the University of Colorado at Boulder so I had to either be a course instructor or a teaching assistant while also working on my Ph.D. in Mathematics.

I worked for 16 years in the Help Desk and was treated like a child the manager micro managed would not allow for advancement and as soon as I went for my Masters she was threatened by my achievements.

Business School of UCD has specializations for the MSIS program and being into Business Intelligence specialization it offered me great experience in terms of knowledge, handson experinece on various BI tools which are in demand.

By far the most professional job that I could ever have. The professors treat you with dignity and respect and have super high expectations of you, which you should also have for yourself and its most definitely gives you a great learning curve. It pushes you to pursue something that you want to do, puts you in connections with great professors and gives you the opportunity to get to know them on a personal level. You get to struggle-bus it with other students who know your pain and struggles and you have the greatest bond with them and since theyre also doing research they're overachievers just like you and its great while you all nerd out about the same things.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.

Cu Police In Aurora has a backwards leadership around, the upper management is run by incompetent vindictive administrators. You will be treated badly and laid off without any real notice.  Low pay and terrible benefits. If you work here start looking and go to a real police department not a wanna be police department like CU Police in Aurora.
I worked as a student assistant part-time, I used to work remotely. I helped in development of new applications and support of existing applications.

The school gave me the opportunity of becoming a ISP student in 2014. During two years' stay in Aurora, I have all the support from my faculty members, classmates and staff members, which make me a knowledgeable and well prepared dental graduate for the U.S. market.
Provides a good, collaborative work environment for scientists.  Fantastic campus that allows for inter connectivity between scientists, doctors and other medical professionals.
In my time at EDS I was promoted 8 times proving that there was always room to grow.  Management helped each employee to get a career path and move up within the company.

spent 6 years working for the ucd campus started on grounds and worked my way to PMT2 for the HVAC dept most of my duties here were not the type one can do for very long without incident i was treated unfairly by ucd and the state when i had my first accident and dismissed most of the employees at that time felt the same so when i left so did a quite a few of my coworkers
They work their junior MD's extremely hard and do not offer job security beyond one year. Their salaries are not competitive.

I worked for CU Denver for many years. It was a great place in student affairs until a new vice chancellor came in and brought his own team in that has destroyed the culture. My colleagues and I were either fired or pushed out for no reason. It has created a hire level of stress for current employees, not knowing if they are next. The level of nepotism and cronyism is unbelievable. I loved the mission and taking care of students but the abusive way staff has been treated the past few years is unconscionable for higher education. Do not look for a job in student affairs. HR does not care, higher ups do not care.
my first internship during my bachelor's and worked hard learned basics and got habituated to work culture good management supervisor is encouraging .
Best Co-workers around! Typical day is very busy and hectic, always short staffed but always a great team to work with and always somehow get the job done!

The work required me to use SQL to analysis data, it was kind of difficult because I was not really familiar with SQL. But after a few times using SQL, it's getting easier and I can know how to manage it well.

Working at the University of Colorado was a great starting point to my career. I had a chance to network and work with influential professionals in my community who have also mentored me for future endeavors.
University of Colorado offers great benefits, large organization with room for advancement, great networking opportunity
My employment with the University of Colorado School of Medicine was invaluable and provided me marketable skills and knowledge
It is a very easy going atmosphere. the majority of the students are very pleasant to deal with. I like my bosses, I work with a great group of people.
Everything is perfect, great challenging job environment and enthusiastic colleagues.good work environment gained good research experience through this job

No one takes responsibility there. Instead of finding solutions to the MANY logistic and processing problems, everyone points the finger at someone else. The schools and colleges have too much influence in the leadership, and there's no consistent way of processing anything there.

UCH is a very great place to work they have good benefits and they do what they can to accommodate if you plan on going back to school. Neurology is the department I work in and I love the people I work with its just management that I have an issue with. There is to too much favoritism that goes in this clinic and I just don't think its fair or right.
Everyone has to start a career somewhere and this was a great place for me to grow. It was managed by wonderful people and they were excellent 10 stars for work life balance.
It is a beautiful University tucked away in the foothills with outstanding beauty.The staff,students and co workers were great to work for. I would recommend working there or attending school there.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
A typical day included advising students, speaking to professors on behalf of students, tutoring students, and providing students with a welcoming atmosphere.
Good place good people. Great facilities and location to work. Good collaborative environment. One stop shop for basic science and clinical research.

The University of Colorado employees about 30,000 people throughout it's many campuses.  I have had the opportunity to interact with many of its employees from administration, faculty, colleagues, etc. and have formed many great relationships because of this experience.
Running and coaching the UCCS club baseball team has been an absolute blast. I've enjoyed all of the players I've been so luck to play alongside for the past 2.5 years.

Great place to work unless you get one bad supervisor. lots of learning opportunities great benefits.  over all most management fair and have an understanding of what goes on in the facility.  A couple bad supervisors can make or break you there.
The staff are fabulous, as are the faculty.  Knowing you're part of the growth of students as they move into the future is quite satisfying.

This is my first job in USA, my boss and my co-worker are very kind, we have a good relationship and communication. My job is support and assist students to deal with computer problems, and also maintained computers and laptops. I learned a lot of computer skills, I can also practice my speaking English.
Good place to work. Needs to have better preparation when an employee is quieting. Needs to address problems with employees better.

In my brief time with the university and with the School of Public Affairs, I'm pleased with the support I've received as an adjunct faculty member. Teaching part time has been a great outlet and I'm very grateful for the opportunity I have had to develop my skills and share my experience with future leaders.
Supportive environment with great people to work with.  My only complaint is the lack of organization as there was difficulty getting things done.
Being a research assistant was such a great experience because I was always learning. I was able to do many research projects that helped me in my work and in my classes.

If you work under the right people and in a position you like,  I can't see working for the university being any sort of bad. That said, you always will have to deal with the politics of campus life and other employees.
If it wasn't for my husband's out of state job transfer, I would have remained there until retirement. Miss it already. It will be a hard act to follow.
Its like any other academic setting. Experiences may vary depending on the direct supervisor. good location in Denver but away from the main campus in downtown
