The university was very understanding of going to school and working. They allowed me to have a flexible schedule to be able to work and continue my degree.

Registered and scheduled patients appointment, answered phones, scanned documents, verified medical insurance. Learned a lot about Physical Therapy. Management and co-workers were great. There was really anything hard about the job. Best part of the job were my co-workers.
very friendly and great work-ethic place. all kinds of ethnic group, age, work experienced people working in harmony. great medical and 401k benefits.

No matter which area of campus I worked for, the experience has always been incredible. Whether it was the people or what I was learning to do, I always felt as though my interests were being fostered.
I loved the culture at CU. It is a fantastically collaborative place driven by the passions of scientists and reaching forward to tackle the problems of the 21st century.

Co-workers are friendly and understanding absolutely depending on your department and position.  Within each main department are sub-departments that are often "clicky".  This may lead to poor management.  Again, depending on the department, the staff and faculty usually gets along however there's a sense of egotistical attitudes roaming the campus due faculty's experience and education.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.

A typical day at work as a Resident Assistant is constantly busy. Residents may call or send a text message at any time and one must respond accordginly to situation. One is on call and works the front desk several times throughout the semester. Training is performed two weeks before the semester to ensure one is responding accordingly to crisis situations.

The benefits and pay are all great (except for PTO- the PTO policy is not good as you have one bank for everything- holidays, sick, vacation etc). Other than that, a good place to get in and stay- lots of people transfer around when they get bored or want to move up the ladder.
Good benefits with reimbursement for continuing education and certifications. Opportunities for working inpatient and outpatient settings.

Assisting physicians and principal investigators on NIH-funded research studies investigating neurological disorders affecting adults and pediatric populations including Multiple Sclerosis, TIA/Stroke, Parkinson’s Disease, and Pediatric Demyelinating diseases
Student in the pediatric nurse practitioner program. Wonderful program though unorganized at times due to seasons of transition.

The College of Arts and Media at UCD provided me with the skills I need to be a successful artists. I had great professors who not only taught, but gave me advice and guidance on what I need to do to get a job in the art world.
It is a RA position, so the key point is who your supervisor is. The people around are very nice and helpful. Working time is flexible, as long as you got your job done.

In a typical day, i will log onto the phones and then get the system ready to help students. I will then start by processing forms like student enrollments, transcripts and enrollment verification.After that, i will wait for students to come with questions or inquiries,
This place is very good to work if you are in to serious studies. The library is a good source various kinds of books. I liked it here.
I have learned plenty while working from CU Denver. I have worked in multiple offices and have continuously loved my coworkers and my projects.
Working for the University of Colorado Colorado Springs (UCCS) Bookstore has been a wonderful experience.  Having work and classes so close together helped me manage my time/schedule very wisely.
Unique environment, many pros and cons associated with the challenges of higher education and a range of personalities in the workplace.

Worst place ever worked, they say work life balance, but only say that. Very intrusive into the way you live. Want in your house your bedroom and into your family life. They are very good at advancing the inept, and very much mid management heavy. Supervisors cant be trusted.

DFS is interesting The Sous Chef  is amazing but is overloaded by the idiot Executive Chef who does jack. The food is Meh and the manager at the lodge is garbage. The student workers are great and love working with them but it makes me angry to see them mistreated by the lodge manager. there is little to no communication even though they whine about it all the time. The only three managers I respect are the Sous Chef, The Director(usually) and the Residential Dining manager at Roaring fork (Dining center).
I love working with the students. Clinical classes are held at Penrose hospital. Hardest part of the job is parking. Best part is the students.

I have had the pleasure of being both a TA and research assistant and would say that UCDenver both downtown and out at the Anschutz Campus want to develop students and others for their future. I have learned a lot about research and teaching, pedagogy and theory. It would be a place that I would look for possible future positions.
Working at the UCCS Bookstore was a huge blessing, given the ability to both go to school and work on the same campus.  The hours were flexible and the management worked very well with students.
Pros:
Service brought amazing opportunities both while serving and once I got out. Proud to have served the people of this county.
I enjoy working at The University of Colorado Hospital.  I also enjoy the different cluture diversity here at the University of Colorado Hospital.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.

Working at the University of Colorado is a very exciting and learning experience. There is always something new to learn and the work, the faculty and researchers do is important, fascinating and it is a true honor being a part of a great institution.
User friendly environment,cooperative coworkers. Managing staff is really good. working in team has always been fun.
worked long hours in front of the computers testing websites for the university, making sure they worked before the became public to the students.
There are a lot of good things about the university that could be great. They do not have any major competion so seem to lack a commitment to excellence or value of their people.

Daily tasks included checking in and out film equipment, transfer film to digital media, and providing input about equipment to the vast majority of the student body. Cameras ranged from 8mm to HD so I had to be knowledgeable for all questions that were asked. I was the go to employee that students would direct their editing questions to.

Covered tuition plus a stipend in return for instructor effort. A very good deal and extremely fun due to energetic students and good advisorship. Classes get hectic when teaching but learning to manage groups is key to the job experience.
Great management and overall lots of learning opportunities. As a student employee, it was a great step into the professional world.

Productive workplace with great facilities allowing for a lot of hands on experience.  Labs were plentiful allowing experience to be gained with multiple chemistry techniques and equipment.  Labs were difficult but allowed for extensive knowledge to be developed.
On a typical day I would take care of laboratory animals. Closely following regulations, and working with researchers as needed.
Amazing cell culture facility with the best cell culture facilitator anywhere. All equipment is the best out there and techniques are groundbreaking.
Good start out job to balance with school and life. Flexible hours and days to help manage student life. Also easy going job with decent pay.

Best atmospheric research in the State of New York.  In some areas it is sub par.  The future of this institution is questionable providing that state funding will not be continued.  Overall the institution is too small to warrant independent existence.  It should be merged with the SUNY's Atmospheric Science Dept.
The employees and staff are all wonderful people.  The students are interested and hard working for the most part. I enjoyed teaching here.
Days vary. Sometimes it's slow. Sometimes it's very busy.

Great working enviroment, amazing co-workers, good Benefits as full-time employees, i feel that management has forgotten why they became healthcare workers and focus too much on managment duties and not enough on patient care. A typical work day is busy and a fast moving pace,

I loved the work environment, but the contract nature of the business did not allow for a stability of a continued job at the campus.  The contract is renewed each year and from one year to the next there is no way of knowing if there was a position that would remain open.
A typical day at work was helping students with their program information, answering phones, keeping Americorp records.
I was able to get the necessary leadership and life skills working for CU. I also worked in a good culture and had a boss that looked out for my professional path.

I'm at the Emergency Room at 7am. A person never knows how a day will unfold. There is 70 percent down time and 30 percent adrenaline when we,  as a team,  are saving a life. There are many joyful moments. A few sorrow filled times as well. There are two sides to every coin. The hardest part of the job is getting a patients identity and salient patient information correct under extreme pressure.
Working as research assistant. The professors are friendly and task oriented. Learning lot of technical skills from the professors.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
It was a great place to work while in college. Being able to keep up on my math skills while helping others increase their own.
On the oncology unit, there are a lot of younger nurses so the environment is more lively than a lot of other units.They are very close-knit on the units and the drama is kept to a minimum
Working with the families and children are the best. Teaching and watching the kids grow is a wonderful experience. There is a lot of training involved but it is well worth it.
Great way to strengthen communication, educational, multi-tasking, and teamwork skills. Learned a lot about how things function in the classroom.

I liked working here. I was not under a ton of supervision. I just had to make sure that I got the work that I was given done in a timely manner. I had no co-workers. I worked amongst the professors in the Department of Sociology.

The job was very simple once you learned the everything. It had the benefit of providing students with the opportunity to work in the chemistry departmentl. The primary duties included assisting the laboratory coordinator (and certain faculty members) set up/restock labs, synthesize solutions for various chemistry courses, and regulate the stockrooms supplies and chemicals.

Portraying different cases and at the same time helping the medical students at the University of Colorado School of Medicine was great. I have learned many things about each portrayal and also given feed back to students to do better when using interpreters or working with Spanish-Speaking patients. Our CAPE group was diverse and fun to work with!

I loved working as an undergraduate research assistant while going to school full-time at CU/ Boulder.  I learned so much more in just a few hours per week than even the students in classroom labs learned, and really found my passion working in a laboratory there.
Work with Supervisor on as need basis,
I love working here. I love the people that I work with. I have never had a problem with any coworkers or management. Everyone is very helpful if there is a problem.
Working here was a great experience that taught me a lot about the office and all types of office work. It was a little low paying, but other than that the work was great.

I loved everyone I worked with and all the students I got to teach. Many work days ended with a ton of laughs. Annette was a great manager, but needed to be a bit more accessible and it would have been nice if she took our classes more.

I teach a variety of subjects, including college algebra, trigonometry, math for liberal art majors, polynomial and engineering calculus, and differential equations.  I grade papers, administer exams and conduct office hours to offer private assistance to students.  I care deeply about my students and enjoy seeing many succeed and learning much after working hard.

the day starts with checking for medical items needed per floor in a system called axium! I have learned purchasing in and out, the best part of the day is when helping a student or doctor get the things they need to get through the day so they can better serve the patients
I enjoy being employed by the University of Colorado Denver. The work is challenging and the pay and benefits are competitive.
There are many opportunities at the University. One can transfer to another position at one of the three campuses, Boulder, Anschutz and Downtown Denver, and retain the very reasonable benefits.
sit all day staring at a computer with little to no breaks.  no talking and your timed on how fast you can get work completed.
Great professors and engaging atmosphere. I completed multiple research studies here and highly value my time spent with this university.

Working on campus at UCCS has not only provided me with a flexible work environment, but has allowed me to work with a team that is understanding and conscientious of my scheduling and academic needs.

Nice team at work , the chair dprt is a wonderful person. I like when we meet for a lunch and share things together, I like also when my chair dprt email me asking how things going and when everyone cares about each other !
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.
Able to excel at the following in under one year:
A good overall work environment. The staff is nice and the managers are too. Generally really care about the patients.
Demeaning and de-moralizing attitude from leadership.
Higher Education is a great place to work and watch as student grow and accomplish their goals, it is amazing.
Great employer! Gained clerical experience and was surrounded by helpful and insightful individuals.

A typical day at work is amazing. There are so many activities and projects to work on. Through the projects assigned to me, I have learned so much abut data entry, data collection and data validation. My co-workers are awesome! They have such an attitude to work that what it does is to elevate you to your max potential.

I enjoyed being a contractor for this organization that had much to offer students until the Board of Regents legislation impacted programs for minority students, like the pre-collegiate development program. Funding was not allocated compatible to programs at other system colleges.

The University of Colorado Colorado Springs is a great place to work, with a ton of great people, the majority of whom are willing to do whatever it takes to encourage you to move ahead and grow, personally, educationally, and professionally.

This was a fantastic program! It instills in its graduates the ability to communicate clearly, collaborate fairly, listen carefully to all stake holders and work in the best interest of the overall social good.
If funding is strong, you get a job and can keep it. When funding fails, you lose your job. That is all.

Teacher candidates show professionalism while educating students. Teacher candidates responsibilities range from preparing lesson plans that coincide with Colorado Academic Standards while providing a safe and inclusive environment in which student can learn. Daily activities range greatly throughout the course of a day from hallway monitoring, conflict resolution, curriculum development, instruction, and maintaining order in a classroom. The most difficult part of the job was limited time during the endoctrination process.
Worked with students on academic probation. Assisted with paperwork, tracked progress, database/spreadsheet use, etc.  Challenging and rewarding. Saw many students overcome hurdles.
Typical work day:
There is some amazing research happening on this campus, as well as a lot of brilliant people.

There is nothing better for a degree seeking student then to work in the library, it is the heart of information. Learning how to use the data bases, how to effectively make them mine, put me at the top of my game when it came to being ready for a project. It also gave me the skills to share and train other students how to use the library. Through this I met many people from all over the world, work with them on a personal basis, and in turn learn about their world. And didI I mention it was fast paced?
excellent place to work, environment conducive to continued learning
Fun work environment and get to connect with several people across the campus.
Wonderful hospital with great staff of doctors and nurses.

Meet some nice people , great  leaning experience , As a transponder you get to help people  that really needs it. And the people  i helped was very thankful .. Gusts services (outpatient) Very good working crew
It is a good school with caring faculty and knowledgeable staff.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.

As a graduate student, I worked as a research intern in 4 different immunology labs. As an intern, I learned to manage my time, organize my experiments by priority, and present data to critical crowd. This was a self-motivating job; nobody looked over me to make sure I was working and I was free to decide when and how hard I worked. I participated in 4 research projects, in which 2 generated usable data, and 1 generated publishable data. The hardest part was juggling the expectations of my lecture courses, while still producing high-quality data. I loved being able to go at my own pace, as I tend to be a very quick learner and want to move on to the next thing right away!

A typical day at work was pleasant.  The supervisor and management as well as co-workers were very cordial, professional and respectful.  Learned about the administration of the chancellor and associate chancellor and their specific duties. I was given the opportunity to learn more about the organizational structure and management.  The hardest part of the job is the politics and how one's job can be affected by it.  The most enjoyable part of the job in working at the University level is that there is so much to learn from a co-worker, a supervisor and faculty.  Just being surrounded by actual teachers is wonderful.  For one thing I have to say, you never stop learning.... and you learn something new each day, which is part of growing, changing and a continuous learning process.
Great place to attend school.  Amazing professors and great learning environment.
Worked in clinical research with a dynamic team. Was a wonderful growing experience and truly loved my 6 years.
In my opinion, this organization is not student-centric is more about their bottom line
I was a graduate assistant in the Economics department. I enjoyed my work.
The workplace pushes its employees to grow, both professionally and ethically.
Great place to work. Flexible with your schedule. Supervisors care about your development as an employee.
Great hospital to work at with high patient flow and good pay/benefits.

There is a very well established "good ole' boys" system at this company which is not always on the up and up.  I have tried to bring this to the attention of the Compliance Department and the CCO Christine Newgren is a joke.  She does not understand Compliance issues and supports unethical behavior.  I did get intouch with a couple of other people in the Compliance Office that understood and were will to help but then I was told that Christine had elimnated thier positions.  The eithical behavior comes from how patients are charged, to what we do when we know there is an issue (in this case ignor it),
Very busy positive learning environment. I am managing 35 nurses who are all professional and eager to learn. We have new residents that always leads to more learning.
Great school; the "college" scene is absent.
Leadership does not exist.  It's all about how long someone has been there.
I loved my time working at UCH. By far the best management, organization and culture.
Great place to work with amazing views of Pikes Peak! Great people, great students, great environment with room for growth

Valued need for the community. Staff worked well together until management change. Great teamwork,  negative aspects due to changes, required excessive documentation which affected quality of service to clientele and eventual closure of Grant renewal
College athletic department with varying degree of satisfaction along with frustration. High level of success expected but not always supported.
A great job that easily balances school and work.  Good job to learn skills related to printing and work on helping others with problems.

What I love most about the University of Colorado Anschutz medical campus was that everyone cared so much about the research they did. It inspired me to be the best that I can. I learned many different laboratory techniques and the science behind it. More importantly, I learned how the results related to scientific concepts, which I found highly enjoyable.
needed more money but very good place to work, very friendly environment, great people.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.

I loved working for UCCS in the Science Department. I worked with a variety of other tutors in a relaxed environment that was very conducive to learning, was able to work around my class schedule. The hardest part of the job was keeping up with the various different classes I was tutoring for while also managing my own classwork, and the most enjoyable part of the job was the aspect of teaching and helping other students to succeed.
I appreciate UCH for their teaching style . The people are great and it is a very good place to work for.

This was a great first job while attending school as a student worker. The staff is helpful and knowledgeable in all areas of the job. Training and learning all aspects of the job happened on a daily basis. It was challenging at times but also gave a good balance so it was not to stressful.
Loved my job, great place to work.  Learn something new every day.

a typical day was working with adolescents that already had a few strikes against them in life, our job was to guide them and support the concept that there was light at the end of the dark tunnel they were stuck in
•	Kept contact information of past LAEF scholarship recipients
University of Colorado is a great place to work. Friendly, helpful people everywhere. Located in a growing metropolis.

The employees are wonderful.  However, there is a division amoung the sub departments.  The division is mainly fueled by the management.  When the employees work as a team or individually, many great things happen.  However, when one department handles its meetings the feeling of comradery leaves and sense of self-entitlement emerges.  Also, the lower paid employees often feel left out by some other employees due to their status.
Great place to learn about addiction medicine

As a work-study student position it was extremely flexible around my school schedule. I was able to learn great skills in managing an online database, customer service and support, and time management along with project management.

A typical day includes posting batch transactions to the general ledger.  Assisting fund managers with issues and training them to read the accounting statements.  Other tasks include various reconciliations and month end tasks.
Excellent graduate program in Urban and Regional Planning
Got to apply my knowledge here at the offices using what I learned in class. A very friendly workplace and connection with the people there are very professional.

A typical day consists of working the front desk, making appointments with students and their academic advisers, answering phones, filing, mailing, organizing and cleaning. I was also in charge of opening and closing the office, building inspections for safety, clear fire exits and repairs needed. I was able to help instructors, making copies and doing other tasks. I also delivered mail and FCQ's to them. I was able to help fellow students register and choose classes needed to graduate. I set up rooms for lectures and other events and I helped with Graduations. My co-workers were other students and friends, we all worked different shifts. My supervisor and I got along very well. I learned much about the College of Architecture and Planning. I enjoyed my interaction with students, staff, professors and instructors.

I worked within a residential housing facility for previous felony offenders with addiction issues called Peer I.  I got to know EVERYONE in my house and know their stories...it was wonderful! And so were my peers.
Get to work with other students in a relaxed atmosphere.  Flexible with scheduling and able to take time off.  Easily able to be promoted, awesome supervisors.

My supervisor was unreliable, dishonest, and manipulative. The work was very demanding, and the pay was horrible. One could only advance if someone left a position at a higher level, which is very demotivating. It facilitates an environment of distrust and competition between coworkers.

Working for the state offers great benefits but that is about all. I worked there for 5 years and never received one raise not even a cost of living raise. Also, the only way to get promoted or move around is if you know the right person. I watched my manager promote and give raises to only people she liked and left the rest of her employees out. I feel this was bad business and it proved me right when all of our positions were dissolved.
I held a position of a Teacher's Assistant twice for freshmen engineering projects class.

I loved my job, I had a passion for it. I went to school to become a pharmacy technician and wanted to work in the hospital. my dream came true until the work place became a nightmare. I was being harassed by my fellow coworkers and my manager as well. I went to the manager to inform her that I was being harassed but nothing was being done. I felt very uncomfortable going to the manager as well because she didn't like me and she brought my personal issues to work when I told her in confidence.
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.

Large academic institutions operate as a sink or swim environment. It can be difficult to stand out as a researcher. I witnessed some of the struggles with funding and recruitment for studies. The benefit of this work and knowing that the study can make a positive impact on systems in place related to the research. Through research, medical treatments and other interventions can be evaluated for the studied population.
Level II trauma center with a diverse group of patients. Mainly worked in Emergency room. Can be overwhelming at times.
Love being a part of the team. Everyone is always helpful and nice.

A typical day at work required catching up on emails in the morning which basically determined my day, however, my day could consist of making travel arrangements to coordinating moves to ensuring applications had accurate materials.  I also greeted and answered queries from other university programs and students.  Using my daily planner and Google calendar, I planned my daily/weekly tasks.
A collaborative work environment in which independence and ingenuity is encouraged.
The people I worked with were very friendly and willing to be a team player.
Nice place. Very productive. Downtown campus, nice location.

Great year. Loved the administration. I worked as a preliminary general surgery intern. The people were great and I am still in contact with them. Most of them are helpful and want you to succeed. Ancillary staff was fantastic to work with. Work days were long as usual for this type of job. Learning was facilitated well by all superiors and most peers.
Working at Colorado Genetics lab is very rewarding and a very cahllenging job.

As an intern in the microbiology department I was encouraged to think independently. Initially I was instructed by my supervisor then as the internship progressed, I was given more credit to work on my own project. When I hit a dead end in my research, I had advice on where to go from there, and aid in interpretation of tests.

I meet with fauculty on a regular basis to identify patients who have the giving capacity to give over 25k and up. They work with me on identifying patients who have expressed intrest in knowing about their research. I find ways to reach out to the patients through cold calls, direct mail or email and try to secure face to face meetings. At that point I work hard to cultivate those potential prospects by taking them to lunch, providing them with materials, tours, etc. Once that relationship has been established it is appropriate to talk about fundraising and money with the prospect. My faculty and I strategize the appropriate dollar amount to ask the patient and come up with a proposal that makes sense and meets the patients needs. Once the patient decides to make a gift it is up to me to continiue to steward the donor and make sure they are updated on what their money is being used for.  I really enjoy working face to face with patients and getting to know why they are grateful patients and what drives them to support their doctors research. The hardest part of my job is identifying the right donor. You could make 15 cold calls and finally get a face to face meeitng with one, but it is still not guarenteed that they are interested in supporting medical research.
A productive place which requires a lot of trial and errors to get appropriate data. Fast paced and on the go environment.

During the summer of 2012 I worked as a student research assistant in the Boulder Creek Critical Zone Observatory.  My responsibilities involved using EM-31 and DC Resistivity surveying techniques to map out the changes in conductivity of the upper fifty feet of the critical zone.  Once the data was layered onto a topographic map of the region, correlations could be made between conductivity and areas of high weathering.
Worked with competent Managers and Supervisors who were very professional and ensured productivity was high.
A good place for students to get involve and get ready for a real workforce afterwards.
Very professional on all aspects for working with head administration for the university.
This was a great place to work. Lots of down time, but was able to fill it with homework. If you can get a job here don't let it go.
Continually working as a team to improve individual and staff-wide knowledge base. A fun and supportive environment for educators.

Duties included development, characterization and utilization of analytical methods for the analysis of self assembled monolayers (SAMs) on electrode surfaces.  Developed and characterized novel electrochemical sensors for the detection of phenolic compounds.  Helped characterize new chemical sampling instrumentation with quantitative capillary GC analysis and a variety of electrochemical approaches. Responsible for installation, maintenance and calibration of HP 5890 GC system, as well as method development and quantitation of samples acquired from a number of agricultural materials
Got a lot of good experience talking with students in this position!
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.

If you are part of the classified staff (state) versus professional (university) you may have difficulty in getting promoted to the other level. I did not receive a raise the whole time I worked there because the state never had the funding. I enjoyed my job and the people I worked with, but being employee of the state was very difficult.
welcoming studying environment and i found most professors very helpful and kind, they are patient to explain any problems that the student might have, the location is good with nice weather

The most valuable aspect of my position is the foundation. We are busy due to handling accounts from all four campuses. This requires the constant revisiting of the University policies and procedures.

I learned how to coordinate the Alumni Board of Directors for the CU Denver campus. I learned how to keep a board motivated and productive. My team was small; only two others. We were a good team. I left because was promoted to the President's Office.

I loved working at CU. These folks are highly productive and highly motivated. Very team orientated and organized. The hardest part of this job was leaving. I learned how to support high level executives while remaining transparent for the public eye. I learned how to coordinate events and private dinners for donors to CU. I learned how to steward donors, as well.

I taught an undergraduate Psychology Research and Methods lab one day a week. Throughout the week I would creat lesson plans, meet with students for office hours, attend weekly TA meetings, and grade students' papers and other homework. I learned how to creat a lesson plan that was not only effective, but was interactive for my students. I also learned my own teaching strategies. The management and my other co-workers had a passion for teaching and we worked well together. The hardest part of the job was trying to balance being a full time graduate student and grading papers at the same time. The most enjoyable part of the job was getting to know my students and watch them grow throughout the semester.
Very fast pace environment; opportunity for challenge,communication with various individuals, wonderful learning experience with medical field.

This is not an institution that advocates higher education. Most of the executives in higher level positions were not educated at CU, nor do they advocate anyone that went to their school having a higher level position. I was a salaried employee expected to be on call 24/7, to come in at all hours, to perform tasks way above my skill level with little to no recognition and absolutely no overtime. My direct supervisor repeatedly took credit for projects and ideas that I initially had, only to continually be verbally abused by that same person and eventually fired. I went in with a higher educational background then the majority of people in my department (Masters level education from a top tier school) whereas the majority of those in my department held B.A.'s from online universities and had never actually attended a brick and mortar institution. I was told on my first day of work that my colleague (hired at the same level) had never actually read an entire book.
Great employer and very nice coworkers. Good culture and environment
Good Benefits and a large enterprise environment where you can learn a lot.
This is a large University, with over 40,000 technology users. It is a great place to learn how to work with many different types of technology.
good staff and good team work it was fun been there,good doctors over 30
Co-Workers were great Upper management was ok no real Issues, My office manager was great. and the benefits were great as well.
Helping students with computer issues, co-workers are always friendly, helping students learn the ins and outs of Microsoft products.
It really a wonderful experience to work with University of Colorado. I have ameliorated a lot at my work place by pursing my masters in Computer Science.
The staff and management are great to work with. My positions allows me to engage with students on a daily basis. They make the university and my department what it is. It is a very rewarding feild.

Daily visits 150 - 200/day, manage over 50 staff with a leadership team of four. I enjoy the Practice Manager role as it provides me the ability to manage the finances of the Practice, work closely with staff on projects while trying to improve the patient experience.
Work hours are very flexable
Great job for working around your class schedule. Good for building your customer service skills.

Managers manage to get big bucks for doing nothing. Classified employees receive unfair wages because all the funding is directed to coaches' monthly bonuses. Unproductive atmosphere - have you seen the show "The Office"?
My experience working at CU has been an incredibly rewarding and satisfying opportunity. I look forward to going to work every day and thrive on my interactions with colleagues.

Horrible experience working at the Orthodontic office poor management, The hardest part of the job is that you go above and beyond with co-workers and patients and still very unappreciated. The pay is horrible for what you do at this office. I would not recommend this to anyone. Turn over rate is bad....
Enjoyed working on downtown campus.Enjoyed the diversity. enjoyed most of the work load assigned.
Great Place to work. I never felt like I took my work home with me. I had as much job security as I could have with a Grant funded department.
This is a very positive environment to work in.

working with University of Co Hospital each Department we all worked well together. we would get together on each employee's birthday and bring different types of food for potlucks; our productivity we always worked together to complete our tasks. the pros of that position was it was always exciting to be there; the cons was there was no overtime the hardest part of the job.....there wasn't any. I I enjoy the Hospital setting. I would like something more where I can be challenged.

I worked as a library aide thru the University of Southern Colorado's work study program. I worked in the periodicals department where I would help gather various periodicals for customers research, I would re-file various periodicals, performed clerical duties which included typing correspondence, establishing ad maintaining a filing system for the periodical department, processed mail, prepared new periodicals for stock, phone operations, coping, collating and corresponding with customers.

Currently I am working as a part-time software developer, database developer and smartphone application developer at this job. I am really satisfied with the experience I got here. I have learned Android Application programming. I got a chance to work on Java Web Services.
This reinforced the technical details of the courses that I was teaching. This is very important to being able to apply the technology in the best way to solve a problem.
Great place to work. Can work according to the schedule which will be mostly from 8am to 2pm

A typical work day was often busy and relatively challenging. The staff was helpful to work with as I was new to the pharmacy industry. I was able to learn brand vs. generic prescription drugs, answer general questions for the guests, and also generate labels for the pharmacist and patient.
University of Colorado at Boulder has one of the greatest optics education program.
Processed applications and reviewed student documents for financial aid approval

Good place to work for contribution to client growth in Recovery and rewarding to see positive change with hard work and persistence. Administration contains to many biases and politics but the actual facility is great to work at everyday.
Learning is a daily objective.

I have had several jobs here, and I learned the importance of being able to balance and manage my time. Best thing is that some times your employer will have you do homework or assignments while on the clock.

a typical day at work is to come in clean the dirty side of the dispensary , dispurse instruments to the Dental students and to asst for morning class as well as cleaning instruments and setting up for afternoon class and do all over again. I am also am crosstrained in the oral surgery department ans the Emergancy dept.in that Depaart we provide nesseccary care as needed such as extractions, fillings or providing aftyer care and prescriptions formedication to pt as needed

Perform laboratory duties including Tissue Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining, H&E immunofluorescence and special stains, enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) assays, tissue processing, microtomy, tissue embedding, tissue grossing, tissue mounting in paraffin, and special tissue staining.

I have managed, maintained and supervised the Materials Laboratory for the University of Colorado Denver for two years. (1) Managing our Concrete Materials Laboratory (2) Purchase of new equipment and maintenance of old equipment (3) Assisting other graduate students in concrete related batching and testing (4) Writing of regular progress reports to the research sponsor (50+pages) (5) Being an unpaid teaching assistant to the Introduction to Structural Materials course using CDOT Structural Concrete Specifications to guide civil engineering students (6) Responsible for preparing the laboratory to be certified by the CDOT for Colorado Procedure 10–Standard Practice for Qualification of Testing Personnel and Laboratories. In 2010, the UCD–Concrete Materials Laboratory successfully passed an inspection performed by the CDOT Physical Properties group.

The University has a great mission and organization is to educate people however with all of the state budget cuts, morale has been lost and people are overworked. This results in students not receiving the proper service that they are paying for or just simply just get the run around.

Loved everything about this job. Pretty laid back environment, My co-workers were awesome, I was always busy. The most enjoyable part of the job was i got to use my IT skills and administrative skills which created my position with the university.

Immediate supervisor and co-workers were very supportive, team atmosphere and great place to work! Poor management & leadership, especially at the Board of Directors/CEO level. Upper management very slow to bring about changes and more focused on hiring more managers to lessen their workload rather than hiring much needed therapists and care coordinators.

Mission is wonderful. The clinicians truly care about the clients and want to help them get the care they need. Upper management is always looking for ways to improve processes. Truly genuine atmosphere of caring staff. For each other and outside of Mental Health Partners. True asset to the community.
Mental health partners is a great place to work. The staff is supportive and caring. I truly feel/felt comfortable and able to reach out for help. I always felt a sense of purpose working there.
I love a challenge and learning and I get to do it with some of the smartest, most caring and fun people I've ever worked with.  I love working at MHP.

Leadership is great and works hard to support staff.  You can really tell that everyone here is connected to the mission and to our clients.  Current leadership has worked to create a more supportive and inclusive culture.  The co-CEO's are great - very caring leaders who connect with staff at all levels and are open to feedback.  Communication is frequent and transparent.

Worked as a care specialist, felt burned out, and didn’t have the support. Staff treated care staff as hired help. The same staff that treated care staff poorly probably treat restaurant employees poorly.

Inconsistent management and a proclivity for gossip about coworkers and patients alike. A severe lack of compensation for highly-qualified positions and intentional ignorance towards internal problems (ones in which HR should be involved). I would not recommend working here if you are mentally ill.

Supervisor denied medical time and asked me to reschedule necessary Dr. appointments. Not all staff on team were treated equally. Lack of coverage on CARE team due to staff quitting. Supervisor micromanaged staff.

I have worked with Mental Health Partners for over 10 years and plan to stay for at least another 10.  Mental Health Partners allows me the structure and support I need to do my job while also allowing me atonomy to make it my own and be creative in the work I do with clients.  The best part of my job is getting to help facilitate change in families and clients.  The hardest part of my job is finding balance between seeing clients and managing state requirement for paperwork.

Every I've has each other's backs, we do good for the community, always growing and improving, even with Covid. Unlike other government run facilities who don't return phone calls and leave people to die of hunger because some stupid reason they lost SNAP or unwillingness to help. We do everything we can to help

I felt like I was not trusted to do my job, constantly micromanaged. Work load was not divided evenly amongst staff, was put in dangerous, unsanitary, and unsafe situations. It was difficult to take time off due to coverage and everyone quitting.

I have received the warmest welcoming in my career (20 yrs) in a wonderful, meaningful culture where employees live the culture the company promotes. Everyone I've met has a vested interest in my success and provides what I need to be successful and will ask how and what I may need. Could not ask for a better place to be during challenging times.

I have received the warmest welcoming in my career (20 yrs) in a wonderful, meaningful culture where employees live the culture the company promotes. Everyone I've met has a vested interest in my success and provides what I need to be successful and will ask how and what I may need. Could not ask for a better place to be during challenging times.

Unfortunately there is a lot of dysfunction, bordering on harassment. Great experience, as far as working with complex clients, but you are on your own with very little support. This will explain the rapid turnover of providers. Watch your back at this place if you choose to go for it.

overworked employees and not kept informed what is happening with the company.  The admin not upfront with employees who are not performing up to standards.  Not a fair system for improving performance.

There are many reasons why there is a high turnover rate here. The work environment was not safe, police were constantly called, lack of support from managers, and it was extremely difficult to schedule medical apts and use sick time. My work team was unsupportive. A coworker of mine told my team that someone must have hit me on my head or that I might have had a disability because “i was slow”. This was not true but extremely disappointing if these are the same staff that are interfacing with clients.

NOT a place to work if you yourself are mentally ill. They put up a false atmosphere of acceptance and “go-with-the-flow” management when the reality is more along the lines of hypocrisy and an extremely unclear vision of the future of the organization. Not to mention the amount of turnover in the past few years, the new management is no better than the old. The homeless and addict population that they claim to help and support are spoken about as “others,” “us versus them.” They treat workers as a means to an end and the hardest working, most public/client facing positions are paid and respected the least. Would not recommend, especially to people that actually care about the mentally ill and the mental health field

While the mission of MHP is amazing, serving a vulnerable, under served population of the indigent and/or chronically mentally ill, management cripples the wonderful work of the direct care clinical staff.
Need better CEO AND HIGHER UPS the company don’t have respect for hard workers. Company need more class and lessons on professional with dealing with people and mental health

I have worked for the typical corporate companies in my career. Working at a non-profit has been eye opening. If you seen and heard what i have been through this company and work experience is worthwhile . I love the chance to help people that are having severe challenges. Some young people who work here don't realize how lucky they are to work for a company that cares.

I thoroughly loved all that I did at mental health Partnerships. The participants are one-of-a-kind and they kept me going day to day. The only problem I had with working there is the lack of training that some of the managers received while being there. Although, my director was amazing he sometimes was laxed at what he allowed the certain managers to get away with. My only hope for the future is better training for management staff

Immediate supervisor and co-workers were very supportive, team atmosphere and great place to work! Poor management & leadership, especially at the Board of Directors/CEO level. Upper management very slow to bring about changes and more focused on hiring more managers to lessen their workload rather than hiring much needed therapists and care coordinators.

Well I have to say after 2 years of employment i am extremly discouraged.... We received email from CEO that there would be no raise this year. That's not it they will not be matching OUR contributions to our retirement package.So very sad so very sad. Also overall poor work culture and Absolutely NO CONSEQUENCES for poor work ethic. I am glad I realize I work for my character that have NONE.

Great meaningful work. Great coworkers. Not great money like any other nonprofit but usually you’re not in it for the money. Usually within a week if it doesn’t feel like work you’re in the right place

The people that I worked with were also kind and loving towards the community of patients that we worked with and also towards each other. My boss was always fair and kind and knowledgeable. One of the best work environments I ever have had the pleasure of working in

MHP functions like a monarchy in which a few powerful women are the Queens. The Queens have placed ineffectual white men in positions that only appear powerful, so they can do what they wish without interference.

I loved my time at MHP, l simply had to leave because l had a serious and life threatening illness. They were 100% supportive l chose to leave because they needed a person in there daily and l couldn't be

The staff at MHP are absolutely committed to the work they do in mental health. It is a great place to work where you will be appreciated for your contributions. However, it seemed that we were constantly trying to hire bilingual Therapists and the competitiion was very rough.

This organization was not big on listening to the needs of the work staff or providing salary increases, reviews or proper compensation.  I would not recommend this organization for someone either mid-level or advanced in their career.

Management was more concerned with pressuring clinical staff to meet unrealistic direct service expectations than employee satisfaction, retention or safety. This included encouraging us to schedule 10 clients/day or double-book clients.This impacted employee and client satisfaction. Our feedback was summarily ignored. Management watched quality colleagues burnout and/or leave.

I was part time filling in no more hours than I was willing. That is not typical. Almost all staff are wonderful people, collaborate and help each other as best they can, but are most often quite busy. Good work with clients, who mostly all respect and appreciate services.
Expected to work long hours. Much chaos and no support from management. Company experienced financial difficulties. Lay offs and no salary increases for over 2 years
loved my job was not able to reach more of the homeless population inwhich we served due vfc to the systems in place.  All in all it was nice while it lasted.

MHP has a records system that is very, very difficult to use.  MHP staff that attempts to keep this system productive is unable to keep major issues from arising regularly that impact the inputting of records and the validity of client charts. Report functions intended to help find missing or expired paperwork do not work. There are reminders to renew paperwork that does not yet need to be renewed. Major assessment tools break and cannot be used for months. Then when the tool is back online it is expected that as a clinician, you will get all of these documents up to date for all of your clients' charts. Often several of these will have to be done to simply transfer a person to another program in the organization. Those receiving these clients often get quite nasty about these "missing" documents.  Caseloads are large, no-shows are frequent and expectations for utilization are unrealistic. There is a constant threat that the agency will not be paid for our work if we don't do this or that in a rush fashion. This sometimes includes making up answers for client assessments in order to meet state filing requirements for Medicaid which might be an ethical issue for some. Management seems oblivious of these issues and "middle management" or staff in charge of serving clinicians tend to paint rosy pictures for their bosses..Working with the clients is wonderful and many are in great need. Many clients respond dramatically to interventions. It is the only reason I stay.

I great place to learn and develop professional skills to accompany you in your long term occupational goals. Always developing new skills in listening to individuals to get to the root of their issues to problem solve in-order implement rational and healthy outcomes.

Challenging setting. Poor communication. Good team but low morale. Kind supervisor who lacked the time to help employees really learn the electronic health record system, which is a beast. Inadequate training.

Very poor Administrative team, no chance of promotion, low salary, general dissatisfied mood among staff. The executive team isn't able to listen to the staff and they continue to make the same mistakes over and over. The EHR sucks
The majority of decisions that influence staff and clients are made by individuals who are not qualified to be in a management position.

MHP is extremely stressful for direct line staff, esp therapists and prescribers.  Rumor has it that MHP has 30-60 days of cash.  Used to be just the opposite in all those ways.  4-5 years ago Upper mgmt changed, new mgmt was too ambitious for this industry, acquired properties etc.  The health care industry is wobbling right now, that is seriously contributing to the problem.  Federal funding was cut back.  Focus is not on clients anymore, but on staying afloat by leaning very heavily on direct staff to meet earnings goals.  I am still working here for various reasons, but will leave asap.  Benefits are competitive.

MHP has changed so much, they keep changing rules which is hard to keep up to date on them. People that work hard are leaving because they're overwhelmed with all the work they have to do. Staff that does minimum sometimes get rewarded for doing one thing right. no raises, not even cost of living. computer system is horrible
Great experience . Great work place .  Learning experiences . A typical day at work , visit clients make sure their needs are met. Go to court and keep up with all documentation.

The interim CEO is in his early to mid seventies and is out of touch with employees, clients, and current trends  affecting the behavioral health community and the organization itself.   The same can be said for the majority of the management staff. Management staff seem ill qualified and the quality of supervision is very poor and questionable.

Immediate supervisor and co-workers were very supportive, team atmosphere and great place to work! Poor management & leadership, especially at the Board of Directors/CEO level. Upper management very slow to bring about changes and more focused on hiring more managers to lessen their workload rather than hiring much needed therapists and care coordinators.
Lack of administrative integrity.  They make people work to exhaustion by often threatening to fire them with no unemployment benefits.  Management is instructed to lie to protect the administrators.

After being with this agency for over 5 years, I believe things have only gotten worse. Higher caseloads, more paperwork demands, constant staff transitions. Significant agency inefficiencies (ie: staff turnover, EHR, management expenses) that prevent salary increases. Lots of lip service from management. Poor communication to clients. Staff are frequently encouraged to over extend themselves, very poor boundaries/little encouragement for self care-comes at the cost of getting behind on work. New “widget” increases competition between colleagues. Very sad to watch this company fall apart

Large case load, high turnover rate, non-cooperative work environment, culture of non-helpful communiction.Questionable decisions made by management staff. Environmental stress and culture has lead to hostile work dynamic amongst staff in the forms of poor working relationships and
This job was the most stressful I have ever had. Where to begin....

I don’t feel supported here. It is frustrating and disheartening to see first hand the lack of quality care. The turnover rate is very high, staff are under stress, and management does very little to support their employees.

As all companies, MHP has it's difficulties...especially as a company that depends on government funds to help the community. There can be a lot of stress and dysfunction, but everyone I've worked with are caring, supportive, compassionate, and client focused. I am only looking to find a new position due to changes in life situations.

I appreciated working on the Kid Connects team. My supervisor was always available for questions and provided supportive reflective supervision. The hours were flexible. I was provided valuable, additional training in addition to my classes.
Going through transitions but the mission is strong in the staff and leadership.
Agency run by people who make mistakes and then lie to cover their butts.  If you care about people with mental illness or yourself DO NOT APPLY HERE!

I had a somewhat unique internship in that I was not clinical. I worked various high-level administrative tasks, as well as a handful of "busy-work" type tasks. My unpaid work directly tied with MHP's Medcaid funding and making sure we still got it.
The most recent CEO of company recently and abruptly departed agency.

I simply do not have the time or energy to detail all the reasons I would discourage anyone from applying for employment at Mental Health Partners. MHP seems to think they're the only under-funded, short-staffed nonprofit working in behavioral health. It's 2018, people. Get it together. You can be the underdog and still succeed. Leadership is drowning in problems they can't solve, managers have no resources to help their staff and they're usually lacking in leadership skills, directors are clueless when it comes to day-to-day operations and staff are exhausted. Clients are perfectly aware of the burn out and don't feel valued. Positive experiences at MHP are few and far between. Do not work here. Wait for new leadership to come around.

Great in the beginning and gave me an opportunity to grow and learn a lot about the field. Due to changes in our funding and the lack of growth, I am choosing to look elsewhere. Best part about MHP are the workers and the clients.

Primarily homeless day shelter atmosphere in Boulder is not conducive to recovery for homeless or more stable population. Quality of service depends mostly upon how busy we are or who helps you. In last year, leadership shows they care more about image and ideals than security or quality.  Highly political out of touch leadership making decisions for client population and clinical service staff whom they don’t interact with. Clients have described us as, “Left hand doesn’t know what the right is doing.”

As stated in earlier posts, a revolving door of employee turnover due to insular, out-of-touch upper management more interested in protecting incompetent, inexperienced middle management rather than retaining talented staff. Lack of transparency and collaboration. Toxic atmosphere. Employees concerns not addressed or valued. Teams with the highest turnover correlated with poor management styles: micro managing, lack of communication, authoritarian style: "our way or the highway". Most studies show that high employee turnover has to do with management and workplace culture. Somehow MHP is not aware of this basic phenomenon of workplace dysfunction. I would not recommend anyone to work here.
This place would like to present itself as come kind of innovative clinic center in Boulder.
nice people very happy environment. come in and start on computer help some poeple on computer. very helpful. loving poeple in work going to lunch. talking to poeple about there problems
Mental Health Partners does a world of wonder, or at least it tries too, within the Boulder County community.
not worth the effort to write out all that is troubling about this agency. AVOID if you possibly can. too low of pay for work. No clear leadership. horrible benefits
MHP gives a lot of training and continued education and room for growth. They care about you as a person, not just you in your functional role. It's a team-building environment.

Immediate supervisor and co-workers were very supportive, team atmosphere and great place to work! Poor management & leadership, especially at the Board of Directors/CEO level. Upper management very slow to bring about changes and more focused on hiring more managers to lessen their workload rather than hiring much needed therapists and care coordinators.

MHP is a wonderful organization with a dedicated and very intelligent staff.  They are committed to providing the best possible service to each client and working hard to contribute to the community it serves.

MHP does an excellent job in hiring excellent and qualified candidates (if not over qualified). However, MHP could work better in supporting employees and retaining individuals. The turn over rate is very high. The "revolving door" aspect of employee turnover rate is not supportive to clients who need services and not supportive of the budget and work environment.

Overall, I did enjoy the different positions I have had with MHP. I was on good teams with mostly supportive direct supervisors. Not everyone was supportive, and many teams and locations had problems.

I wouldn't recommend working here long term. Too much turmoil and understaffed.  Skip this place and look elsewhere.  Very Liberal environment creates folks that get sidetracked and can't focus on the critical issues. Cutting costs is more important to executive staff.

The very high caseload,  the lack of communication from management, concerns constantly being  ignored, and the pressure to manage many cases has lead to an unsatisfactory feeling of "burnt out"  (I am happy my internship is over) . In my short time, I  observed staff members frequently quitting.

Management and MHP executives have noted the higher than average turnover rate and the turnover rate has been expressed in meetings. This is not the employer of choice.  This is not a healthy work environment--high case loads, stringent policies, and a culture where communication is not encouraged amongst staff. Clear signs of little or no training amongst some management team staff.

I agree with other reviews saying there is an "Elitism" attitude with upper management. It started in 2013 when the Chief Strategy Officer came on board. He was a very poor selection for a position that is not even needed. He unfairly eliminated very talented technical people that were leading MHP in the right direction. MHP has been wavering ever since with no technical leadership.

Do not work here.  You will regret it.  It used to be a great place to work but has steadily gone downhill since the hiring of a clinical psychiatrist into the Chief Strategy Officer role in 2013.  Management is out of touch and there is a culture of elitism and secrecy.  Technical decisions are made by non-technical people and large scale projects frequently fail.  The organization is top heavy and needs a haircut and a shake up to oust the entrenched.  They claim to want to be the "employer of choice" for Boulder County.  Laughable comedy.  Save yourself headaches and heartaches.  Skip over this company and aim higher.
Not surprising this place has bad reviews.

Top Heavy Management concerned more with their job titles (VP's and Directors) than providing a constructive work environment for their employees interfacing directly with clients. Management has created a segregated 'elite' group. One recent example is they renamed the Sr, Systems Administrator (IT position) to Director of IT because they could not find anyone to accept the Sr. Systems Administrator position. Non-technical management can not make decisions. Don't waste your time here if you want a long, fulfilling career.

Caseloads were through the roof, clinicians were constantly quitting due to burn out, management ignored our concerns and basically told us we weren't working efficiently enough.  People (like me) were referred to (by our CEO) as a "negative Nellys" for bringing up legitimate concerns about the ethics of what we were being asked to do.
The lack of experience of the CSO hurts MHP. The CSO has never had any major accomplishments. Good talker but lacks experience.
Two stars.  Able to utilize skills.  Passion for client quality of life and recovery mid level staff and down.  Upper management lack of client focus.
Management heavy, clients come second, HR is there for the upper managers only in personnel issues.
The work day included charting, meeting with multiple clients for hour long sessions, organizing for groups and or helping in the milieu.

Good place to work if you like to help people but get paid very little. Everyone seems to be over worked, under paid and highly stressed.. High turn over, poor direction from CSO focused only on money. It would be nice to hire some experienced business people instead of psychologists... the executive team has been in place too long so there are no new ideas, very stagnant.

The AOP Program in Longmont is chaotic and unorganized. The manager and supervisor have no sense of humor and are heady and unfeeling. They cannot find anyone to fill the substance abuse counselor there, so asked me to do a month's documentation backed up because the other people before me were "mishaps". Mental Health Partners (MHP) is not interested in hiring people who have warmth and good clinical skills. It's about overkill in paper work for job security. There is a lot of judgmental people in the management structure too. For example, at the last new employee orientation, we were watching a video on cross-cultural sensitivities. A man addressed that it is going to be tricky for him because he is going to work with law enforcement, which may be a culture of punishment, while he comes from a more treatment point of view. I have over 15 years working with offenders in community corrections. I stated that I too had some struggles when dealing with the criminal culture, as well as a culture of punishment in the half-way house program where I worked. When I expressed that, I was shot down by the presenter, an unfriendly aggressive woman who judged me and my opinion and experience. I dare say she never worked with manipulative criminals or sociopaths. MHP is a culture of stoic unfeeling aggressive women. I was let go after a week because I struggled to learn the hundreds of guidelines to make even a simple note in a timely manner. I passed the Spanish proficiency test, but they are not committed to reaching out to monolingual Spanish-speaking consumers. Bilingual clinicians are

I worked for this company for about 15 months and loved being here.  The management is wonderful and really aid in your professional growth.  The weekly supervision meetings help with your growth as a professional with honest feedback and wonderful support for what you are doing well.  The company encourages a balance between professional and personal life as well as encourages you to enjoy what you are doing with your professional life.

I wouldn't recommend anyone who is good technically and looking for a long term IT career work here. It would be too frustrating. The management is inexperienced, non-technical and has no long term planning or prioritization skills. Both deadlines and workloads are unrealistic since they are driven by nontechnical Psychologists.
Interesting work but very stressful. Lower pay, constant threats of budget cuts; don't feel appreciated or valuable as an employee. hate to see other folks laid off

Immediate supervisor and co-workers were very supportive, team atmosphere and great place to work! Poor management & leadership, especially at the Board of Directors/CEO level. Upper management very slow to bring about changes and more focused on hiring more managers to lessen their workload rather than hiring much needed therapists and care coordinators.

This was a demanding job requiring a lot of paperwork. I enjoyed working with clients at the front lines of their recovery from mental illness, however, found the agency as a whole was bogged down with too many clients and not enough clinicians, making the workload heavier on all parties.

I am happy to work at Mental Health Partners. My supervisor is incredibly supportive, and my colleagues are kind and helpful. My work is meaningful, and I get to work independently and participate in various committees.

After 6 years of hard work in difficult work environment I lost my job due "budget cuts".  Working directly in an inpatient environment certainly had its moments as well as very fullfilling knowing you are helping those with extreme mental illnesses.

Seems like the emphasis here is not on "Mental Health" but more on cost cutting and reduction of staff and/or hours. The hardest part of the job is remaining focused when all the people around you are overworked and stressed. Senior Management is pretty incompetent (not skilled in people management). In my opinion .. If you are an RN you are better off elsewhere

Fun place to work to help indigent clients. Upper management is focused on money more than employee loyalty. low pay, limited job security due to budget cuts - currently expanding but may cut back later due to budget constraints
I enjoy working at Mental Health Partners. It is an excellent non-profit organization.  It offers help to a large population in healthcare.
The hardest part of my job is not being able to truy help some one face to face otherwise it is a good place to work.
I enjoy that this company takes care of mental health patients no matter what there ability to pay is.

Mental Health Partners was a great place to work. Now,  however, the work environment has changed significantly since the layoff of the much loved Director of IT. A Clinical Psychologist acting as the Cheif Strategy Officer has decided to take over the IT department and micromanage it and therefore, eliminated the Director's position. This new guy is difficult to deal with because he expects too much, has no real management experience and has very little technical knowledge. Job security and future outlook do not look very good.

A new Chief Strategy Officer (a clinical psychologist) came aboard in April and changed the work environment from cooperative to very hostile. No one seem to care for his management style. He has to take control and micro-manage employees which is very counterproductive to getting work done. This Strategy Officer is very unapproachable, non-technical and has obviously never managed before. Seems he has taken on more work than one human can successfully handle.

Currently working at MHP and enjoy working with other mental health professionals that are truly dedicated to their jobs, and the welfare of our clients.  Working with families and individuals to improve their life circumstances is very rewarding.  Helping the clients/families in the same communities that we live in, is empowering for both our clients and staff.  Love my job!  Wonderful team and management support.  Good hours and benefits!

I worked with students at both Erie Colorado Middle and High School. I was providing support and confidential counseling for the students as part of Mental Health Partnership, a third party agency and thus exempt from the policies that the school counselors had of sharing all information that students shared with the rest of the school system. I was required to keep notes on all interactions with students and fill out ongoing progress notes as well as confer with a Mental Health Partnership supervisor on all of the students that saw me.
It was a positive experience for the most part. The people are nice and supportive.
As a contractor at Agilent I had a wonderful time getting to know the employees and management. everyone was extremely friendly and the idea of safety was always a priority.

Agilent provides an okay workplace - most of the good was due to the people at the same level I worked with. However, there is no real vertical communication, and you get the feeling that the company has no plans, no vision for its future. Compensation is average for the industry, but don't expect a raise or a chance at a promotion.

Overall i believe the company is great and they have phenomenal instruments and service. However there is a rather large divide between the service industry and the rest of the company. They have picnics and parties occasionally while the service people are working like crazy to just keep up with the workload and half of us don't even know who other people in the district are. There is not enough people to support the amount of work for the territories.

I have only worked contract work for them and found them very reasonable and accommodating. I highly recommend working for them on a contract basis. You are treated as if you are an outsider by management, but then you are. They are accomodating if you have any personal emergency.

This place is very laid back I will give them that.  But it's too much favoritism being shown in this warehouse.  They also will hold you back from other positions in the warehouse, if they feel that they need you in that position you currently have.  They employees are messy and the supervisors are messy at times.
Good vacations and benefits, solid company, decent upper management, generally good employees to work with.

Agilent's focus on workplace culture and teamwork makes it a fun place to work. They are about self accountability and try to help employees do their best. They provide opportunities for employees to showcase their talents and abilities. The work being done here has an impact all over the world and that makes every effort worthwhile.

I enjoy my job and plan to stay for the time being. I love my team and feel valued by my direct manager but cannot say the way of “corporate” as pay is sub-average and there is little room for advancement. The flexibility, time off and other benefits make up for it for the most part. The work can be challenging at times but overtime is rarely expected and the job is low stress overall.

Did not feel like I served a purpose. Management will not let you know the information that you need to succeed in the company. I felt that there is no room for advancement and my manager was ready to leave if she didn't get her way.

I liked my coworkers, liked what I did, stayed busy, didn't like the mean managers. Not a great place to work, but not lousy either. I liked the manager who hired me, but he was replaced after about six months. From there, I didn't know where I stood day to day, always felt I was going to be fired the next week, and kept looking for jobs. Eventually I found one and left.
Overall great company with solid executive leadership.  Strong culture and generally good people in the company.  Mature company top in its field particularly having been spun-off from good old HP.

Loved being a remote employee.  Company Car.  Great pay and benefits.  Most management are really good, but the last one was what pushed me out of the company.  Even though I almost always worked alone at customer sites, there was a real since of being part of a team.  Loads of resources, from product literature to factory support personal.  Can't say enough good things about the company or coworkers.

I recently graduated and joined Agilent’s Sales team. They are welcoming, work with new hire to ensure learning curve is met, and generally care about you. The work/life balance is awesome. A great place to work, except for when the management doesn't have a clue what to do. I was in the Bio-Science division. We were developing gene chips for all sorts of purposes. The management didn't have a clue. They were all gun ho on the hardware and software we were developing. A gene chip scanner was the furthest along. The management supported its development really well. I was in a group that was trying to automate the process of using the chips. That is take a new gene chip, inject a sample of DNA. Let the machine process the sample. After the process, the gene chip is inserted into a carousel (like a slide projector) that is removed from the machine and placed into the gene chip scanner above. They dumped the project because they could not get a software person to fix some lines of code. This was in the late 90's when software was hot, but we hired a guy and then he was taken away from us. The marketing guy had no interest in the project he barely spoke two words to us. They were shocked when three of us left the group. The lead engineer left for the Agilent lab and me and another guy left the company. Like I said, great company, but try to find out if the division knows what it wants to do.
Great Company. Hired through Intellisource. Terrible company that hires and fires the wrong people: Wrongfully fired. Intellisource discriminates. I waa
Good work life balance, slow to change.  A great place to work if you can handle the slow rate of change and the tools available to you as a marketer.  Lots of smart people.  Tends to be R&D driven.

I have achieved as much as I can here and now it is time to take on another avenue.  The company treated me well and I enjoyed the work, but I feel I have more to offer so I need to find a new challenge.
