Mid and upper level sales management and most of product managers and marketing CSD personnel have never carried a bag. Agilent is first an instrument company always has been always will be. Aftermarket is an afterthought. Second, Agilent is a marketing company and the thing they market the best is themselves. Don't believe the hype and stay away from the kool-aid.

Man was i fooled on this one.  When you first start everyone raves about the work-life balance and the company culture.  But once you are in hat all goes away.  The departments are ruthless towards each other.  Blame game and employee stealing is rampant throughout the company. I managed a repair center and was always fighting off other managers from trying to steal my talented employees.  HR is another entirely different animal.  They are on the extreme side of the employees and very anti-management.  If you ever approached them for advice on how to handle a non-productive worker, it suddenly became your fault and it was your butt on the line for not coaching them properly.
supervisor was great, hours were flexible. let me also work part time after maternity break with pay cut for a few months. team = good. pay was okay..

Started out there as an equipment operator.   After two years of that they informed me that if I chose to go back to school in the tech field they would pay for it.   I was working 6am to 6pm so I signed up for school and they paid the tuition, parking fees, books, supplies, etc.  They also let me stay on the clock while attending school so I was paid to go as well.   Was able to complete my technician degree in two years and then I was advanced to the Maintenance Tech group working on High Vacuum pumps at first, the on to the main equipment used to manufacture integrated circuits.  After a total of 6 years, I was made redundant and received a package equaling 1 years pay.   Found a job in 4 months so banked the rest.   Very happy to work for them and would return as an operator or technician.

A small company that is going through some growing pains.

a normal forklift job with advancement opportunities. the work is not hard at all. the warehouse is very orderly. they have good management. they give good breaks and lunch.

Agilent, now Keysight, has long dominated the high frequency electronics test and measurement industry in the USA and worldwide.  Electronic Test & Measurement instrumentation was the initial focus of the corporation and HP computers were originally developed explicitly to control their instruments in order to sequence through measurement steps and retrieve and analyze test data.  These computers were designed specifically for this purpose along with their custom CPUs and proprietary operating system HP BASIC, which was also the programming language.  Their printer business, similarly, was created to provide printed output capabilities to support reporting and graphing of test results - this started with pen plotter machines and ultimately produced laser-jet and finally ink-jet technologies.  All the computing and printing technologies were byproducts of the need to facilitate automated test and measurement systems.

I worked in Corporate Marketing and Sales. Most of the team I supported was remote. San Francisco, CA, Anaheim, CA, Portland, OR, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, and Ohio.  I enjoyed supporting so many remote people. I always had something different to do for them.

The focus is on "One Agilent", which means that individual issues and conflicts should be minimized for the good of the organization.  98% of employees seem to buy into this approach. It makes the company a great place to work.  98% of people are reasonable, friendly, and working toward a common goal.

I managed inventory and created an MRP spreadsheet that downloaded data from Oracle to an Excel Spreadsheet with a Macro to tell us min and max qty's.  What current on hand was, total dollar value of our inventory.  I saved the company over $1 million dollars over 3 years by implementing a min max for inventory therefore only bringing in the required material based on customer orders and vendor lead times.  They had no method to use before I developed the min max qtys.  We had pot luck lunches, had a birthday cake for the birthdays each month which allowed you to get to know you fellow employees that you didn't directly work with.  I love my job and the freedom to learn as much as possible about Oracle
Just not a good environment. Poor management & unhappy employees. There was no good direction given. When notice was you got walked out that day. It was very hard to show up to work.
Excellent corporate culture and a CEO who is approachable and progressive.  Fair and supportive, there is no tolerance for irrational or unacceptable behavior.
Typical day: active, fast paste,

The product teams are well managed and funded. The marketing organization at Agilent, though, is backward and managed by people who are not up on modern practices. Pay is ok, health benefits are mediocre. They don't have free soda or decent coffee. They don't even offer purified water. The coffee urns probably date back to the Reagan era or before, and the coffee in them is just terrible. No free food, either. They used to offer a pension, but now that is gone.
Agilent is trying to be agile and some departments are, however it is not the case for the whole company due to many employees who have "always" worked here.
Company management was supportive and focused on employee development.  Decent place to work with good benefits and competitive pay.  Workload was stressful at times.

Agilent was a great place to work!  Generous time off and bonuses.  The people were to BEST and there was tons of room to advance. Healthcare was high deductible, but they all are now, so it was competitive.
i loved working in agilent beacuse they were very sensitive to empoloyee needs and allowed us to work varied hours asnd this made it possible for me to go to school.
Agilent was formulated from spin off divisions of HP. The culture remained very "HP Like" for the time that i was employed there. I departed shortly after the formation of Agilent
Very good place manufacturing, one of my best...

Agilent offers many opportunities to learn and grow. The culture is collaborative and friendly. It is a very good place to work, but the compensation is not currently keeping up with the industry in silicon valley.
Cutting edge technology company that was spun off from HP a decade ago and is highly profitable as world leader in medical technology.  The management are fair and communicative.
Agilent is a very good company to work for.  Like any large organization, some positions are more exciting than others and offer more advancement potential.
Good management, structured to make life easier for the engineer. Empower them to get as much done as possible. Never felt overly scrutinized and treated as a professional.
There is stability working for the company however everyone is not treated the same. Also upper management is not very involved when they absolutely should be.
As a contractor at Agilent I had a wonderful time getting to know the employees and management. everyone was extremely friendly and the idea of safety was always a priority.

While Agilent is an excellent company to work for the compensation, and the turn over rate leaves a lot to be desired. The work environment is fast paced, and stressful.  This explains the turn over rate. Many others have left the department in which I work because they simply don't feel like their experience, or level of expertise is valued.

Relaxed environment, and great coworkers.  Learned to hone my help desk skills one call at a time, with available online assistance and in-house subject matter experts available during all shifts.  Management was phenomenal  at motivating, coaching, and leveraging the different talents available at the help desk.  Coworkers were fantastic and willing to teach a tech support neophyte the ropes of working on a support desk. Workflow could vary but was often times too slow.  The campus itself was a great environment to work at, with a cafeteria that is unsurpassed in my experience.
Pour chances of challenges, lots of favoritism with the site management.
make sure the task for the day is completed, revise my work for any errors. Make sure any email are responded in a timely manner. Create reports for repair request.
I have no yet one person that does not like the job here. I think I gained a lot of experience, especially as an undergrad who was graced with this job.
While no job is perfect, they tolerated my hours and I got to do some interesting work. I filed a couple patents which I'm prowd of and would never have been able to afford myself.

This was my introduction to hardware QA test. As time went by, I was able to take on more interesting work. I was able to develope significant VBA skill, and a bit of C#. Ironically I was hired for my abilities with Rocky Mountain Basic (HP basic) to maintain their EMC software..

NASD in Boulder has become very top heavy with managers and has become a place that hires friends rather than qualified candidates. Good employees are leaving because of the current culture. Departments only care about the success of their group, often at the expense of other departments.
Good company over all. Excellent people t work with (in the Santa Rosa area especially.) A well run company but it is a big company so you have to excel to stand out.
I did not appreciate the fact that you hourly pay was lower because you may receive a bonus based on how well the company was doing.  The bi annually bonus may or may not actually happen
They overutilized the temporary workforce during an increasingly busy business cycle, and things got stressful for some of the longer term employees....

Just like most corporations, employees are pawns and treated as such.  Management runs on lies and manipulation.  The products are not for the greater good but only driven by the bottom dollar.  If you have accepted these facts of our current culture, then go for a job at Agilent.  If you think Agilent will be any different then all other multi-national, profit driven corporations, look elsewhere.
I was able to launch an online university that had measurable impact of the sales teams while working in one of the best cultures in the valley.

I found my experience at this company to be very positive with the exception of lack of opportunities to advance into other roles there. I found work intellectually stimulating, supporting Instruments assays and software for many applications including sure select. I enjoyed my manager and he gave me lots of leeway to grow in my role there.

due to budget cuts, I was laid off.  I would have remained there until I decided to retire.  The team and management were very well organized and knew how to have all members of the team be successful so that the sales teams could do their jobs well!
Excellent team spirit, motivation largely inspired by desire to not let the team down. Fair employee pay  and strong team values put into practice daily.
Good company with good employees. Great products and services.
This is a well-run company, and if you follow procedures, look for innovation and help develop what's there, you'll probably do well.

Agilent was a great place to work.  Many great benefits and lots of opportunity for career advancement.  Days were long but so were the weekends.  Work life balance was great.  Management was always there when needed.
Average work place with common issues. Reactive management, strict internal compliance rules, many tools that lack interoperability creating tedious work redundancy.
As a contractor at Agilent I had a wonderful time getting to know the employees and management. everyone was extremely friendly and the idea of safety was always a priority.
Great company to work for.  Very innovative and transparent.  Market leader in many technologies.  A collaborative and engaging work environment where people are encouraged to share ideas.
A very good company to work for if you are a full time employee with the benefits they offer.However, as an intern their benefits are limited.I would mind working for them as a fulltime employee.
Agilent was a great place to work. I have learnt a lot working with the organisation. Agilent has helped me be a thorough professional. Culture was enriching.
They have a great culture and wonderful people.  Good benefits and salary.  Global company so you'll meet people from all over.  There is no typical work day in IT.

Working at HP and Agilent Technologies are good companies, but hire mostly engineers, managers, sales consultants and other professionals with higher education.  But my jobs were out-sourced to other countries, not good.
High work load, usually doing more than 1 job, working on several projects at a time.  But the high caliber people you get to work with usually outweigh the negatives.
Nice place to work; good benefits; great people; stable company; lots of scientifically minded people; best to have a PhD or equivalent life sciences degrees.

Monitored operations to ensure production standards me expectations. Recommended adjustments to assembly and production process. Ensured high quality mechanical units and components through thorough inspection process.
nice place to work! no complaints, lots of opportunities for scientific professionals. have to relocate to Delaware if you want to work here though!!!

The people at Agilent make it a great place to work. The atmosphere is relaxed and people here know what they are doing. Everyone is friendly and willing to help. This was probably one of my favorite places to work.
Working at Agilent was great. The work was fast paced, but not high stressed. The company was very employee oriented and made the tasks and workplace enjoyable.
Agilent was a good place to work. The company is the market leader in many of its product lines which made sales easier. The company is well know and the name will get you into any discussion.
this place made me feel like i could never advance.
the best teamwork and teammates I ever had worked with.
It was busy, talking to Cost Accounting Managers and R&D engineers. I learned a lot about how the manufacturing process works and how to communicate with engineers.
Great company with people that had vast amounts knowledge. Training was very good. The support was great among my colleagues. I was able to meet a variety of different people.
One of the best place to work with a lot of learning and amazing culture. people love to work here and get a guidance from all seniors.

I enjoyed working at this place.  My boss was so awesome and understanding.  We worked really hard to provided the services our Engineers needed in a timely manner.  Loved the cafeteria, staff picnics, vending machines, and most of all caring and kind employees.

Incredible team of people and a great environment.  Unfortunately, I was one of the last hired and one of the first to be laid off.  Eventually, most if not all of Colorado divisions were closed.  I had a great manager and was able to hone my project management and proposal writing skills.  Awesome opportunity!
Over the many years...
As a contractor at Agilent I had a wonderful time getting to know the employees and management. everyone was extremely friendly and the idea of safety was always a priority.
Agilent Technologies was great in the early 2000's.  I was there for three years, and I really enjoyed my job.  The training was not the best, but the job was interesting.
Good place to work, learn and full of challenge. Unfortunately the business was down therefore a lot of employees got laid off and I was
Great work life balance and nice place to work

Autonomy to introduce new ideas and run with them.Extensive training opportunities available. Good pay/profit sharing/benefits.Due to specific role, certain periods of the year are quite intense.Volunteer time off given to assist non-profits.Frequent sales or special occasion celebrations with food, drink.Bureaucracy and processes to resolve simple issues can be challenging.
Agilent is a pretty good place to work.  Good work-life balance and close to home.  However, little job growth or advancement.  This can get a little frustrating.
Agilent was a fun place to work. Very busy office, which made the day go by quick. I grew very quick being at Agilent. I loved the responsibilities i had and assisting with my team mates.
Much of your work environment is your team; co workers and immediate manager.  I was lucky and to have a great team.  There were plenty of opportunities.
Great work environment, with a work hard play hard atmosphere. Team environment with a family oriented team. I would still be there if the economy didnt crash in 2008
Great Management with VERY open door policy.  They are FAIR to everyone.  Great high tech assignments.  Top of the line benefits.  Generous Retirement.
When I worked there, it had rather relax work pace. Management is friendly. But I am able to provide any current information as I left so many years ago.

As long as your are an effective hard worker, you have nothing to worry about. People are nice and easy to get along with. Some departments have unlimited overtime available. Other departments do not allow overtime. Everyone basically polices themselves, making sure that they're on top of their duties. Managers step in to tell you of their expectations and upcoming projects or new procedures. Team work is crucial for most departments. I've had the great opportunity to work with mostly every department on the first floor, at Little Falls. I started off in Receiving, then moved to Stores and helped in Shipping, then I moved to Field Repair, and ended in the Refurb department. Although I was only a contract worker they made me feel a part of the family.

I had just started this position when they decided that the site was going to be closed and the manufacturing was going away.  I was disappointed because I really enjoyed the group I was working with and the work I was doing.
Liked this biotechnology work experience.  Worked with a lot of very smart people and enjoyed learning from them.  Every day presented new challenges, and I was usually engaged.

Liked the challenges and the people. Technically, the job was top notch, but the overall environment was rough due to continuous cut backs over the years.  Management was always trying to do more with less and the compensation/benefits moved toward the middle of the industry versus the top that it had been.   This was especially tough as Agilent spun off of HP and the company began its focus on the medical analysis / equipment business.

Agilent likes you if you have a bio, chemistry or some other kind of science background. They also like secondary (masters or higher) degrees. If you are a PhD, you will be fine. If you are not, better plan your networking strategy and get some recommendations to go back to school!
Great place for work
I was promoted to Project Manager

I worked on automated and manual filling stations, drove a forklift when needed, staged product for shipping. The management and co-workers were great and there was no hard part to this job. The most enjoyable part was the freedom I had.
Agilent is a great place to work, great people, interesting job assignments. On site cafeteria, huge parking lot, close to home and shopping. A great place to continue or start a career.
The benefits are mediocre.  The work hours are long and management is demanding.   Engineers are ranked against each other which leads to a less cooperative environment.
As a contractor at Agilent I had a wonderful time getting to know the employees and management. everyone was extremely friendly and the idea of safety was always a priority.
I learned a lot about telecom billing.  Enjoyed learning a new thing and the person I was working with. There was not much direction, and the billing system did not have accurate information.
I will never forget this place. This is one of my favorite. Just a fun place to work.  Coworker are super nice and lay back.  It does not mean we did not work.
Excellent place to work with management and co-worker support.
Very Good, a great company to work for/with. I would tell friends to apply here and I think they would like it. Enjoyable, good management
fun place to work
Loved the coworkers and managers. Very supportive atmosphere.

Agilent is a left behind branch of HP.  Its continuous struggle to modernize it's culture is plagued by the old HP residual culture which supports large unaccountable layer of bureaucracy that suppresses innovative spirit.  Having a great idea is not good enough and often innovator is intimidated by those who is not accountable for any relevant task.  This company culture reminds me of communism, job security means 100% brown-nosing your superior and learn how to hide in plane site with lessez-fair.  Agilent needs new leadership blood, same people cannot improve its old culture because they don't know what to change to.  Agilent needs to redefine itself form "Old HP" image, it needs at least to be "New HP".
Excellent company to work for! The level of technology they manufacture is world class. Some of the best engineers I've worked with were at Agilent. The culture is professional and relaxed.

Technical marketing was a rather laid back environment. It included supportive management and had a plethora of resources and mentors to help out with any questions, concepts, or issues. While I worked there most of the employees were probably in their 40's and up, and had families. Overall the company was enjoyable, but the work I did wasn't really something I wanted to continue doing.
A typical day is very simple stress free great supervision very helpful when problems occurs.The negative part of our daily routine is not fast paced too much time wasted.

I followed my manager from Oak Technology to Agilent. This was a big change. Agilent was much larger as an HP spin off. I provided routine administrative support to the President of the Semiconductor Products Group as follows:
A great company to work for, one that treats its employees with dignity and respect.  let one self manage, and its fair compensated.
Flexible work hours

Agilent is a wonderful company to work.  Very diverse with cultures, people and work ethics.  Agilent continues to improve with the times of life.  I enjoy working at Agilent and would recommend anyone who is interested in applying for jobs.

Management is very cool.  The schedule was very flexible.  All they ask is that you work an 8 hour day.  It was a regulated lab so you do the same thing everyday following precise protocols but otherwise I miss working there.
Excellent place to work with supportive management. Technically lot to learn and lot of people to help around if you face any issues.
I loved working for Agilent. The people and management are great. It was a great all around experience. A super company for personally grow and develop.

It was a very open and friendly office environment.open door policy with managers and supervisors. great commuting with office close to the center. Far to many temp workers, who do not take ownership of they're  responsibilitys.
Worked at Corporate

Culture was awesome. Met a whole lot of interesting folks.  proprietary laws keep projects confidential, and I learned various builds that are hard to explain since we where r and d that also be illegal.  Deadlines keep you on your toes. Hard to keep customers happy, our department made it easy to satisfy their goals.
As a contractor at Agilent I had a wonderful time getting to know the employees and management. everyone was extremely friendly and the idea of safety was always a priority.
Agilent came in with great interest after purchasing Varian Inc., After 2 years they deiced to move manufacturing to Malaysia. Not much more to say.

Most people are paid well and many groups are relaxed with a good work life balance.  However, there is little to no opportunity for career advancement and the recent reorganization/reinvention of the corporation appears to be killing its future.  The primary corporate focus now appears to be saving for the bottom line and not innovative product development or customer satisfaction.
Great work/life balance, compensation/benefits, management and culture.  Supportive management and career development.
Good company to work for overall.

PRO'S: job security, training/furthering education, stock/benefits. Very flexible with schedules and family oriented. Most positions allow you to work from home at least part time which can be an added perk for most.
Agilent is an excellent company to work for and it provided me many valuable experiences and opportunities to perform very successfully.

Agilent was a great place to work until it wasn't. The company was originally formed around the Old HP Way! I learned plenty about customer account management and providing complete customer solutions. The most enjoyable part of the day for me was spent interfacing with customers, trying to pinpoint our next big opportunity.
because it is large company:
The entire company is aging out, but they still aren't ready to hire young, fresh talent unless they accept lower than normal wages for working more than 10 hours a day.
very nice working environment
Cold calling to customer to get payments
I had the privilege of working with great people. Would recommend others to work here. I worked here for almost five years.

High energy, aggressive company. Very flexible work schedule. Was able to work from home on Fridays which really helped with my commute. People are really nice and helpful. Loved the people.Beautiful campus in Santa Clara. Great on- site cafeteria, volleyball court, & gym. Starbucks in the lobby. Lots of free parking.

To start things off, I must admit I was a subcontractor working at Agilent Technologies.  However, the culture was for the most part the best of any company I've been at thus far in my career.  Each quarter there would be some sort of pot luck or social gathering to maintain morale.  The few times I asked for time off I was never hassled, and a handful of times we were even let out early on the Friday before a holiday.  Hard work is certainly appreciated, and I was promoted several times and recognized when major deadlines were met.
Perform routine diagnostics and maintenance with multiple operating
The team at Agilent is extremely professional and considerate.
The company uses MS set of technologies (.NET) in 90% of their development.
There is always room to learn and grow with a company. If you think you know everything, you are wrong...I learn something new everyday.
This was my first management position. Had a great boss that walked me through the processes and coaching to be the best I could be.
Agilent incorporates structure with a team environment. Employees are helpful to any need and work is efficient to complete the common goal.
As a contractor at Agilent I had a wonderful time getting to know the employees and management. everyone was extremely friendly and the idea of safety was always a priority.
What I learned by working at the HQ of a global size company...

Agilent is now Keysight Technologies. I only worked at this job for a couple of months but found the same friendly environment I experienced there 30 years ago when it was Hewlett-Packards'  microwave Instrumentation Group. This is a great place to work in Northern California.

A typical day at work includes actively managing the Stability Program for over thirty different customer-specific stability studies and diligently adhering to quality and compliance while meeting the needs of our customers with speed and decisiveness
Monday through Friday operations.
I enjoyed the short time working for this company and liked the people with whom I worked

Agilent has changed from focusing on hardware solutions to providing general solutions for the life sciences market.  This has led to some restructuring and change.  The management culture values honesty and integrity and people are very fair and professional.
Great place to work if you are an engineer and not overly social. Some very intelligent people work here, and it's a great place to learn about tech and complex business processes.

You get to evaluate new technology and manage the source code, design and create the tool, collaborate with cross functional team.  Co-workers are friendly and nice, hard working team.  I have opportunity to learn new technology and new programming languages, especially how to communicate with different level of people.

My typical day at work was good, I did clean room cycle counts, drove the forklift, did flow tests, worked on automated filling stations. The Management was great along with my co-workers. I did not find any part of the job to be the hardest and the most enjoyable part of this job was my co-workers.
A typical day at work are always relax and work at your own pace.
I like my job there however it is really hard for a contractor to become full time at agilent.

Manufacturing & Assembly of Gas Chromatograph test computers (main board & pcb board & sub assembly). Work in electro static free clean rooms to test and repair units as well as shipping & receiving.  Also, trained new employees.
Contract was completed successfully. Client was satisfied with requirements having been met
Bad to be contractors.
It was an extraordinary experience.  I worked with the greatest people, technology, and had a world wide exposure few people ever get.
The pay is not good, it is very slow paced, mamagement is not that well. Benefits are the absolute worst.
I was a temp to hire.It always felt like there was only a  small chance of being hired after your contract.
This was hands-down one of my favorite positions. I gained much knowledge and was able to expand my current job role by taking on more responsibilities.
This company will set the bar very high, and will only reward you with more work. Decent rewards and base pay early in career, but leveled off quickly at the mid range of experience.
I learned that a temporary worker, known as a "NonAgilentWorker "
As a contractor at Agilent I had a wonderful time getting to know the employees and management. everyone was extremely friendly and the idea of safety was always a priority.

I was contracted to work at Agilent through Spherion agency.  Really enjoyed the work required of my position.  However, sometimes it was difficult to feel like part of the "Agilent" team since the contractors were looked as "outsiders".
Great work life balance...lots of nice people...good benefits...
Company was broken into several small companies which created more volatility.

This is a proud company with deep engineering and innovation roots.  They expect long hours and fast results with limited budget.  Willing to invest in systems and quality process development.  This is a good place to work with folks working hard to deliver great products.
Customer base was world-wide.  Working with different time zones made the job very enjoyable.
One of the top technology companies to work for during this period.  Managers focused on company and personal success.

Being on schedule, great team management ,co-workers we got along pretty good, I don't think I ever had a hard job to do because I always enjoy it so much and I what I enjoy most it is work with people.
Really great company to work for: component procress down sized in 2007.
As a manager of team of RF/microwave engineers in a non-typical contact center, the daily challenge keeps me coming to work each day.
I grew to love Agilent Technologies and the people that worked there in my short time as a contracted worker.
- Innovative lost of good products

Enjoyed working at Agilent.  The staff is very dedicated in getting production completed on time.  The hardest part is that the management is not involved in the overall production planning, making supply chain management very difficult.
Fast paced contract manufacturing. Manufacturing API for new drugs in trials

Listed every year for one of the best Colorado companies to work for, Agilent never disappoints.  The co-workers are nice, employees are held responsible for their actions, and have the power to do right by the customer.  There are activities outside of the office to build culture, and many courses offered within the company for those who wish to advance.  Promotions always come from within, and every position feels like it is necessary for the company to run.

Administer, coordinate and improve activities with all American Field Sales logistics services.  Report maintenance, cycle counts and verification of system testing, WIP (work in progress).  Communication with management and focal point for Field Service Engineers.  Touch point with third party logistics provider.  Provide logistics analysis and new/customized approaches to providing logistics services.  Solve complex problems requiring breadth and depth with knowledge of logistics processes, strategies and programs.
Good management, strong management to employee communication line.

I had the opportunity to do a summer internship at the Santa Clara location for the Nano-positioning and metrology division. Everybody is extremely nice and friendly. There are a lot of things to do during your work day at the campus, for example a Gym, voleyball and  basketball courrts, mini golf, etc,etc,etc. People work hard but also put an emphasis on making sure they are happy at work. This was a great example of east-coast vs west-coast attitute at work. I truly enjoyed it... specially bc every friday a reasonably large group of people of all ages and positions got together during a long lunch to play soccer at a field next to the campus...
Very nice and dedicated people.
My normal day at work involves a complete pass down from the previous shift technician. Organize equipment Preventative Maintenance timelines. Handle all equipment failures and manufacturing needs.
* Love Doing IQ,OQ,RQ & PV.
As a contractor at Agilent I had a wonderful time getting to know the employees and management. everyone was extremely friendly and the idea of safety was always a priority.
Factory training attended at Santa Clara, California.
* Day Job
I learned alot during my years with originally Hewlett Packard and then Agilent Technologies.

Originally hired as Material Handler/Shipping, Receiving Assistant in a calibration department dealing with repairs and data entry responsible for creating RMA allocating and shipping units in MFG PRO and SIEBEL. Also moving units to difference areas as needed. Performed visual inspection checking for missing accessories and dents and move units for calibration by placing them in a WIP location until completed. Dealt with any discrepancies relating to travelers and once completed and released by technician I ship7 units as required. Handled purchase orders, returns, stock, ordering of new parts and cycle counts.

Agilent is a great place to start your career. I daily learn a lot about wireless technologies, customers, marketing, business development, and sales. The best part of working in the company for me is the customer base I work with, the challenges in my work profile, and my co-workers who I learn from on a daily basis. A very collaborative working environment.
Enjoyed working independently, traveling six states, selling our drug testing supplies to the criminal justice system and other drug free workplaces.  Also the training on how to use our supplies.
A company that allowed me opportunities to succeed and grow my abilities beyond what I was hired for.
With Agilent, my entire stretch of employment was at the corporate level.  I managed several commodities in support of facilities around the world.

I don't believe I will find another company that paid and treated their employees any better, but just like many other big business' they sent manufacturing overseas in order to stay competitive which left me out of work.

My job is very demanding and requires travel.  Travel is 50-60% of the job.  I wear different hats.  evaluate customer requirements.  Develop collaborations.  Technical discussions.  provide Agilent solutions.

Agilent treats their interns very well; all interns are given specific personal projects to own and complete. The T&M business is generally much less hectic than consumer electronics, so most of the people working there are very laid back and have plenty going on in life besides their jobs.
This company is good work for ,because they all way be fair for employee & alls way 5s program and implement the system.

I am currently a subcontractor and I work from a home office.  It has been a wonderful opportunity and offers a lot of flexibility.  My kids are almost fully grown now though and I am attempting to plan ahead for a more challenging opportunity.
My co workers wee great and the atmosphere was casual business.

Providing a service for clients to bring their intelligent designed DNA based pharmaceuticals to reality.  I learned how to make oligonucleotides for therapeutic purposes from lab scale through kilogram.  Hardest part has been the commute.  The most enjoyable part has been to break new ground on scaling the manufacture of synthetic DNA.

In a clean room I visual inspected 900+ slides daily, Shipped 10K Monthly with 0 returns. Updated monthly and daily spreadsheets for completed slides. Trained co-worker on process of dispensing, toluene, RBS wash, plasma, pocket tape and packaging.

Like any other large company, there were a lot of ups and downs.  When I was hired Agilent Automation Solutions (AAS) was doing well.  At the end of my tenure (3 years later), a lot of people and management began to leave for other endeavors.
Good team Work,

Web Producer working with a global, cross-functional team of marketing stakeholders, designers and coders delivering and managing a Fortune 500 global website that provides effective worldwide e-marketing, e-commerce programs and product pages and support for an expanding group of products.  Routinely met the company strategic goals of greater brand awareness, increased product sales and higher customer retention.
I was an intern at Agilent for 6 months at the Santa Clara site. I have since been working at another company (location reasons) and I now realize how amazing Agilent was.
As a contractor at Agilent I had a wonderful time getting to know the employees and management. everyone was extremely friendly and the idea of safety was always a priority.
This was my first office job as an order manager.  I was the middle-man for communication about orders for a specific region.

Each day at work was like a surprise you never knew what you mightface . the work is very tedious and you must at all times remain focused, the slighted area could cost consumers and company large sums of money. Everyday with chemistry you learn something new. The co-workers where great and where always there to lead a hand. that was great ,we always somehow found ways to make each other laugh and smile boy did that make the day.Each day we where responsible for many task but the most difficult one for me was pouring a 40lb bottle of chemicals overhead in a glass dome, that was tough!

I have seen a lot of changes as Agilent with regards to how the employees are treated, and none of the changes are good.  They are striving to be a mediocre company with mediocre pay, but they want top-notch engineers.  Good luck with that.

As the outbound marketing manager in a complex fiber optics test & measurement division, I had to constantly seek approval for details from not only my direct boss but marketing personnel in NAMO - Agilent's North American Marketing Organization AND marketing personnel in the German office.  The German group was highly technical and responsible for product development.  The US group was the sales arm for the German division.  Relationships were not often good.  I was in a pivotal position, trying to augment US sales peoples' interface with clients in the US.  With NAMO help, we put a costly 16 wheel truck on the road in the US and it transported all the division's major products - for product demonstration across the country.  The building of the mobile unit was a laborious task, as was the coordination with sales managers in regions of the US to use the mobile unit for product demonstration.  The dot com bubble fueled the early success of the division, but management did NOT read the decline of the dot com frenzy.  Eventually the division was closed.  Very poor long-term projection skills and too much technical in-fighting within German/US division.  Not an easy place to work and be successful.
A typical work day consists of pulling financial information for various controllers. Whether that be orders, revenue or even gross margin and growth rates.
Agilent was a spinoff of HP.

I didn't work here for too long, but during that time I was given good training and access to plenty of additional training material which was great. The people I worked with had their ups and downs like most places but were mostly good-natured and easy to get along with. I attended regular meetings that allowed and encouraged employee input and management seemed to listen to what was on their employees' minds.

Agilent Technologies is the split between HP's computer and HP's test and measurement division. Great , clean working conditions, top of the line test equipment. Management was the best I've ever encountered in a manufacturing facility. Top end benefits , high pay scale, Manufacturing and Management cohesion. Flexible hours, always a professional atmosphere. It's unfortunate that this division closed.
The IT culture is no longer US based. All decisions are being made from India.
Limited supervision yet very productive. Peaceful work place, friendly co workers, constant workflow. Management was always available when needed.
Pace of work was appropriate and people were eager to listen to my recommendations also respectfully gave me their insight.
work with your co-worker and and learn things from them.
Regular 8-5 with work life balance
In the department I was in, there was not an ounce of HP Way left. I'm sure it's there within the company somewhere.....just not in CAG Marketing!!
learned a lot of new things about work . co-workers are ok. godd benefits to all employee.
Learned a lot. Great benefits. Good co-workers. Lots of employees.
i learned in sap-abap/4 Erp language,then i have total 3.4 years of experience in this domain.
they allow me to work qith different areas and resolve a very important situations

On the management level they seem to not divulge too much information and you need to coax it out of them.My coworkers are great . they are a fun group to work with. hardest part of my job is maybe keeping up with the work load.
Direct management was outstanding, but higher levels were too far detached.
As a contractor at Agilent I had a wonderful time getting to know the employees and management. everyone was extremely friendly and the idea of safety was always a priority.
Learn the new thing on Dicing wafer, nice management and nice co-worker.
When I worked at Agilent, the work it self was pretty simple once I got into the swing of things. Mostly worked by myself, got to listen to my iPod while I worked.
Very good employee relationships. High talent level. Competitive products driven by technology.

Agilent was awesome, I miss almost everything about it. It was just an environmnent that was really relaxed, pay was great, benefits were great. I really regret leaving Agilent at times, but it was time to move on.

Awesome! Great team environment. I was able to learn the high tech industry for electrical/mechanical equipment. Working with teams and on my own has enable the facility to be noticed throughout ISO and Accreditation facilities. The hardest part was to keep us in compliance for our International bodies. We are always monitoring processes and flows to insure "what we say we are doing" we are actually doing. The most enjoyable part of my job is my co-workers we work great together. I would say helping our company to stay as the "World Premier Industry" by meeting the business needs and our organization's goals and objectives is very rewarding.
good company to work with. Good lerining. Everything seems to be good. Recessio and other unexpected things has direct impact.

a typical day at work is confusion and hectic. I have learned more about using SAP and it's various processes.On the management level they seem to not divulge too much information and you need to coax it out of them.My coworkers are great . they are a fun group to work with. hardest part of my job is maybe keeping up with the work load. we currently only have three workers in the logistics dept and they will not hire anyone else. I feel the most enjoyable part of my job is the people I work closest to. they as I said already are a fun group.
Agilent was a great place to work and observed the HP Way.

Telephone follow up for purchase orders and data entry. Learned some different software applications for instance SAP. Management was great. My co-workers were very pleasant and helpful. This was not really hard but when it came to having our work and files audits it was tons of files but with our team work we always managed to get it done in a timely fashion. The most enjoyable part of the job leaving early for the major holidays and having off the day before Christmas Eve along with the day after and the day after Thanksgiving.
Excelent!!! Would love to go back to work there.
Agilent has 75% contractors, not very good chances of being hired full time
God company to work at
* Clear training of job duties and expectations along with use of the company's system and applications.
Excellent company to work, the best that i have and i don't thing I am a find a better company like Agilent.
This was one of he best work experiences I have had to date. The Management that I worked for was excellent i.e., easy to approach,
Typical Day at work - Purchase material and communicate with suppliers from all over the world.

I liked working at MBS, and it was a pretty open environment. I helped maintain the data enter at Agilent technologies. We checked servers, and kept the server location maps up to date. I learned a lot about standalone, large ADIC libraries, and data center maintenance.Our site was also the hub site for many stateside & international sites for MBS. So I have a lot of experience routing tickets to the correct team for assistance. Although my job wasn't a management position. The managers always asked for our opinions in improving the job site.
If you can manage the endless politics you will enjoy everything about Agilent. Their metric systems and reporting tools are poor so be prepared to not meet required standards.
Interesting work designing new products.
A great company that demonstrated the ability to morph in something new. Some slowness in the pace of change, but great values, strong management, solid business strategy
As a contractor at Agilent I had a wonderful time getting to know the employees and management. everyone was extremely friendly and the idea of safety was always a priority.
Nice working environment. Supervisors and fellow workers are very supportive.
Agilent is a exceptional place to expand one's career and find opportunities to learn different analysis techniques as well as expand one's knowledge of the Biotech area of expertise.
Had many resources to allow employees to develop skills and career
There is on other company to work for like this one

Typical day the last year I was at Agilent (temporary position) was mainly assisting vendor managers / contractors, getting them set up from the very beginning to the very last of their requirements to work either at Agilent site of offsite. Management was okay, but didn't really want to listen closely, too busy I presume. Loved my team of co-workers and they loved me! Hardest part of the job was when there was software glitches and having to wait for resolution of the glitches. Most enjoyable part of my job was a completely successful project completed and the "thank you" that went with it.

I worked in Shipping for nine years. Was the RMA coordinator. Which is receiving products back from customers. Inspect them and give to engineer to inspect. Then release credit to customers on Oracle system. Also did cycle count each morning of products. Helped ship products domestic and international. Ordered boxes from vendor for our department and checked inventory. Also loaded trucks that would go to airport each day. It was a very rewarding job.
Good benefits, 401k, stock options, Medical, dental, optical, 2 weeks paid vacation
Great company to work for but the salaries are low. Management is good from what I've seen. The business is growing so very busy.

I was disappointed at how unorganized they are,,,I worked there 10 sttraight days in Feb as a contractor and day 10 was when I got email, system log in abd started me SAP profile set up, I sat for 10 days with nothing to do....so sad the old HP was never ever like that...

RF - IF equipment primarily. Learned quite a bit about metrology. Management has really got to get in touch with supporting workers needs to complete tasks. Lack of support from management is the hardest part of the job. Most enjoyable part of the job is personal satisfaction from solving complex electronic problems.

Science remains supreme at this instrument company. It was a pleasure to discuss plans and and to help determine the future possibilities. The best part of the job was the ability to set priorities of the daily workflow.
Management by the numbers with no vision on the overall strategy. No commitment to long term goals.
There was cross training at the end. It keep me busy. I liked to be kept busy. It made the time there go faster. They kept me busy.
Agilent is a good company, only that it doesn't offer salary hike each year. Many complain that there is no salary increase within 10 years...
Great company with great benefits and a nice work environment
Great people, great work but not perminate. Very clean company with outdoor pavilian for social gatherings. Cater service for meals. Exercise area and Meetings for updates on all upcoming events.

Received a warm welcome to the work team, given specific instructions for each project, well organized management and staff. Intra-company social events, i.e. potlucks and BBQ's sponsored by the company. Work was pleasant giving a club like atmosphere. It was a joy to go to work each day, no matter what the task. Plenty of appreciation for the help proferred.

I’ve read a lot of the reviews on indeed for Frasier, and I agree with every one of them. Frasier is a great place to work if you take out the management side. The residents are super sweet and understanding, coworkers are amazing and you’ll find some of the best people  in all departments. However, the management gives you little to no support. The upper team management is all too concerned with what the CEO wants/ will make him happy instead of the residents. The management side of Frasier is really disappointing especially after you meet the nicest elderly population ever.

Typical work days were hectic and disorganized, this was mostly due to various aspects of upper management. They recently built a new facility in order to increase revenue. Paid time off is minimal, no floating holidays, no sick days but flu shots are mandatory. most federal holidays are not provided, no real retirement benefits, bargain-basement health insurance. The most enjoyable aspect of the job were the residents, who come from a multitude of backgrounds and tend to be very skilled and talented people.
Good benefits almost immediately when hired. Management is decent and pay is fair. A slower paced community but always things to do keeping a steady work pace.
I really don’t want to get into it so I’ll just start by saying this. Keep scrolling and do not give this place your time and energy. Management is manipulative and will drive you mad.

The environment is always one of change.  the CEO is an egotistical man who is not very smart.  He makes sure that only board members who will rubber-stamp whatever radical new idea he proposes are placed on the Board.  He only hires Upper Level Management that will support his radical agenda -- not ones who will actually stand up to bad ideas and hold him accountable.

I enjoyed working for Frasier the residents where wonderful to care for. the staff was also nice to work with. It is a relaxed place to work, and quite a bit of over time if you are looking for additional hours.
I really enjoyed my PT position with my first supervisor.  She was very interested in my recommendations for improvement.  We actively worked on a process improvement project until she left.
It's a good place to work with good management and the best part is the residents are soo much co operative and helpful. It is situated in the beautiful place which is safe.

Management is not to be trusted. Watch your back. Long term employees released and jobs eliminated without any notice. No loyalty. Wages are not commensurate with experience and lack of support for career development.
Caring work environment making it's way through changing times. This multi tiered facility strives at being the best it can be while paving the way for a new culture in new times.
Awesome place to work! Definitely fast paced, as you would expect in a nursing home/skilled nursing setting but staff was wonderful and residents were sweet.

Very disappointing place to work. The leadership/management team have no idea what they are doing and the place functions only because of over-worked, dedicated staff. The CEO and his "leadership" team are a joke. This place needs to be reorganized with a whole new management team. The residents are paying so much money to live here and they deserve better. Unethical decisions are being made regarding residents' care. Shame on the leadership team and Board of Directors for letting things get to this place and allowing it to continue dispite reports of employees reporting their concerns.

Poor leadership.  No training or support.  Many staff have gone years without having adequate training or support from their supervisors.  Focus is on the new building but the residents and staff currently living/working are being forgotten.  The onboarding process was poor-one day of computer training for basic info, the rest is "figure it out on your own."  Very disappointing.  Management needs to wake up but I don't think they care enough to change.

Management is not available and does not support staff.  Management is most concerned about making money and making sure their apartments are filled. Staff are overworked and staff are taking on roles that they are not trained for.  The leadership team makes it clear that they do not want to make changes.  There is no onboarding or training and staff are left to fend for themselves. The mgmt team has no sense of what is going on in the day to day operations, but ultimately they make the final decisions about things.  Staff are very stressed and unhappy.  Poor communication.  Many staff that are in leadership positions do not have the skills to carry out their job responsibilities.  There is a lack of support and guidance.  Many of the management team members speaks poorly about staff.  Management is not aware of the policies or procedures, or there aren't any in place.  Bad behavior-unethical decisions-by leadership is allowed.

I love working here, everyone is friendly, lots of opportunity for growth within the company. The PTO is amazing, and all employees receive discounted meals at the restaurant inside.Its also a beautiful building, well maintained. Amazing view of Flat Irons.
It is great place to work. I like working 12 hours 3 days a week. Great pay with good benefit. but, I wanted to work less days with more hours. I have children and 5 days a week is hard.
A good place to work, very little to no advancement opportunities. A place for the elderly so if you don't like all that comes with it not a good place for you.

Frasier Meadows cares deeply about their residents as well as their employees. Constructive criticism is always taken into consideration and they reward employees through positive reinforcement, which makes anyone happy to work there. My only issue is the Relias training that's due every month because it's hard to get that done while taking care of residents but that is my only complaint.
Frasier Meadows is filled with a lot of really great people to work with.  The residents are fantastic, educated and spirited elderly....loved it. I would work here, if I lived in Boulder.
Great job! Best ratios I've experienced in long term care where patients aren't in a lower level of observation than needed. Clean, beautiful, where almost all staff is happy!

I worked for Frasier Meadows for close to 11 years. I was lucky to be able to work in the Independent Living/retirement community area. Unfortunately, at the point when I left, the "family" feel that I had always enjoyed working at Frasier was being replaced with a more corporate attitude.

I’ve read a lot of the reviews on indeed for Frasier, and I agree with every one of them. Frasier is a great place to work if you take out the management side. The residents are super sweet and understanding, coworkers are amazing and you’ll find some of the best people  in all departments. However, the management gives you little to no support. The upper team management is all too concerned with what the CEO wants/ will make him happy instead of the residents. The management side of Frasier is really disappointing especially after you meet the nicest elderly population ever.

I loved working at Frasier and was sad when I had to leave to return to school as a full-time student. Mostly everyone there was extremely nice including management, HR, and residents. There were only a few co-workers that I worked with that did not treat me with respect. Overall, I had a great experience at Frasier.

Frasier Meadows is not a bad place to work. Everyone has fun during their shifts .Management needs to be more involved with the staff. At times and most of the time your co-workers can make you the point of interest. Not in a good way.
Frasier is the best place I have ever worked.  The staff is wonderful, many of them have been at Frasier for over 5 years.  The residents are so lovely and knowledgeable.

Typical day at Frasier goes by very fast and very busy but I love it. I learned vary much, learned managing my time, learned new skills. Management has been okay for me, once very supportive and then not so much. The most enjoyable part of the job is to being a problem solver for patients, family members, providers, CNAs and colleagues.
The CNA's are extremely overworked. Job functions had to always be performed in a rushed fashion. It always felt like you could not offer the residents the time needed for adequate care.
always busy, most everyone was great to work with

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.

Working at Ricoh is a contract position and can end at any time and it will. They pay below the national average and you are expected to do what ever the customer wants, they will make you do way more than the contract is allowed. Ricoh, I all about "YES" to everything and this is causing "Scope Creap" on the  account and employees will be way over worked and management will not do anything. I do believe in giving excellent customer service but, when management and sales just keep taking...this is not right.
Great if you are carrer driven and want to grow in different areas of skills. That can push you to the next level. Compensation can be matched to skills

Management is terrible.  There are problems with the machines which make performing your job extremely difficult but, management will ignore the problems and expect you to still make productivity.  Problems are not solved, they put a band aid on a bullet wound and keep it moving.
Ricoh is the best company to work if you are beginner. But no salary increase in 3 years and management wants to change entire system of company so hardware guys are struggling
They do nothing for their employees, other than pay them (and the pay isn't even great.) I rarely spoke with management unless someone had reported that I did something wrong. Poor management!
Easy place to work. Only thing is there isn't much by way of career growth. Nice facility and and it pretty low stress most of the time. They should work harder on promoting employee development.
Duties rarely change, and most days are predictable. Not the most exciting job, but fairly easy. Some days are more busy than others, and occasionally the work piles up.

As a Field Support Representative, I am placed at different sites on a weekly basis. I work with mailroom processing, print/fleet production, and occasionally reception. I get moved from one site to another up to two times a week. We don't see our schedule for the following week until every Friday, sometimes as late as 7:00. When we are sent to different clients, we are sometimes sent in blind in terms of "need-to-know" information. Management has poor communication skills and will leave you hanging quite often. I heard a rumor that they don't do raises, that rumor turned out to be true as I've not received a raise since I've been here. This company needs to learn how to treat their FSR's, how to maintain good communication, and how to hire and train competent leaders and managers.
There were layoffs every year. Always looking over your shoulder towards the end of every fiscal year wondering if it was your year for the axe to drop

You normally work alone depending on your site. Not a place for advancement. And raises are close to a cent or even a quarter if we are lucky. If you like working alone or in a small group, you will be fine.
Pay wasn't very good took 8 months on a temp basis to make it in. Day to day is basic logistic wasn't really any room for moving up so yearly raises sucked.
Flexibility and room for advancements.  Training via Ricoh website provides many opportunities to increase knowledge of practices  to help customers.
Found Ricoh to be a good place to wok with good people.  Learned a lot about the sales process as it relates to an analyst role in the industry.
Site management was terrible for print services. More focus needed on growing employees. Print services manager was not professional and utilized company time for personal gain.
Working here was a really good experience, everyone is very kind and friendly. The job itself is very straightforward and fun. You will learn new things everyday
Good place if you need a job but definitely a dead end job. Very toxic environment for being such a small group. Do not consider if you’re looking for long term.

The worst management I have ever worked for. Definite inequality in pay. Mistreatment and beyond disrespectful to staff. Horrible! Lousy pay. Lousy benefits. HR makes excuses for the managements mistreatment of staff.

When I first arrived, I enjoyed what I did. I enjoyed the managers and my co-workers. I took pride in my work and felt appreciated. However, over the course of time, things started to change it and became more about meeting metrics than anything else which was something they told me when I was interviewed that they didn’t do.
I’ve been here a few years and it has been good. I don’t think there will be any advancement. We are always afraid of being let go with the current situations. Pay is okay.
Management was really understanding and great to work with. Many opportunities to grow within the company. The scope of work was fun and not too difficult.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.
Office printers are like video machines. They are going obsolete.  Although we will still need printers they are all designed to be customer serviceable with remote assist service.

I have a supervisor that pretty much leaves me alone to run the shift however I need to. Pay could be a lot better, but I can pretty much do whatever during the shift as long as everything is done when it needs to be.

The Ricoh I worked at was a great place to work, I learned a lot and grew into the job. If I hadn't moved I'd still work there. Working with the hospital and making forms was interesting and educational.
If they'd just let the techs do their job without all the micromanagement, it'd be an ok place to work. My local manager was always great but area/corporate was always changing the goalposts

I was employed by Ricoh, but worked as a contractor for another agency. I really liked my job, but it could sometimes get confusing with all the different people to report to and rules to follow, sometimes seemed counterintuitive to follow Ricoh rules when the company we actually worked for had different ones.
I am payed lower than most on my team so pay in general might not be that bad. My direct

Ricoh is a great place to work if you’re just starting out. They have great benefits and offer lots of holidays. But I was also a contractor for SDGE and know that some of the holidays were due to our contract. There is not a lot of room from growth in the Copy Center. Most days are filled with minimal copying, and then a large job will come in that takes a couple of days to complete. The work culture here is quiet and friendly. If you’re in leadership, you can expect a lot of paperwork and meetings. Good first job, but not somewhere you can grow without years of experience.
Good benefits, somewhat decent pay.  Good for the self-starter types as management can be a bit out of reach.  Good vacation time, floating holidays but can be tricky getting coverage.

Not sure how this company is still a float with the way management glares down upon its employees. The complaints about workers only making minimum wage when the McDonalds down the street will pay $15 starting really wears you down mentally. Expectations are high and the pay is little.

Over the course of my employment with Ricoh USA, I had my fair share of managers. (this is due to Ricoh making changing within the company). Most of those managers were good people, but there are a few really BAD apples in there, as well.

I have worked for Ricoh for over 6 years and I can say it is a good company to work for. The customers and people you meet are very professional depending on the office you work in. And as an FSR or traveling service rep you are reinbursed for your travel time. As a contracter for Ricoh though there is very limited was to move in the company, you can on the other hand work at variety of different sites.

Typically, a good work environment if you can handle some level of stress.  Limited growth opportunities in some areas of the business.  Due to a shrinking industry, company has to constantly reinvent itself every few years.
No job security,  low pay overworked and management is a joke. Stay clear from this place !! Management is basis and clingy. Unfair advancements treatments and a unbearable work load

The best benefit is the work/life balance. The work is very easy, the workload is usually light, and there is little to no stress. Moving around in the company is relatively easy. The pay is terrible and you can go years without a raise. The benefits are pretty standard - medical insurance is high, two weeks of vacation for the first five years, sick time accrues slowly.

Great company , You work early get off late. Lots of overtime, . Great co workers and friendly environment. Days can be really busy but also some slow days in which you can work in the warehouse. you are guaranteed your 40 hours.
For a technician job, they pay waaay too little. They expect you to work as if they are paying you a livable wage but in reality, they are paying few dollars more than minimum wage.

I was paired with a senior Technician who gave me hands-on training. I was given the tools and training I need to Excell at my job. The hardest part of the job was Identifying what the problem was with the printer. But that was the challenge that I faced every day. Management encouraged me to take the time to learn the job and even kept me busy with different aspects of my job. I Loved this job.

They keep brining in new top management to 'clean up'. Once thousands of people have been laid off they move on for the next one to come in and continue. No one is safe anymore. It's impossible to feel safe and there's the constant fear of being let go.

Extremely poor management, with unrealistic expectations for the service technicians.  The main company purpose seems to be the production of thousands of spreadsheets full of meaningless "metrics".  All other activities are merely engaged in to produce numbers for the all important spreadsheets.   There is no recognition, no raises, and your job is constantly hanging by a thread.  At the whim of corporate Japan, literally anyone can be fired for no other reason than that they don't want to pay your salary and benefits.  Those that remain are expected to do the work of two or even three people.

Enjoyable workplace that's fast paced. Workload is busiest when school is in session, and management is always available for support or to answer questions. It's a great entry level job or first job right out of high school.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.

This could be a great place to work if senior management had a clue as to how to go about onboarding of new employees. There was no oversight as to what was expected in the position and my coworkers were only concerned with their own job security
Was a good company to work for until mass layoff and outsourcing to the Philippines.  They had fun group activities and fundraisers for food causes. A lot of long term employees.

It's copiers and every part of doing it is to service the company and any other person's agenda. Lots of finger-pointing. The tenured folks are just collecting their money so far into an inglorious career that they just finish it out. The industry is a bad one especially if you truly enjoy people. They'll cut your throat later.
Management has a loosing strategy. Poor maintenance of infrastructure creates constant downtime that turns into overtime.  Management has little interest in the people.
They aren't concerned with employees at all. Improving their income as a company is above everything. You  are just another number to them. Favoritism is strong in this company as well.
Bad leadership with no idea how to change with the times.  They don't value experience just want to hire for the least amount.  No job security no matter how you perform.

A circus like culture. Once you think you understand your role and leadership it changes.  Either the client changes their environment or the wonky upper management of Ricoh comes up with some new initiative or direction. Incredibly weak HR-outsouced to ADP-and your contact there is subject to change. The Ricoh managed services support staff (marketing and district manager) are laughable. Just stay out of the account and let me get the work done. Morale is terrible.

I was there four years before we were laid off. My direct manager was great, she set me up to succeed. The culture is good, they always had something going on for us like blood drives, cancer screening holiday pot lucks and monthly team outings.
If you like to drive from place to place this is the company for you.

No raise in 2 years. No advancements. Not given enough shirts to wear. I would not recommend this company to anyone. You are expected to do more work than one person. There is always open positions so we are always short handed.

Overall great experience, Great Team - good training, clear communication from management. Fun motivational meetings. Changes in CRM system at the time was a little confusing but we managed to get through it. I learned a good deal about technical sales and software packages.
Stable,  easy work for decent pay. Relaxed

I no longer work there but I recall a lot of stress on the job. It was a very fast-paced, monotonous position. It started out great - I was promoted from an associate level within six months, but moving up all depends on whether you are "in" with your current manager.
High tech office hardware/software company. A place to advance if you put in the effort. A lot can be learned. Good people. Stable and ethical management.
Ricoh is a great company to work for the benefits are great the ability to work at different locations is a great cross training tool and it helps you.

Ricoh did an AWFUL job of navigating COVID.  I believe they used it as an excuse to do what they wanted to do for years in decreasing their headcount by 25%.  They don’t care about their employees, only the shareholders.  Even loyal, hard working employees with long tenure are susceptible to being tossed out.  Hope your manager doesn’t play favorites, or that you’re the favorite, because you’ll be sent packing otherwise.

Do not work for this company,  they expect their drivers to be copy technicians since 35% of the techs were laid off due to the pandemic,  HR is not helpful at all when it comes to reporting safety concerns and they will not compensate you on the extra workload you are expected perform due to the pandemic, management is awful!!
Good hours and benefits. Nice location with overall nice people. Pay could be a lot better and more on par with today's standards. Culture is tough because everyone is treat very unequally.

Work is not fairly distributed amongst employees working in the same department/title neither is financial compensation. You will become stagnant due to management not assisting with or encouraging promotions. Very little room for growth.
I worked here for almost nine years fixing copiers. My manager was a decent guy. It wasn't bad but it's a typical impersonal corporate structure. Don't expect much advancement.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.

Ricoh provided a good place to work with great benefits and 40 hour weeks with occasional overtime when required. The people were great to work with and management was approachable. However, it is difficult to advance.
No matter what you do meeting KPI's are impossible. Management is  horrible and doesn't have a clue what is going on or how to resolve issues. It was a clown show.
I worked on 3rd shift which was good because it gave me time to take daughter to school, and pick up from school. And as job was relocating and I've worked on 2nd & 1st.

Before the pandemic, my manager was a mean, micro-manager who would try to dictate every part of the day even when she wasn't there. Once the pandemic hit, I couldn't be more relieved to be finally free from her! I got a week off until I got a depressing call that she had recommended me to work at another site -___-. This site was a lot better though! It was a copy center and, due to the pandemic, there wasn't much work to be done. I really enjoyed it there. Everybody (manager and co-workers) in the copy center was excellent. I miss them! There were days where I had to go to the mailroom which I HATED!! Eventually, they wanted me to stay in the mailroom and I just couldn't let myself go through that so I resigned the day they told me that I'd have to report there everyday instead of the copy center. </3 :( Overall, Ricoh itself is pretty good I guess. Good benefits, decent pay (?). Not really enough for me to move out comfortably on my own though. I heard some not-so-great stories about my first manager from co-workers at both sites and how many times HR has been contacted about her but nothing was done. Disappointing really.
There are no good words for this company from management on down. The only thing I could say if any, they definitely treat everyone the same....no respect

Easy enough job to handle and a decent pay for the work. Very big on scope of work (but doesn't matter in the end cause if the clients want something they'll more than be happy to oblige). Lot of busy work. Big on Acronyms.  As for on the job training, they'll team you up with some one for a few days to get the gist of what ever software you'll be using and then they'll pretty much provide you with the tools and training videos to figure out rest. So you have to have a learning mentality. I was fortunate enough to have a manager who would also assist me as I was looking for answers. My only issue is that wasn't a fan of the client I worked for. It kind of soured the company as a whole for me. However, someone else might have better luck.
I was very happy working those 10 years, then last year I had to quit. I got promoted twice. It’s a company that you can make a lot of money and the opportunity to grow.

Really wish management would get they stuff more organized and recognize those who are actually doing the bulk of the work and not the person that’s in your face most of the time just having a conversation that has nothing to do with work and gets work backed up for others to do. The committee team are the best people in Ricoh and is highly missed. Wish everyone was like the moral committee..
The most enjoyable part of the job was being out in the field and putting smiles on customers faces, when we walked in the door to repair their equipment.

Enjoyed working in the field but had my job eliminated due to Covid. My direct manager was great but upper management was only concerned about the numbers that would make them look good and yet were very disconnected to the field front line.

Very poor culture! Employees are treated as commodities, the Japanese culture does not value the individual. They change process without feedback or consulting the boots on the ground...they cancel things that work for things that are unproven....very odd approach. Managers are feckless due to corporate tyranny
great recruitment process, quick onboarding and great support, but frequent layoffs and reconstructions - if you have other options I would go with them.

Working for the company was okay. The pay was nice, good job security if you did the work. The training was good and paid for. It was stressful from time to time, especially when you can’t figure out what the issue is and you have calls to go to after. Good benefits.

Forget about calling in sick, because all your coworkers will have to pickup your slack. And if someone requested the day off, you cant call sick. Other than that they give great benefits! Every worker is disposable! So if you want a job where you can advance, this isnt the one.
Upper management will run this company into the ground.  'IT' sucks up too much company money.  Corporate in Japan only cares about the bottom line - dollars - and not its employees.
