I would focus on the large page print division that they bought from IBM after I left the company.  Management in Irvine was top notched and so were the high level technology people as well.
Compensation & benefits is pretty good. They have good principles but seem to be scattered all over the place. Very frustrating. Need better training

Benifits,direct manager and co workers are very good. The upper management asks you to do tasks you are not trained or hired for. They are monitoring everything you do. They do not give you all the tools needed to complete your tasks every day. Customer frequently must wait due to management.
Ricoh is a good place to work. Just need to show up and get things done. Great Vacation, Sick Days, and Great Work and Life Balance. Pay is still low.

This company is not inclusive and does misleads all potential candidates of position. This position requires beyond mailing and 80% of your work day requirements are in their contracted warehouse doing extremely heavy lifting without the proper safety equipment required. Poor training, clients lack communication and do not value each other. They say overtime is provided but you need a written with reason and signature to authorize overtime within a specific timeline. This company gives unfair pay. There is a lot of drama and unprofessionalism at this location. The companies policies are international. Lack of communication within its management.  They have one employee to do a three-man’s job. You are not to associate with the client or their functions to which they have many of. Ricoh employees are excluded. Lack of empathy. Payroll process is terrible, the process takes a month before you receive your first paycheck. They have you on a contract before they make you an employee with them and you end up with a huge gap in your pay.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.

This job fosters uncreativity. Taking initiative is discouraged. Everything is "company first." You must stay in your limited and specific role. Job description was misleading. I never would have applied if I knew this was at a hospital. Pay is terrible. Benefits are terrible, but advertised as wonderful; things that seem great at first actually aren't. Ricoh equipment is cheap and constantly breaking, making it difficult to do my job well.

Things were fine during the first two years in the Chesapeake, VA location. The management was pretty laid back.  Toward the pandemic, the dress code became more regulated, and the managers started breathing down their employee’s necks.  All of a sudden, mistakes were not acceptable.  Favoritism around the office became more apparent, and the favorites’ mistakes weren’t paid attention to.  In two months, I went from working in the office, working remotely, and then working at an Anthem location during the pandemic.

My summary of Ricoh  is a company that is a micro-managed company if you like that type of atmosphere. They pay their delivery drivers low for the amount of work they want you to do. Ex ..Ricoh expects you to deliver,  set up , connect IP addresses , transfer address books, train the customers and take the customers old copier . Oh did I forget they give you a  machine called a stairclimber to use if any stairs are involved  , by yourself to operate. Plus management will watch your time on the field if your taking to long and bring it to your attention and treat you like a little kid about it . Ricohs annual raises are a joke too...I've worked at 2 other places after Ricoh already and at both employers I was offered at least 3 dollars more an hour on average and the work was a quarter amount compared to what Ricoh wants out of you. So look at Ricoh as your last option.

I loved it at Ricoh. We only got let go due to being bought out by another company. My manager was VERY compassionate and understanding; always spoke to you like a father would. He actually LISTENED to what you were saying; not just hearing you and brushing you off. The job itself was interesting. You'd call an office and the conversations were just a hoot. I disklike the dress code, but I was pregnant at the time so trying to find that balance between comfy and business casual was difficult, especially in the winter time. I'd go back if we had the opportunity to. I just wouldn't want to drive in everyday. That got exhausting.
Company is struggling to identify its place and products. COVID has accelerated this change. Not sure where it will lead but I think the goal is to shift the entire sales process to regional dealers.

I actually enjoyed working for Ricoh quite a bit in the 7 years I was there. There was minimal micromanagement, pay was decent, and benefits were good. As the only Ricoh employee on-site, I felt well encouraged to make the site my own, and that feeling of ownership led to a strong personal connection to site goals. For the first 6 years, I couldn't have asked for more, however when the workload became too much for a single person site, help was very lacking and the production began to suffer. This was the ultimate reason for my eventual transfer, which was much too far for a daily commute, and it was more like I'd just been brushed under the carpet with expectations that I'd quit, and I did.
Good and bad, corporate America.  Low OT basically 9 to 5. Covid has been hard on the industry lots of furlough and some layoffs, see how the company can bounce back
Es un lugar de trabajo muy tranquilo,y el personal de la empresa son muy amables ,hay  coperacion a la hora de ayudar en el lugar de trabajo y me encanta mi trabajo de limpieza
Great work environment, coworkers easy to get along with, open path to advancement. Management always there to help with problems.

For a large company it was a real nice place to work. I switched careers from a Senior Service Tech for 10 years to Sales. A great move on my part. Left Ricoh for more money at a smaller family owned business.
The BS sites are not at all a friendly place to work most of their employees are rude and management is very incompetent and upper management has no clue of what's going on around them.

While my coworkers were outstanding, management is severely misguided.  The end user is their only priority. Their mission statement does not reflect the culture. I witnessed first hand favoritism over seniority. End users would request me to work at their site, I had nothing but positive feedback from the key contacts and yet I was laid off.  My peers in the same position as me where kept on board. I was deceived by management. They strung me along and ultimately let me go. I never had any corrective action or write ups. If you voice your opinion, ask questions or challenge management to see a different perspective you will be shunned. Stay far, far away.
To be successful  one must find ways to get the tools to get the job done. This can be tricky, because  the company is so regimented.

Many people see Ricoh as a stepping stone into the job market. The job is decent but the management flounders. l'm not sure why this is but they were punishing the techs for management decisions. The management is always right and the techs are always wrong. Teams have a good working relationship most of the time but the company policies don't make a lot of sense. It often gave me the impression that upper management didn't know what they were doing. Customer tools for the office environment were excellent but internal tools for doing the job were subpar like the management was easily bullied by sales reps and didn't take the time to see if the tools worked well for us. The climate often felt like "business as usual" no matter how many climate surveys we did.

I have been with the company for over 10 years. Though there was a boom following the last recession of new customers, there has been a constant loss of 1 to 2 customers per year over the past 4 years. Some of this is due to the staff on site, but most of this is due to failures from the sales teams to billing to management.

It's not worth it. Retail pays better (I've worked here for several years and Target pays $15 while we get just under $12). The pay raises are terrible. Management is horrendous. If you aren't one of their favorites, you get treated terribly. No one cares about health or safety either, and some site locations are covid hotspots.
Pay & benefits
Organization wants everyone to succeed.  Team shares ideas and thoughts.  You are held accountable.  Overall great company to work for.  Growth opportunities available.
Good place to work and increase your professional life with great co-worker people ready to help went needed.

Ricoh's managers suck. They are afraid of employees knowing to much and fear for their positions in the company... My direct manager had to make up an issue to get me fired. But also forgot that when I was at home with a 100 degree temperature he had someone come get me to work that day.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.
Work-life balance

The only good part about this job is its only 8 min from my home and my supervisor is flexible about life obligations i.e. appts, etc. Other than than that, the pay compared to the work required is laughable, no annual raises, they hire you for one thing and expect you to do everything...they don't show appreciation for their hardworking employees. Lots of lies and underhanded sneaky things going on among management.

I can say that this is/was an interesting working moment. I gave my rating because the job itself starts off ok since you're learning the ropes...However that begins to quickly fade once you begin to fully work work.. Between the team and management (before new management arrived) the experience was/is horrible. When you think you can go to upper senior for help, but don't ask for help when they are finished with their work because they think you are interrupting them. You're better off learning a few things on your own. There is a lot of gossip so please be careful of what you say to some "co-workers" because your words will get twisted around and next thing you know your in the office with a manager. Instead of an individual talking with you first to solve an issue.
I loved working for this company. My boss was the best teacher and made sure you knew what you were doing. An excellent work environment and room to grow!
This is a failing company, mostly due to old school management. They do not listen to employees or customers. Company is lucky to be surviving right now. Do not work here

This company doesn't care about their employees.  Lots of favoritism. No matter how loyal you are to this company, they have none to the employees. You can be there for years and not get the deserved respect. That is one of the reasons of the high turnover rate.

Unrealistic expectations of the sales staff.  Turned into a boiler room telemarketing job, low pay, expensive healthcare and the product you are selling they can't deliver.  Sales managers have no knowledge of the products or the processes and can't help you.  The Directors (3) and the VP of Sales are totally disconnected from the sales staff and don't listen to valid concerns that drive revenue, increase profits and keep quality sales people on staff.  Bottom line they are a broken operation with no direction or desire to fix the problem. Advise to Middle management is to step up to the plate!  Make your sales managers accountable for supporting your sales teams or provide sales support to them.  You have to invest in supporting your sales staff in order to achieve success.  If I had one of my sales reps go to a manager for help and they said they didn't know and walked away, I would say they are in the wrong position.  How can you manage a team of sales reps and not know how to do the job yourself!  To the Directors and the VP of Sales...start putting qualified managers in place instead of the "guy you like."  The "guy you like" doesn't always do what makes you look good nor is he qualified to "LEAD" a team to success!

The co workers (most) were outstanding.  But then they had the lame butt kissers. They would make stuff up, and the bad managers (most all managers were bad)  would threaten to write you up or call HR.  HR sided with management, even if you had proof.  Management would constantly violate the company's principals and code of ethics.  Nothing would be done about it.

Management wasn't the best. Communication wasn't so good either no balance. Only thing that made it good working there was my co-workers. Had to fix a lot of managements mistakes and would get no credit.

They got rid of all but a small percentage of their sales people, hired telemarketers to sell equipment they've never seen, they've gotten rid of a majority of their senior, experienced and talented technicians either by poisoning the work well, early retirement or voluntary separation and hired unskilled,much lower paid, inexperienced people to replace SOME of them. They're losing market share, reputation and a ton of money.
good place to work...IF THEY CALL ME BACK ILL GO BACK..learn alot /made some good life time friends..great work experiences/freedom/had my own territory witch I managed /two other tech..

Great people to work with and great benefits, I just feel there is no room for growth to advance to other opportunities within the company. Currently still work here but looking else where to exceed more in growth and pay.

Great place to work if you’re friends/buddies with management. Entirely too much favoritism is shown to employees who have relatives or friends in upper management. The higher your position, the less work you do.

Ok company to work fore.management is  ok . Coworkers made the job easier as you build relationships with your coworkers. The job is not that demanding answers you get to interact with customers  in a daily basis

I enjoyed the whole process of this company, interviewing, working, and through the pandemic,  Their hiring process, compensation, opportunity for advancement, and learning the work, I feel was more than fair.  It was very exciting to get to know the city with a position that one was able to ease into with little to no stress.  I miss it, I would love to work for them again.

Constant harassment of low end employees by management to find activities to fill the day due to lack of work at customer offices..I would not recommend this company to anybody to hire into because they will dispose of you like a piece of garbage when they are done with you. No company loyalty to employees but they expect employees to be loyal to the company.

Going down hill.  Layoffs.  Techs doing same job with 2 techs that 4 use to do.  Don't have clear direction of where service dept. is going. Micro managed. Poor dispatch system. Upper management will lie to you.

Ricoh does not care about their employees, they will not be honest with you. I worked there almost 20 years and they eliminated my position and forced me into taking a job with a dealership only to meet their needs with no concern about my needs and would not pay me the severance pay because I went to work for the dealership because I needed a job !

Pay could be better. Too many cooks in the kitchen.  Not everyone can be the boss at the same time.  My training was very inadequate.  Luckily I have a background in the field of my work I'm doing.  Unfortunately not everyone else does and it's difficult to explain how things should be done.  They're so used to doing it one way whether it's right or not.
Enjoyed my time at Ricoh Business Systems. I was afforded the opportunity of installing Lotus Notes , & Windows 2000 Active Directory Servers.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.

Working here is manageable if you only want to stay in one position without any real chance of moving on. There was so much drama especially with shipping and receiving department. There were well qualified people passed up for job roles that others received and had no experience. Mostly based on favoritism. Good Luck
Liked working there. Pay was decent. Commute was awful, due to heavy Atlanta traffic & distance from home. Specialists helped in troubleshooting issues when needed.
Ricoh has no idea how to grow their revenue. Company is lead by old copy machine salesmen that are just trying to get another couple of years out of their job so they can retire.

A lot of fun activities for employees, but a lot of unproductive meetings. Good workplace culture. Unnecessary meetings or too long, unproductive. Low inventory availability for sale, is hard to sale without inventory. Great customer service.
The company has been laying off for the past several years.  So many changes that there is no clear future of the company.
Management
Ricoh is a ever changing, fast past company. If you are quick to adapt, hard working, and are competitive...you will love this job. Culture is great!
No room for advancement and definite favoritism.  Lack of clear training causing people in same positions to be at different levels and issues among each other.

Pay was good, benefits were there sooner than most employers.  My position location changed regularly but that was explained when I was hired.  Management for me was fine.  I only left because the varying schedule did not really fit with my family life.

Where to start.....Extremely poor leadership, outdated selling methods and ineffective management. During my tenure, I had two terrible managers, they were essentially “babysitting” an undesired and unprofitable territory and directed by an ego driven leader who resorts to bully tactics and fear to “get things done” Horrible for people just getting started in the business and who are new to the company. I would not wish this place on my worst enemy.
Ricoh is like any large multinational company: it all depends on your coworkers. My co-workers were great. However, Ricoh's wages are a bit low in the local area.
It's an okay job for the work, though the coworkers can be rude and untrustworthy, but you can find a few that are alright. Management can get up your a r s e about things.

Staff leaving almost daily, redundancies in very high numbers since the start of Covid. All staff on Ricoh Europe contracts mandated to book 5 days holiday and work them, which is shocking. HR working hard to push the reduced workforce left to pick up the extra work. The ethics are really being brought into question from the board and executive levels.
This is one company to stay away from if you are employed with their service partnerships through law firms.

Good company to work for long term. Decent pay with great benefits. Training is provided for essential job skills. The ability to plan your work schedule daily allows for freedom to work efficiently at your own pace.
Everything is so so.  Average pay, average work culture.  I worked at smaller office so maybe it is different at a larger corporate office.  Decent chance for advancement if you work hard.M
Managers really want you to succeed at the job/site you are sent to. They will move you if they recieve serious complaints but if you have issues with your job site they will support you!

Very slow especially during COVID, no chance of more than 1% pay rase and little to no room for advancement. The benefits were atrocious. And lots of positions required working from multiple sites as well as mulfi schedules
Was very stressful job,20 t0 30 customers a day per tech. No matter how many service calls you did or happy customers hounded to do more. No appreciation or raises.
Ricoh is what you make it, honestly! That concepts applies to most walks in life. The resources and opportunities are all there, how you exploit them is the question.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.
I enjoy working in Ricoh, I have not had any problem with Managment, the only thing negative i can say about the company is they need a better training process.
Work-life balance

My job was busy, exciting and incredibly different everyday. At the offsite location for ExxonMobil the workplace culture was HEAVY for safety and safety enforcement for all employees and contractors due to the nature of the company. I learned on-the-job first time how to "endure" this new culture starting on my first day! It was very difficult at first. But my manager was wonderful at showing me how to do and what to do. I worked closely with the safety team and the other managers to provide all levels of support for whatever they needed and for all team members. This is what I enjoyed the most about my job there. All the people, supporting them, communicating management decisions, and helping my managers.
The pay is great but very little support for remote positions. If you're new to the industry, you'll have to do a lot of learning on your own and the products are constantly changing.
I was only working as guest relations (receptionist) for a short amount of time. I'm glad I left when I could. I would avoid working here at all costs. Nothing to do all day..
That the so called supervisor /manager was not a good leader if he didn't like the way you were doin your job his way then you wasn't getting the money you deserve
Management was Great, Workplace Culture was Diverse, Hardest Part of the Job was calling it a day, The most Enjoyable part of the Day was coming into work, Everything, Great Place to work..
Your under paid and over worked for a job that always looking to cretic you about your work this a revolving door started $10 after 4 years $10.85 no
Great benefits. Good working environment. Great clients.  Wouldn’t trade this job for nothing. This job is better than most contracting jobs.  And Ricoh has sites in most of the state.
Mature Industry. Not a lot of opportunity. Not much for employee growth. They are trying to move the direction more to a digital transformation but the process seems slow.

I have served as both a field representative and an onsite representative, and the field position is the better by far. As a field rep, you cover onsite reps for sick and vacation days. Sometimes you get assignments a day or two before but it's normal to get your assignment the morning of and report for work at a site. Every site is a little different but generally as long as you are ready to help and attentive they appreciate you. As you are covering different sites the hours can vary anywhere between 7 am to as late as 7 pm. You only work 8 hours though and as a field rep you get compensation for mileage. The only real difficulty you may experience is traffic, as you are usually going to be going into a site during rush hour and because you are receiving assignment sometimes the same day it's impossible to plan around the traffic. But you will not be considered late if you are stuck in traffic after getting assignment the same day. You also get to work in different work environments and different locations with new people all the time. It is a different story being an onsite rep though. The client's and some of their staff can be incredibly fickle and demanding. For example, the acceptable procedure for processing mail can work for a staff with about 20 different secretaries but you will be asked to do things differently for just one. And this will be normal for several procedures. You will also see mistakes made and deal with them but if you make an error it becomes a grave situation. Some site leaders are also lacking in leadership qualities as they are usually promoted

I believe that Ricoh can work on paying their employee's a better salary. Taking a trip funded by the company is OK but, giving a increase to accommodate the cost of living would be greatly appreciated.

Managers play favorites, cliques are everywhere, and nearly everyone will stab you in the back to get ahead. If you choose to work there, don't trust anyone. Also understand that this is NOT an American company. This is a Japanese company, with Japanese rules and expectations, that happens to be based in America. Read up on the Japanese business culture before accepting a job with them. For example, no wastepaper baskets allowed, smiling and talking are discouraged, and long hours are expected.
Incompetent Blind Leading the Blind...
Lots of travel and management lets other reps cherry pic your opportunity.

love the work as a technician, hate the micromanagement from the upper management,  my job was easy and i enjoy dealing with clients one on one. at the end you are just a number and i'm OK with that, they do talk a good talk about ethics but they force   employees to break them to meet the numbers.
I got in trouble for doing the right thing, retaliation is common. The pay is low. Just a bad work environment all around. The management is some of the worst I have ever seen.

A typical day started at 8:00 am - 4:30 sometimes 5:00 pm. I would pick up breakfast for the employees. I would pick up the daily mail from the post office an then distribute it into the job mailboxes. I would get my first assignment from my onsite supervisor. I would then begin my first courier  run of the day. I would deliver or retrieve the private documents. I was required to get signatures on delivery forms as proof of delivery. Meeting new people on my daily courier runs was the most enjoyable part of the job.
I enjoyed helping customers, however, getting repair parts became a difficult process. Keeping up with call volume became difficult with short staffed and micromanaging.
The guys I worked with and the supervisor were all helpful in my experience of working at Ricoh, from the loading and unloading process to performing the installs on site.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.

People are great pay is not always as competitive as some places. Benefits are good. Depending on the site you're at situations/culture wise may be good or bad. The main goal is to keep and grow accounts no matter what.

Great place to learn and develop your tech skills software and hardware. Typically service printers, install, repair, and upgrading software. You must have initiative and an aptitude to learn on your own.

Horrible pay physical work moving copiers long days depending on your route management is clueless raises are a joke poor raise or no raise at all no bonus no holiday parties nothing don’t get acknowledge for your hard work but make one mistake and your a loser no good driver require more and more from the drivers always trying to add to job duties and no raises this place is trash everyone steals toners to get by and do workers are like women

Ricoh has been good to me over the years, they have good benefits and lots of vacation time.  The company is going through some hard times currently due to Covid.  Its a pretty casual dress everyday and they put a gym and game room in a few years ago for the employees.

Supervisor teaches me lot of things.  Ricoh is a strong company based out of Japan. Lots of classes to take online.  I'm getting to know lots of people who work for Ricoh and at US Cellular. Still working under Covid -19 guidelines and still wearing a mask. Workforce is lite. 8/18/2020.

I came on with Ricoh in March of 2019. The job was very different from anything I've ever done before, but they were offering paid training, so I went for it. Things started off alright with my mentor, but after about a month, they considered me "ready" to go out on my own. Beforehand, my mentor would explain minimal things to me, but not enough to where I was ready to go out on my own, but that's what management wanted. Of course, I found myself having to call and ask for help from my mentor, but his answer was always "look in the manual". So most of this job ended up being a self-teaching/learning, trial-by-error experience. Eventually, I started to pick it up, but at that point was when I started noticing certain things with the company. For example, how ridiculous it is to give customers the power of "escalating" service calls. Most of the time, customers would escalate a call AFTER you already looked at their machine and told them when a part would be arriving for it. They would escalate it because they wanted the part to arrive faster than the expected time, and of course, upper management then gets on the technician's back and that goes against their productivity rating. And to make matters worse, RICOH started laying people off (like me, and even people that have faithfully worked for them for 38+ years) because of this pandemic. In other words, they said "let's screw them before they screw us" and expect us to be fine with it. Then they started drowning the remaining technicians with more service calls than one person could handle. It's a shame too because I really
● Overall
I met many different people throughout 18 different sites that I covered. it was a perfect fit for me.  I was trained in many different positions throughout the company
This was one the worst places I have ever worked for.  The management was not supportive of their employees.  Many times it was an environment of CMA.  Very high stress environment.

This company is a terrible place to work at . Theres no job security, all they caer is about there numbers and not there customers. They make there employees work there 8-5 then be on call all night. They don’t caer about there employees.
Ricoh was a company that did not encourage growth within the company. No incentives and the management was not supportive.

Great job until Ricoh took us over. Poor vacation policy, poor pay, insensitive management and total disrespect for employees. I worked there for 22 years and did not even get a phone call or any recognition when I retired.

I hated this place. Management was horrible and changed several times while I was there. I only stay because of my coworkers, they made the job bearable. Most of the machines used to perform you job break down daily causing you to have to work even harder. Most of them are under paid. Dealing with Management was like being in high school again. Messy, favorite and other inappropriate work behavior.
Great place to learn new products, new facilities. Benefits are great. Many locations to choose from. Your success will depend on the manager liking you.

I believe Ricoh has a bit of a bad rep here on Indeed, which is understandable to a degree. For one the pay/benefits as you start out are pretty  bad. I started out making 15.14 an hour, but once you add in the mileage and car bonus would have been a few more dollars than that. So that's one factor to consider, your pay would depend on your productivity. I was still severely disappointed to be making so little to say the least. However the positive side is that the work was interesting, you learn a lot, the job duties were good (such as being on the road) and the company is practical (such as having several small raises for the first few years). Aside from this (as you can see by the pay) they have a bit of a cutthroat attitude and wont hesitate  to lay you off, cut your hours, cut your pay etc.

The job structure of this company is lacking in many ways. The management does not care about a person's well being or any opportunities that an employee wants to take within the company. It is decent pay but it is not worth the time and effort when the job duties are not clearly laid out and there is lack of communication at every location. Definitely not worth the headache and you will get written up for everysmall incident.

I worked for this company 3 years, broke 2 bones on my neck because they kept getting rid of people and making me do their work for FREE, they lost the contract and they laid me off hurt and told me if I get a job with the company that got rid of them, they won't pay me severance, they messed up and want to take me down with them, their raises are like .15 cents an hour every year

After the daily morning meeting, I was on my own which was a good thing.  Management was ridiculous.  Certain employees did what they please; whether they came to work on time, or didn’t come at all, and still was counted present- nothing was never said. Go figure that. Other employees, no matter how well they worked or showed up to work, management was never satisfied. Long story , short  ; that’s the best they ever had so I guess that’s why they do what they do.
The boss is fair willing to work with you. Co workers and nice and will to help if you have any questions. We work together if there is any problems. Everyone is just friendly

Was hired on as a FSR (field service representative). The job itself was very easy, you are basically a substitute or abled body to cover various positions and tasks for services within you market or region. RICOH is a managed services company meaning they contract with other businesses to do the tedious work for them. In most cases they were mainly mail, reception, hospitality and print services. RICOH will deploy a team to service the company for the set amount of time the contract exists, until terminated. While employed I had witnessed incredibly high turnover. Most places I covered for had many complaints and internal dismay among the employees, but management will never take action in fear that they lose the contract early. Managers care more for the contracts than the employees. There is no room for growth as there is no structure to job level or position. You can become a supervisor for a contracted service or a manager, but pay will not change, just your responsibilities. This company has very poor communication among management as well. The company had a solid foundation of preaching positive work attitude and had a fairly strong campaign in leading the managed services field, but updates rarely impact the contracts. The company has good intentions on services provided, but often time the managers have a hard time fulfilling those intentions by poorly executing them to the teams. The FSR role paid decent, but not enough for the living expenses in the area. Along with on call schedules, your week and days can always change. As an FSR we also had other duties to help

Great working invironment;able to interact with alot of people(students and faculty);manager offered suggestions in moving up with the compay;company has excellent benefits

Review incoming stock for refresh. able to work with different computer systems. The managers I worked with were easy to work for.Given a chance to work with imaging developer to improve system, and assist legal department in backing up and clear systems for recycle process. Assist management with warehouse inventory and stock.

It's okay when you first work for the company,,,But the only one who gets any were are the ones that tell's the manager everything!!! You work hard everyday and on time/ never called out and they don't recognize you.

Had good local management, very supportive sales manager, excellent service managers. Co was attempting to drive software sales along with their hardware, and began gaining some traction. However, corporate laid off the entire US Commercial Sales force and moved the business to their dealers, .
There are very limited opportunities for advancement, culture embraces tenured in place management. Expect a reorganization every 18 months or so which result in quiet job emiminations

Turnover has increased substantially in recent years and management has shifted from taking care of customers to micromanaging employees to produce pet metrics. The company fails to negotiate contracts that allow them to stay profitable and then uses up their employees hoping to make their profit off of internal savings and productivity. They will use up your physical health and use up your vehicle and replace you as soon as they think they can get someone younger and healthier to repeat the process. The company used to take pride in empowering employees to service the customers. Now we are told to not talk about things that are impeding us from providing the service our customers deserve.

I don’t have any complaints, they always take care of their employees. An awesome please meet new people and become good friends. Which, automatically gets you to where you need to go in order to be successful.
In this industry Ricoh has to be one of the best places to work. The equipment is excellent and the support and infrastructure are great. all allows the employee to accomplish the job as needed.

I am just going to use one word "THANKFUL" and to know management put the employees health and safety first. I  learned to listen closely to customers concerns & needs. To focus and leave customer satisfied with the help and information that I provided to them.
This is a stressful and challenging place to work. There's a lot to learn in short amount of time. You're on the road all the time. If you can handle this part of it...that's half the battle.

This was one of the worst companies I ever worked for. Management sucks no structure in how things are done if they don’t like the way you do a job they have a issue with you. People that are the favorites make mistakes and it’s cover up because they have a family member who works for the company. They blame it on other workers and fire them. They also love to micro manage your work. The environment is very hostile to work. They also promote a person not because they deserve it because they are friends with management.
Great company, terrible supervisor. He plays favorites and the moral is DEAD. Most of my coworkers get along, but the manager sees it as a threat to his ecosystem.

It is a good, stable place to work if you need a McJob to pay the bills. Don't expect any career advancement or performance feedback. You are just a warm body. For the most part, the work is fairly low stress.
Muy buena, sobre todo a nivel entre compañeros, sin olvidar el resto de aspectos (S. Técnico, Dirección, Personal responsable del Cliente, el propio Cliente, etc.... )

There are 2 sides to Ricoh Managed Services: Field Support Representative (FSR) and Site Specialist. FSR's are mostly mobile. They may have what amounts to a "base" site that they go to on a regular basis, but are available to fill in at any Ricoh site that needs a person to fill-in for some reason. They may have a schedule made out in advance for the week ahead, but they are still "on-call" to go to a site that may be short-staffed that day. This means their schedule can and does change day-by-day and even in the course of a day.

I love the Company, and everything about it.  Ranked among the Most Innovative companies the World, with a client success list of 74% of Global 1000, Ricoh's $20 billion solutions portfolio is solid.  My position is being eliminated June 30th, 2020 (COVID); Going to miss it so bad, it pulls my heartstrings.   There isn't anything I wouldn't do for them.
Continuation of IKON as Ricoh-USA bought IKON 2008.
Very hands-on job. You learn a lot of things. Best management team. Work place culture is not too bad. I don't think there are any hard parts of the job.

I worked in many of the local law firms in the downtown Seattle area.  Most of them were very nice, I would have even considered working for them full time.  Getting a permanent position in one of these offices happens one in 10 contractors.  There's the catch.
Ricoh cares about the employee wellbeing and makes sure that we have everything we need to work diligently and with passion. Excellent training and ergonomics.

awesome place to work for yhe whole team always trying to help the newbies. If everybody successeds then everybody successeds. Highly recommended if you like hw.
Loved every single thing about this job however due to unforeseen circumstances I had to give up my position. Supportive team and a ton of fun while we got the job done. Absolutely miss this job!

Ricoh does not support employee growth unless you kiss your bosses but. I am supposedly being laid off due to COVID 19 however I feel that my boss is using that as an excuse. I have bent over backwards for Ricoh, working long hours but not getting paid overtime.
I enjoyed working at Ricoh. The managers were very supportive. It was a fun work environment. I learned alot working there. They were flexible with getting time off.

Good job to work no stress supervi zdx ors very cool plenty of hours and overtime if neederd drivers are underpayed they keep giving drivers more responsibility without more pay

Was hired as a Site Mgr into the most abusive, hostile work environments. From day one, some of my staff set a plan to get me fired. These people abused Ricoh, Western Union and their coworkers. Had to quit as I was getting ZERO support from my management. Human Resources knew all about the abuse and hostility and all these people still work at Ricoh. All of them should be ashamed of themselves. Yelling, swearing, threatening coworkers with box cutters, racial remarks. I was setup by Management who knew all this was going on but failed to mention it. Ricoh boasts about their ethics but letting people get away with abuse and threats is the norm. The former Site Manager, the NOM, the sales team, the employees who were let to run wild and continue to do so at RPS, should all be fired. I am still traumatized by what was allowed there and still considering a law suit against all parties involved. Defamation, abuse, hostile environment... a can of worms to be uncovered by an attorney.
On-line education available to improve your sales skills and business and business acumen.  Learn to speak to the IT world if you have not sold software solutions previously.

Very nice place to work, very friendly co-workers and overall a happy environment. For myself workload is not too bad however I know others who really struggle. Ricoh is a good company to work for and solely focus on the well-being of their employees. Salary is very competitive with others.
no support from managers ricoh lost the site to another company and didn't care about the employees.no future and support from company, HR didn't work with employees

Your career will be based on an obsolete technology and a set of experiences that no one trying to be successful 21st century technology will have much interest in.

This is not a good place for anyone to work they have no sense of core values whatsoever and the management sucks. I would not recommend this company to anyone based upon the atmosphere and location.

The work is easy once you learn it. My boss is awesome. Upper-management doesn't really understand what we do. The pay is low but the benefits are good. They only promote within the team but there isn't much to be promoted to. The only real down side to this job is the pay, otherwise it would be 5 stars. You do sit in front of a computer all day but they allow us to where headphones while we work. It is a very relaxed environment. Would definitely recommend this job to someone at the beginning of their career. Great experience and a good place to transition into a work environment.
Example: I obtained my Net+ certification and I was promoted and given a raise. They have college tuition reimbursement, but you must follow the proper procedures to get it.

Field Service Representatives have a variety of work locations and hours, Site Specialists are placed at a specific location. Due to contract requirements, there is little flexibility in hours, gettting time off for personal needs, such as doctor appointments can be challenging.
Overall a fair place to work. Management not very fair. Busy on your feet all day. Many packages are handled daily. Lunch is hour and campus food is good. Many choices
Good products in a very competitive industry. Company is going thru major change and restructuring making job security a challenge. Overall great experience.

aluing structure, rules, and respect for authority, Dojo Masters take a careful, thoroughly-planned approach to achieving their goals. When I started this job, there were two people on-site; a manager and a Service Specialist. After about 1.5 years, they got rid of the manager potion leaving just the service specialist (me). Not only was I now doing the work of two people, I was also expected to do managerial work (reports, data reporting etc). This would have been fine but I revived no additional compensation for the work being done. You see the person above you maybe once a month unless they decide you're doing something wrong and I was left out of many conversations that involved me.

I worked for Ricoh. Senior management team was involved in many solution and pricing processes to ensure sales and clients objectives were met. Ricoh provided a great environment for innovation. A company with great futur growth.

Started as a Field Support Representative traveling site to site, day to day depending on the needs of the district learning about the companies managed services and getting familiar with them each site manages different services based on the customer needs (Print shop/ Printer Fleet, Mailroom, Shipping/Receiving, Reception, etc.)After a year was assigned to a permanent site doing Shipping and Receiving and Mailroom services for our client. This is a great job for someone looking for a job with a variety of duties. Many employees have been hired on by the company being provided services you meet lots of great people and make great connections to network out to. The only downside is there isn’t much room for growth within the company unless you personally know someone up higher. Decent pay and great benefits for full time employees

If you are talented, inovative, educated, and career minded go to another company. This ship has hit an iceburg and is sinking. If a site you work at closes or the contract moves to another company you have only 30 days to find another job within Ricoh. This includes the 30 days you are wrapping up your present position. It causes employees to scramble to find something before they are terminated. a paycheck. I am not required to tell you anything about my work experiences. This is intrusive and unfair. requiring information about my previous employer is not ethical.

If you are female and single, you will succeed here. Supervisors and managers do not care for anything else. The training is poor. The environment is totally unprofessional. Ricoh is a great company to work for. My time with the company has been amazing. The management is fantastic and the benefits are really good. The pay is where I have had some issues, not because they don’t pay well because they do it’s just not enough for me to support my family.

It is a fun and productive workplace.  I am only writing this because I need to fill this space with one hundred and fifty characters.  Eny, miny, moe.

this is a great on-campus job and a wonderful opportunity for a starter job. Coworkers are very friendly. Richo is very a patient place and is willing to teach. They understand mistakes and help you learn so you do not make the same mistake twice.

i do not recommend working for this company.  job is fun and keeps me busy. no team work or communication. constantly blame gets put on the newbie or the one that's different.

Eternally trying to revise business, and cut costs which means more layoffs on fairly consistent basis and generally poor morale. Is the result of perpetual change.
Management was ok but communication was missing. Took advantage of you and well underpaid. Customers would work with you but was leary of the company and equipment.
Enjoyed working hard to meet daily production quotas. Liked being able to put in as much overtime as I could to earn more money. Enjoyed having a job so close to home with so little of a commute.
Ricoh is a paycheck, it is not an enjoyable place to work, however. There is really very little guidance at the company and any advancement is virtually nonexistent unless you are in the club.

Managers and above do not lead by example and do not lead at all.  No foresight is present it is knee jerk reactions to any event that has happened. Good company to work for with lots of travel opportunities. Gave me an insight on the business aspect of technology and how its used in a business professional environment.
This is one of the worst places I have ever worked, The pay is horrible and they put all of this work on you. Management is horrible, they don't fight for you.

The job at Ricoh is pretty simple in every department in my opinion. It only gets stressful due to lack of communication or employees doing their jobs half way.

I dont have anything to say really. The company itself is a good company. Minus slot of flaws in leadership as far as professionalism.  It it the only flaw of the company. With a better leadership team it would be a OUTSTANDING company.

Company doesn't pay decent salary or commissions.  Benefits are not that good either. If you are a college graduate you may consider spending here a year and a half the most for the experience. Also technology sales on your resume may provide an opportunity to transition to medical or Pharmaceutical sales.
I enjoyed working at Ricoh because the hours were very convenient which gives me time to spend with my family when I get home from work. God along with everyone that I worked with
Nice place to work  The environment is great the people or nice and friendly. The parking is great. The break room is awesome, game room is nice also.
It’s there way or the highway. Doesn’t mater what skills you have they want everything done their way even if you prove your way is better. Way to much red tape to consider changing their procedures

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.

I was part of the joint venture between IBM and Ricoh in 2007 that led to the spin off of IBM's Printing Systems Division to Ricoh completely in 2010. The Japanese ownership whittled away non-strategic products of the business leaving just Production Print hardware and strategic software offerings.

It use to be stable work but now they are downsizing frequently. If you are highly productive you will have a good chance of a long career there. Make sure you stay in a position you are highly qualified for.

Ricoh is all about customer service, and wanting to help customers through their devices and technical services when needed. Ricoh will do their best to assist their customers with any help they may need on their ricoh equipment

This is a great company for someone who is good at troubleshooting. The pay is pretty good but the company seems to be heading in a new direction for technicians. Learning how to service other equipment is becoming a must so, either keep up or get left behind. Overall a good place to work.

They Offer a lot of technology to a Corporate levels in Japan what you get in the NY Metro Area there are Leaches that dress the part.  Good Company Horrible Management. However great upcoming younger prospects that are devoted to the Company.

Great corporate culture, higher management and corporate leadership is always supportive across all functional levels and willing to help navigate corporate processes as well as professional and personal growth.
I loved working for Ricoh until July 2017 when the layoffs began and
I learned a lot at Ricoh it was one of the company you want to work for.Most the thing i enjoyed about  working at Ricoh how the treat they employees.
I always had support from my Service Manager to succeed. The most enjoyable part was always having a happy customer when done servicing there equipment.

The management sucks. I was site supervisor at a site and was never properly trained had to figure out everything on my own. When I transferred sites I still was never trained. I had manager that was never helpful or around because he focus on other sites. After all this I had HR called on me serval times because the FSR never like me because I made them do work.
No contact with recuiters! Never return emails, phone calls or social media. Iron fisted approach to days off or vacation. Pay is very low with no advancement
they want you to work faster with no mistakes. this is impossible unless you're a robot. only men in higher positions. i feel like a number,not a human being.

I very much enjoy working for Ricoh. However, the company's outlook for the future does not emphasize my division, and that is creating a situation where employment and advancement are not realistic options for most employees.
Management runs the company poorly as far as how things are done and equipment is always down had to work 3 months by myself on night shift so employees safety is of no concern
Direction was not clear, company cares more about saving money than making employees happy. Manager had high expectations for role but pay and direction was not comparable.

Excellent training program. Great commitment from Managers to your success. Very professional atmosphere. Get to know stage of the art industry technology   through seminars, hands on training and company weekly meetings. Job demands highly motivated people due to industry competition. Overall, learned a lot and enjoyed working for RICOH.
relaxed atmosphere, unstable company overall, alot of outsourcing of jobs, was a wonderful place to work for in the begining until the company began loosing money in the US.
Capital equipment company focused on hardware.  Small sales force for multiple verticals, low compensation and minimal benefits.  Lack of true leadership.
On a typical day once you have the machines it's kind of nonstop. So for me i never got bored unless it was a slow day which wasn't that often. Coworkers made you feel like family.
Little opportunity to advance, pay is below market, no sense of work culture.  Good benefits and hours. Industry leader. Would recommend if future growth is not important.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.

I’m not a fan of this job at all because of mostly the pay. We don’t get paid enough here. The drama that takes place is too much. I don’t care for my boss at all. The only thing I can say really is good insurance benefits, some of the people here are nice.
Great company to work for, no task to difficult to tackle and plenty of people willing to assist/train. Fun atmosphere created by management throughout the year.
This review is specifically for the Farmington Hills Location.
not very supportive - new management took to much control - I would not recommend this company - after my original boss left the expectations where changed

When interviewing with the managers, ask plenty of questions about the job because the job may appear in the description that it’s what you’ll be doing but when you get into the job, it’s completely different and that’s where the disappointment sets in! The pay raises are horrible and no OT under no circumstances and if so, it HAS to be a legitimate reason. You also have to plan your vacationss well in advance and put in the time early because they can deny it, even if it’s 3 or 4 months in advance.
Great people to work with.  team mates really help each other.  Onsite manager is very easy to talk to.  Onsite Supervisor is always there when you need assistance.

Not given time to train properly and poor upper management.  Absolutely no direction from management.  Basically thrown into the deep end of the pool and told to swim.  Poor direction and almost impossible workplace.

Management made a huge purchase over 5 years ago. They over paid for a company because they did not want our competition to purchase the company. This purchase has impacted Ricoh's bottomline in a negative way.

A typical day would be very busy with different job duties.  The hardest part was working in the rain.  I did like the different duties responsibilities for my workday as it would make the day go by quick.

My Ricoh office is under contract to a large law firm. It handles legal document production, mail-room, hospitality, and other services. All Ricoh employees are expected to fill multiple roles as needed. However, I am the only one specifically detailed to the role of legal courier and court-runner. As a managed services provider for the legal industry, each assignment that Ricoh handles is unique, and for my position, especially unique, as I am making legal filings for a variety of cases, for a diverse clientele, to various courthouses at the local, state, and federal level.

Go to work every day work on copiers peinters and basic networking. Going to training is always fun get to meet new people and learn new products. Driving can be a headache sometimes have to drive over 2 hours to get to a stop. some days just wear you out.

As with any company that you decide to go to work for do as much research as you can. It’s an ok place to work and gain experience so that you either make a decision to stay, or you might get laid off, or you can use your experience to find a better job somewhere else. Just keeping it real. I know what happened to me.

My short time at ricoh was a nightmare. There is no appreciation for anything you do unless you're a higher up. To advance in the company you have to have been there for around 10 years. My lead, let's call her "M" was an absolute nightmare. Nothing was ever right to her, even if it was done the way she told you to do it. And our team lead, scott.. what a self absorbed, entitled, moronic, two faced backstabbing idiot

There is no increase in compensation with the increase in workload. There is no drive to do anything when the boss comes in and sits down behind his computer and watches YouTube videos all day. It’s just not the environment I want to be in anymore.
I enjoyed working with my fellow techs (very skilled and competent) but in recent years, in attempting to redefine the company management lost focus..

I wasn't expecting a major job move here, but after my interview and accepting the position, I thought there was a fair level of equal expectation. The hiring manager knew I was looking for a job with quick growth potential. I was told a number of things would be available to me, including flexible work location and the ability to increase the job profile. In fact, only the pay rate that was promised has been accurate.

Work hours are great. Benefits are ok. Job requires alot of driving. YOU WILL NOT WORK CLOSE TO HOME. THIS IS A LIE. managers lie and only do what's convenient  for themselves not the team. Also your "team" is everyone for themselves.

Fun working environment. good team spirit and supportive environment. Unfortunately lacked corporate support, not enough staff. I was the sole operator, and literally the site could shut down if I called in sick.
Not able to move within the company, after many years and earnings a degree you would hope to move up. They should have in place tools to promote more diversity in upward management.
They are louses especially the upper managers. Do not interview with this Japanese company. They are a 4 Billion dollar company so top heavy they lost 1 BILLION dollars in 2018.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.
Management needs to improve.
It is bad for employees seeming a relationship between supervisor and employee. The employee gets away with things other do not. So, anybody job is not secured there.
Need better management skills
Sales support by management was great but they decided to close the sales division nationwide. Company now uses resellers to service corporate accounts.
This company can be a great place to work if your manager and co-workers are great. I had both and enjoyed the job.  Left for advancement potential.  Pay is low.

I'm lucky enough to have one of the most amazing bosses that I've ever had. The job itself is very demanding but easy if you are good at self management, time management, and taking care of your site. The most enjoyable part of the job is all of the people and interaction with others. Ricoh requires a lot of unnecessary online training classes which can be very time consuming and take away from actual work. They are also a very low paid company. Considering I am an assistant site manager and all of the responsibilities that on are me, I would anticipate a higher paid wage than what I am currently at after being with them for over 6 years. However, between sick time, floating holidays and vacation, I have almost 6 weeks paid vacation a year which can make up for the lack of wages.
Closed entire department due to missmanagment. Managers were cherrypicking tasks for favorite reps, stole money from our activities budget, and basically show us how to fail at business.
Not a bad company, just your position in it, Depends on your role, either in a managed service or company direct. Culture is good and PTO as well. I can't complain otherwise.
Great commitment to learning and developing their leadership team. Very focused on the customer and growing the business profitably. Great opportunities to advance your career.
The very worst place to work!!!!!!!  Management is the worst, employees are not valued.  It wasn't  always like this.  I wouldn't refer Ricoh as company that has a future to offer.
Am looking for something "better". If found will leave. But company has same review, If company finds someone better bye. Pay make looking for some easier

Management team will say and do what it takes to make themselves look good. They have no idea how to develope, encourage, or boost moral. Management consistently deliver empty promises and are not consistant of anything else.  If your strive and learn quickly, you will not be bothered. If you struggle, there's no development. Start looking for another job. It becomes a hostile/miserable work env. HR protects the company  and management.  Remember,  that t is their job and what they are hired for.

As a whole...the company is like ever other company...just know if your a majority advancement will not be an option for you...so if your comfortable with just getting a check then this the company for you

I was a field tech here for 26 years.  They assign too large a territory for one man to handle.  Over worked, long hours, no support from managers.  They also denied me family leave which Violates  the family leave act.
I scanned, did print production, and billing. Customer service for the ones that come in requesting a print job. Deliver some print jobs to different locations
typical work day is long days
I was hired to do a job with no training, and was fired with no explanation of why. No one cares if I was there or not and the language was completely bad.

I was tasked with learning the job without on the job training consisting of billing and other application management. While my position was PSS1 (Print Support Specialist 1) my duties were not of the position but that of collecting meters across 500+ printing devices and meeting with department heads to verify billing for "prints per click".  With this position, I was able to rectify $100K in billing corrections owed to Ricoh from Metro.  After metro moved to a new contract, I was able to make the Dell account for Ricoh profitable for the first time since the contract's inception by billing out labor as needed for event setups on a one person basis rather than using excess labor that was unnecessary.

I have over 10 year's experience as a copier technician but Ricoh put me in a mail room position, and said I had to be a mail clerk feild service representative for a year and then I could apply for another position. I have talked to other employed copier technician that haven't had any experience in this field at all Ricoh works backwards.
No care about you at Ricoh. Ur only a worker. Ur pay will not change forever. They only care of the work to be done. Never care of workers well being.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.

I would have a customer to start the day would arrive at customer at 7:55am to talk to customer about the problems there having with copier  then go to copier and diagnose problem and solve. Then go to my next call.and repeat.

I have set hours from 8-4:30  M-F. I learned how sort and deliver mail to all the Departments on my location. Keeps log of items received and delivered. Responds to client requests, ensuring the accuracy of the order taken and delivery of the completed orders in a timely manner. Distributes office supplies, fax transmissions and mail to company personnel and/or designated drop-off points as required. Management  is great for my location.

Ricoh offers great marginal benefits. The only problem they have is being a technology company are always behind trends and have no customer service satisfaction department. All complaints and services issues are managed through the Account Rep and it affects their work balance and performance.
Great company to work with great benefits. Online training to move up in the Company. The pay could be better but the benefits are worth the pay greade,
Room for growth for entry level workers. Love working for various types of customers internally and externally. The job does have work life balance. Pay and Benefits are competitive.
The environment was fun and ever changing. Just like any other company or business, be careful who you trust. The one you hand the gun to may be the one to pull the trigger.
Hello All...

did well for time I was there   Until I had to move on my own inside the company for a new position   Mgmt  was not very supportive  New postion downtown was very toxic and had a horrible poor manager

Ricoh is a great, stable company with tremendous people at all levels.  I enjoyed working with great people all over the world.  There are many different facets to the business and avenues to explore.  Workforce mobility however is a challenge within the organization, but I believe they are working on that.

Ricoh is a good company to work for, I could not have asked for a better supervisor, when it comes to being fair and advancing his employees as he sees fit, he will do it, but I do understand some situations are out of his control.

I highly recommend this company for those who are recent graduates who would like to get their foot in the door in a great company from the start. There are many advances available and they offer so many classes to train and prepare you for your work with Ricoh and even beyond.

Ricoh is a nightmare in terms of stress, work ethics, and demand. It is an exaample of how not to run a corporation. It's not organized and operates on favoritism. They continue to increase work load with no increase in pay.

Good place to work at after you retire from your career. Not a place for anyone seeking advancement or to begin a productive career. Very slow work days (even on the "busy" days) and same work experience day in, day out.

Management in the maintenance group for continuous forms printing are nothing but a collection of former exceptionally poor managers, who ignore the reforms Ricoh senior management are attempting to implement.  A collection of bullies which Ricoh USA refuses to reign in.
Ive had my time with this company it's time for me to move on ..I feel like as long as I been with this company my status there would be better than it is now .. DISAPPOINTING
I have no additional feedback, I'm a 13 year tenure employee and I appreciate the opportunity, and have build some great inter-departmental relationships.
great place to work. the people are cool the work is easy. its a really good place to work. The benefits are pretty good to.I would most likely recommend this company to any friend of mine.
Very progressive company with great people and management. Competitive compensation and benefits focused on employee success. Great technology and services offerings and an industry leader

I worked for Ricoh for 14 years didn't get raise over 4 years management is VERY bad talks about employees to other employees, doesn't keep people updated on things that are happening withing the company. Let go of the good people and kept the people that does nothing or little work there I can go on for days about this company its just a bad place for anyone to work

The managers tell you what they want from you but when you give feedback or want to discuss how your doing , they don’t reply. Some of the management is approachable but I think you learn more from your co-workers. Be careful who you trust.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.

Great company to work for and the management team is on point. Can be high stressed sometimes as with any job. I would recommend this company to work for. Only negative i have is our annually pay raises are at minimum.

I was excited to start something new, however, I was very disappointed. There is no training. I had to train myself and then, when I figured it all out, I then am training a 5th person, due to the fact, previous trainees quit and one was terminated. Their health insurance is horrible. Unattainable deductible even for the lowest priced plan. You are looking at close to, if not more than $200 per month for a single person with a $7,000 deductible annually, where you still have to pay 20% of all medical services. Not worth having an insurance card in my wallet to not be able to utilize it, while just giving the company money to which, you are not covered until you pay $7K annually before medical benefits kick-in. Very sad to work full-time for a company that does not pay (salary-wise) and cannot have medical coverage.

Poor leadership- Supervisor was absent most of the time. If she was there she was calling in two hours late everyday. Or giving directions via   face time. The job itself is fast paced, repetitive and challenging at times. Lack of communication between management and staff. makes uncertain working situations on the daily. They expect you to be a machine and not complain. DONT WASTE YOUR TIME HERE FOR $13/hr. Keep looking, this place isn't worth your time or grief.

On  the road performing service calls.  Have to achieve certain numbers. Copier business is going down. Had to put up service calls and check meters to keep busy. They are branching out to other things like working on amazon lockers and cash changers for employees at Walmart and Target. Some of this is 7 days a week and outdoors.

This company looks backwards instead of forward. Not competitive, not relevant, and will only hold you back from your real career. They hire innept managers who've never worked in the industry and cannot use the computer or even do a simple quote.... who will sabatage your career.

Learn what you can learn from there are get the experience and move on. Ricoh do not pay well and lose good workers to there competitor's. Word to the wise PAY YOUR PEOPLE MORE MONEY. They care about what they do. But you let them down with cheap raises five and ten cents.
Ricoh provides an exceptional and extensive sales and product training program for each employee. There are tests which can include role-play after each subject.
A good company with many entry level positions that can lead to much more.  I have been with Ricoh for almost 8 years and have turned it into a career.
It's not a so excited work environment. Very fast pace environment. The shop manager is keen on work speed and not so keen to growth and development. I wasn't impress.
Time for me to move on.

Expectations are to meet and exceed sales targets while maintaining and growing customer relationships with current customers as well as expand the portfolio of services with those customers and also potential new clients.  There is a strong support for driving the new world of work through team collaboration.
Overall it was a pretty good company to work for. There are not many jobs in the east valley though. The vacation/sick time was really good. My manager loved to nitpick
Ricoh is a good company. They supply copy machines to customers and they contract office service personnel to customers. Fellow employees are helpful.
Ricoh has a great sales training program!  They also provide benefits for their employees. I enjoyed meeting new customers and learning about their business needs.

Nothing much to say as a former employee because my functions were different than that of other coworkers. I had a negative experience with professionalism in management, but that fell on specific managers and doesn't necessarily reflect management as a whole.

Do not promote from within, do not stick to policies they implement. Sales offerings change quarterly making it difficult to know what you will be selling long term. No organizational clarity. A place that was very much relevant in the 90s and is no longer.
They need some work as far as management and staff are concerned. There is a lack of knowledge when it comes to running the mailroom. There are also to many people

They didn't know what to do Concerning the Client not delivering the Expectations the Company asked for and there Employee's weren't taken care of the Benefit worked against you, you paid a heavy Price.
Management is very flexible and have an open door policy. Increasing morale is very important at Ricoh. Unfortunately, there has been no room for advancement in the past 3-4 years.

My experience showed me the dark underbelly ...it is "hair trigger, old school, psychologically abusive." management mindset.   If you enjoy your sanity, this current batch (group of Managers)  is not worth working with, this type of cruel and rude treatment is a personality trait they outwardly reject but it's the first and only tool in the bag they reach for consistently,  Not to mention AZ. is an "at will"  state so you can look forward to being dumped just because someone decided they didn't like you for some random reason, and they'll never tell you what it was, just .. buh bye.

Ridiculous schedules, poor management and they all answer to the clueless execs in Japan. Leaders are only looking out for themselves and constantly leave the grunge work for the worker bees with zero appreciation.
Work environment varies from site to site, typically office services, print production, mail sort, and hospitality.
Not Much to Say about the company it was a place where I gained more experience and it is very faced paced.  Wanted more and there are ways to move into over areas within the company.

The company is more concerned with outdated policies then they are with customer satisfaction. Management has no clue of what they are doing. My typical day is driving all around the city and sometimes out of town to pick-up and deliver projects.
I was laid off for second time in less than three years as part of multiple layoffs. My separation package prohibits giving any opinion or review. Not allowed to say anything.

The company could put more into the employees, the main focus is training but because of their client relationships they throw people away anytime the client does not agree.  Makes for really bad moral.
Benefits. Career Longevity lacking advancements lacking advancements and pay raises.  12 years I've been employed and there is no advancement opportunities
Mandatory OT every weekend! Didn’t care if you had a home to go home too. Forced to work double shifts if some one called out. Terrible management! Terrible experience!
Opportunities for individuals willing to fine the right placement with management. Services oriented company seeking to supply large accounts with out sourced personnel.
Breakroom on each floor , two different levels with flexible hours and managers good people, reliable training and resources for a new project brand new equipment

It has pretty good benefits if you are a FTE. Employees were encouraged to give their opinions, but they were ignored for the most part. It was impossible for me to advance my career. They kept promising advancement to me but did not deliver. Started to stagnate after 3 years, no new challenges after the three year mark. Almost impossible to make changes to ways of thinking and executions that have proven to be ineffective.

Ricoh is very unorganized. Lack of moral within the company. Ricoh does not value their employees and sell a dream to their customers just to get the contract. They are very under staffed, yet constantly downsizing departments and even getting rid of needed departments. Management has meetings twice sometimes three times a week, but there is still no progress. For a company so big they seem to not have found their way in the industry to keep up with the competition.
Other then that, it was great.  The people l worked with were incredible, and were a joy to work with. I loved working their.

Ricoh does not have any SOP, they operate of of who they like and who sells their souls to  move up in the company. Ricoh has several lawsuits against them for harassment and discrimination.Their HR team are friends with all of the managers so when things are reported to HR about violation of code of ethics, they immediately dismiss it.They need to revamp their entire management team with people who are trained to actually do the job and lead properly; without all of the ego trips.

They cant seem to identify their niche. Big market? Small market? Mid Market? Lay off a couple thousand people in the Spring and see what happens - every year. They change direction, comp plans, job titles,and keep the same executive leadership that cant seem to let a growth strategy gel and expect different results. We used to have a joke at Ricoh that if you didn't like the current version of Ricoh just wait and "Imagine Change" because it would be completely changed come springtime like clock work.

Ricoh gave me an opportunity to work with the law firm clients they were employed by due to my paralegal certification. I worked my way up to a site manager position but opted for a career change as a paralegal.
I liked the diversity of the work places. They could if paid more. They were flexible with my hours when it comes to my family. The people you work with are kind and friendly .
My supervisor does not promote or respond to his employees as I do, but the company is good to work for.  I would clean house in HR if I were the risk manager or corporate counsel.
